fields.headline: New Zealand take charge
fields.standfirst:
New Zealand 445
Zimbabwe 31-1
fields.trailText: New Zealand put an early stranglehold on the second Test against Zimbabwe during the second day with a first innings total of 465 at Harare.
fields.body:
New Zealand put an early stranglehold on the second Test against Zimbabwe during the second day with a first innings total of 465 at Harare.

A Chris Cairns century and other notable scores from Mark Richardson, Nathan Astle and Dion Nash were the mainstays of New Zealand's big total, their biggest score against Zimbabwe in 10 Test meetings.

Zimbabwe opener Gavin Rennie was dismissed for four runs as the home side's faltered to 31-1 in reply in an awkward final hour.

New Zealand's large total effectively eliminates any prospect of the home side winning the match and squaring the series, with them having lost the first Test in Bulawayo by seven wickets last week.

Cairns' 124 was two short of his best in Test cricket. He hit three sixes and 13 fours and he needed only 172 balls for his fourth century. When he reached 71 he achieved a personal Test career landmark of 2,500 runs.

He also figured with Dion Nash in New Zealand's new record eighth wicket partnership of 144.

 Glenn McGrath may have bowled his last ball for Worcestershire. The county has announced the signing of paceman Andy Bichel - their third successive Australian overseas player - to cover for McGrath next summer during the Ashes series.

fields.headline: Reverend Horton Heat
fields.standfirst:
LA2, London
**
fields.trailText:
LA2, London
**
fields.body:
When the Reverend Horton Heat strolls into town, time rolls back. The way he looks - greased-back hair, sharp jaw, crisp orange- red suit with powder-blue trim snaking up the arms - the Reverend's real name may as well be Bill Haley (it's Jim Heath). The way screaming rockabilly riffs spill from his guitar as he drawls into his square-cut microphone, you'd think Elvis had yet to go into the army.

His devoted audience are right back there with him, too: all around are motorcycle punks in leather jackets, tattooed heavies with square-tops, girls in pencil skirts. The only incongruous figure is a Vinny Jones lookalike whose idea of dancing is to grab anyone within a half-metre radius and fling them across the room, and even he is dressed as if this were a lounge-club scene from the movie Swingers.

The Reverend has his own, thankfully less violent, take on dance music, one that is still waiting for the computer chip to be invented. His honkytonk numbers are perfect for square dances, his frenzied rock'n'roll ideal for a swift jive, while his take on the cha-cha-cha, In Your Wildest Dreams, is steamingly saucy. The sounds may be old-fashioned but, over six albums (including the deliciously titled Liquor in the Front and his most recent release, Spend a Night in the Box), Heath has developed them so that everything he plays with double bassist Jimbo and drummer Scott is taut, vibrant and exhilarating: a frenzy of robust, clattering rhythms and the kind of piercing guitar action that could lead kids astray.

The trio's sound is as crisp as parched autumn leaves and as skin-lashingly clear as a freezing winter's day: that's what makes it refreshing on record, and so disappointing at the LA2. The LA2's PA is so bad you can only assume it is being run by people with degrees in making speakers sound like they're inhabited by squirrels. Listening to the Reverend play guitar should be like turning a diamond around in your hand and watching every intricate angle glitter. Here, it's like having handfuls of mud shoved down your ears. Heath's lyrics are hilarious, but choice items such as "Nature boy Jimbo, get in your pick-'em-up truck, go cruise around with Lady Luck" (from Jimbo Song) or his celebration of his "wiggle stick" - "I got a whammy bar momma, and it's just your size" - are inaudible in this mulch. Yes, rock'n'roll has a dirty sound, but here the Reverend's music is soiled in all the wrong ways.

webTitle: Danes on track to plunge euro into abyss

fields.headline: Danes on track to plunge euro into abyss
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Denmark's historic euro referendum campaign enters its final crunch week today amid mounting government gloom that opponents of the single currency are still firmly ahead.
fields.body:
Denmark's historic euro referendum campaign enters its final crunch week today amid mounting government gloom that opponents of the single currency are still firmly ahead.

Nerves are fraying, with the prime minister, Poul Nyrup Rasmussen, under heavy fire yesterday for tactical errors and colleagues admitting that the crucial vote could be lost.

If it is, the repercussions will echo far beyond this country of 5.3m, famous for its bacon, Lego and recurring bouts of worry - the "Hamlet syndrome" - over whether something is rotten in the state of Europe.

Britain and Sweden - both in the EU but not the euro-zone - are watching anxiously before making their own tough choices. And in Brussels and Frankfurt Denmark's decision will be seen as a measure of confidence in the battered euro, which fell to new lows against the dollar this week.

But as two of the latest opinion polls - Gallup and Vilstrup - confirmed leads ranging from two to 11 points for the No camp in advance of next Thursday's referendum, efforts continued to persuade Danes to change their minds.

In the Tivoli Gardens, wonderful Copenhagen's most famous attraction, employees were given time off work to debate whether or not to join the 12 countries of Euroland.

Yet there was little sign that opinions were shifting, amid concerns about the effect on Denmark's generous welfare state, dismissed by government spin doctors as scare tactics but real enough to ordinary people.

"I think that to have enough money to get into the euro zone they are starting to save on homes for the elderly and on pensions," said maintenance man Jan Persson, 56. "I'm against."

Mr Persson's defiant response is one of many indications that Denmark's latest attempt to resolve a European question, its sixth since 1972, is likely to be a close-run thing.

But the great debate is curiously muted. In the Radhus Pladsen, the heart of the capital, just a handful of posters wired to lampposts exhort citizens to say Ja or Nej on September 28.

Newspapers carry blanket coverage of the campaign, but television advertising and party meetings lack oomph because of a Scandinavian dislike of showyUS-style politics.

Public meetings are restrained and polite, with a refreshment break and community singing at one on Tuesday evening in a school in Hillerod, a small town north of Copenhagen.

There was not a cross word between Marianne Jelved, the popular, slightly schoolmarmish finance minister and Jens-Peter Bonde, the forceful Euro MP of the anti-integrationist June Movement.

Questions from the public reflect deep worries - and confusion - about exchange rates, the role of the European central bank and the dangers of speculation against the krone.

But No campaigners have cleverly widened the debate beyond the euro - thus Mr Nyrup Rasmussen's ill-advised decision, quickly retracted yesterday - to ask fellow EU leaders to guarantee Danish retirement pensions.

Part of the problem is that opponents of the single currency are defending the status quo in a rich country with low unemployment and a healthy economy, whereas supporters have to show clearly the advantages of joining.

As the krone has been pegged to the deutschmark since 1982, and now shadows the euro closely, the effect of opting in will be limited. But much damage was done by the row about EU sanctions against Austria, which bolstered the image of a meddling Europe.

Most supporters of the single currency come from Denmark's elites - in business, politics, the media and unions - while it is the little people who fret about national identity, globalisation and the ability to keep their beloved, tax-heavy Nordic welfare model.

"The better educated you are the more likely you are to vote yes," said communications graduate Stine Lolk. "Its a very big split."

"This is all about what the political parties want, not ordinary people," muttered an old lady in Hillerod, reflecting disproportionate anti-euro opposition from women.

Optimism is hard to detect in Copenhagen's gathering gloom, but the campaign is not over yet: both polls showed 13% of voters still undecided.

Even so, Anders Jensen of the Danish European movement admits: "It's looking very bad."

Watching, waiting, hoping and fearing

Britain

Downing Street will be nervously watching next week's Danish referendum, knowing that a No vote will deliver a severe blow to Tony Blair's chances of taking Britain into the single currency, writes Nicholas Watt, political correspondent.

A No vote would give a boost to William Hague's "Keep the pound" campaign by proving that voters are prepared to ignore the warning by pro-Europeans that rejecting the euro would damage their economy.

The prime minister, who instinctively wants to join the euro but is afraid of public opinion, will adopt an even more cautious approach in the event of a No. If Danes endorse the euro, the prime minister will be quietly relieved.

Sweden

A Danish No would give little comfort to Sweden's prime minister, Göran Persson, who has promised his own countrymen a similar vote some time in the future, writes Andrew Osborn.

Opinion polls show that some two out of three Swedes are opposed to trading in their krona for the single currency.

The timing of the Danish referendum is in any case awkward for the Swedes, who are due to assume the EU's rotating presidency in January and want to avoid a public debate on the euro during their six month stint.

Mr Persson's ruling Social Democratic party signed up to the euro earlier this year but other parties in his coalition are anti-euro.

France

Co-founder with Germany of the precursor to a single currency, the European Monetary System, France is so committed to the euro that a Danish No vote would be little more than a diplomatic hiccup in the midst of the French EU presidency, writes Jon Henley in Paris.

But, among France's surprisingly numerous Eurosceptics, Charles Pasqua, the rebel Gaullist and former interior minister, delights in calling the euro "the sickest currency on the planet".

Italy

Apparently unmoved by the implications of a No vote in Denmark, Italy's ardour for the euro has waned to the point of resignation. Few people seem to know or care that the referendum result could undermine the currency they fought so hard for, writes Rory Carroll in Rome .

Tired of fretting over the euro's slide against the dollar, politicians have paid scant attention to Denmark, although the minimal media coverage has tended to favour the Yes campaign.

Poland

Although EU affairs are followed closely in Poland, little coverage has been given to Denmark's referendum, mainly because it does not reflect the Polish viewpoint, writes Kate Connolly.

A referendum will probably take place on the basic points of EU membership, but most believe the euro is part of the package, and cannot be rejected.

fields.headline: Plano XXI
fields.standfirst:
Various venues, Glasgow
****
fields.trailText:
Various venues, Glasgow
****
fields.body:
And here is your starter for 10: name five contemporary Portuguese artists. Three? OK then, just your favourite. Still stuck? You're not alone.

Plano XXI, a season of Portuguese contemporary art, is currently doing its best to educate us with events in galleries, cinemas and music venues across Glasgow. It is an engaging, spirited selection of emergent, experimental works rather than established names.

Ines Paris (at Street Level Photoworks) presents her Revolutionary Kit - posters and the simplest of disruptive materials. Pieces of paper with TEMPORARILY OUT OF ORDER typed on them are piled high, just the right dimensions for a cash machine screen. It seems crazy, facile almost, as if it would never work. Then you remember the fuel crisis, the sudden simple crisis, and you know it could. Joao Tabarra (also at Street Level) prefers fantasy to revolution in his large colour photographs. The artist trawls over rocky terrain or bleak urban streets in the company of the oddest human fairy - all shimmery dress and big wand, but seemingly no magical powers.

Francisco Querios (Intermedia Gallery) is a wizard by comparison, and one with a fine sense of humour. In two short animated films, he focuses on the body in video games - its stilted and yet ultra-real quality. In one, in a My Little Pony landscape with a calming, repetitive soundtrack, girls whack each other, push each other over. It's funny in the way The Magic Roundabout (18 certificate, directed by Tarantino) would be funny.

At the G-Mac/Exhibition Space things take a darker turn, with some work that dwells rather too long on suicide and violent sexual fantasy. It treats the latter with some humour though - Joao Fonte Santa's furious black-and-white drawings are all orgiastic orifices and no trousers, one with a big JOIN NOW slogan across it. Paulo Mendes has Ken and Barbie up to all sorts in the work Kiss Me Stupid, locked away in a suburban bedroom complete with borders and a nice dressing table. We peek in; Ken, casually in flagrante, stares back in the mirror. In the centre of the exhibition space, a polystyrene head sits on a table, unexplained. There are pens for you to leave a message, many of which are in Portuguese; sex and football are the themes. We may not know the names, but that does not make Plano XXI the cultural stranger you might expect.

 Until October 14. Details: 0141-553 2620.

fields.headline: CBSO/Oramo
fields.standfirst:
Symphony Hall, Birmingham
****
fields.trailText:
Symphony Hall, Birmingham
****
fields.body:
This concert by the City of Birmingham Symphony Orchestra was dominated by the same work that opened the season the previous week: Richard Strauss's Alpine Symphony. Not far short of an hour long, in one continuous movement, this detailed evocation of a full day's mountain hike makes exhaustive use of a huge orchestra, including wind and thunder machines, cowbells and organ, as well as a brief but spectacular contribution from 12 offstage horns.

The Alpine Symphony has been dismissed as a collection of wonderful effects and not-so-wonderful tunes. That's not entirely unjust: two of the leading themes don't just teeter on the brink of corniness but plunge in head-first. But some of the orchestral effects are breathtaking: the multi-layered, cascading waterfall, the magnificent storm, and perhaps best of all, the astonishing opening tone cluster - a descending three-octave scale of B flat minor, with every note sustained by the strings. It shimmers and pulsates like a mountain viewed through heat haze. All this came over brilliantly in the CBSO's performance.

Conductor Sakari Oramo has a special flair for balancing complex textures and bringing out the leading lines so that they sing rather than just declaim. His strong sense of line kept the music moving when Strauss's imagination faltered. Even the Bing Crosbyish Sunrise theme carried complete conviction.

Oramo showed the same skill in Alban Berg's more densely written Three Pieces for Orchestra - scored for forces only slightly less vast than Strauss's. The Berg was unusually clear throughout, and the performance grew in strength and intensity towards the final, violently despairing March. Even more vividly than Ravel's better-known La Valse, Three Pieces evoke images of Vienna in terminal decline - fragments of dance and courtly music drift weirdly in and out of the teeming musical nightmare.

But it was the Strauss that dominated the evening, even if it isn't ultimately as significant or as emotionally searching as the Berg. It certainly eclipsed memories of the first piece, Mozart's compressed, one-movement Symphony No 32 in G. This is a fine piece, with a muscular springboard of a theme to set it all in motion. But the large, bass-heavy string section used by Oramo weighed the music down, despite all his efforts to drive it forward - rather like mud collecting on a runner's shoes. Even in Mozart, success isn't guaranteed.

fields.headline: DV8
fields.standfirst:
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
****
fields.trailText:
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
****
fields.body:
DV8's latest work, Can We Afford This? was actually paid for by the Sydney Olympic arts festival, where it has just received its debut. But the cost to which it refers isn't that of producing dance theatre, but the price we pay for competing in a society obsessed by image. The work's huge and talented cast spend 90 minutes desperately shaping up, showing off and sometimes playing dirty with their rivals. The references to the Olympics are unmissable. But what gives the work its brutal edge is that personal disabilities and frailties are also part of the competition.

In a confessional line-up that is strongly reminiscent of a Pina Bausch production, the performers offer up their eccentricities and pain, like victims of some gruesomely inverted beauty competition. "I'm 72," states Diana Payne Myers, the sags and wrinkles of her tiny body exposed by a bathing suit, "and I've had four lovers under 30." We laugh encouragingly, but when another man baldly introduces himself with the announcement that he has Aids, our titters falter and die.

Then there is David Toole, who has no legs but is possessed of a disorienting virtuosity. As he leaps and glides around the stage on his long, strong arms, at times addressing the audience with a cynically flirtatious wit, we start to feel cosy with his disability. He's extraordinarily gifted and funny: he doesn't need our pity. But when another performer starts hounding him with the questions we squirmingly want to ask - "Do you have a dick down there? Were you born without legs" - we're forced to recognise the humiliation Toole risks daily.

And it's a humiliation known to all performers. Paul Capsis, camp and ageing, is a vision of showbiz shame as his hysterical tactics for wooing the audience start to look increasingly forlorn. Dancer Vivien Wood tells us that since she's 40 and in her last show, she doesn't care how little she is paid. Lawrence Goldhuber is simply fat. He weighs 330lb, and by way of apology he fixes us with the unwaveringly jolly smile required of the overweight.

Not that this is a freak show. Not only are the 17 members of the cast talented dancers, singers and comedians, they portray extraordinarily unsentimental, sharp-featured personae. They give us acting of a high order, and director Lloyd Newson has done an impressive job in eliciting it. The problem is that he has too much material. Most performers appear on stage so briefly that we barely connect with them. And the work deliberately eschews the kind of formal structure that would knit the cast into some larger imaginative world, some larger journey. Our sense of being voyeurs isn't enough. Though we may momentarily feel warmth, discomfort or shame, our emotions are rarely more than pinpricks. Can We Afford This? is very, very entertaining, but it doesn't draw blood.

 Until September 29. Box office: 020-7960 4242.

The work's huge and talented cast spend 90 minutes desperately shaping up, showing off and sometimes playing dirty with their rivals. The references to the Olympics are unmissable. But what gives the work its brutal edge is that personal disabilities and frailties are also part of the competition. In a confessional line-up that is strongly reminiscent of a Pina Bausch production, the performers offer up their eccentricities and pain, like victims of some gruesomely inverted beauty competition. "I'm 72," states Diana Payne Myers, the sags and wrinkles of her tiny body exposed by a bathing suit, "and I've had four lovers under 30." We laugh encouragingly, but when another man baldly introduces himself with the announcement that he has Aids, our titters falter and die. Then there is David Toole, who has no legs but is possessed of a disorienting virtuosity. As he leaps and glides around the stage on his long, strong arms, at times addressing the audience with a cynically flirtatious wit, we start to feel cosy with his disability. He's extraordinarily gifted and funny: he doesn't need our pity. But when another performer starts hounding him with the questions we squirmingly want to ask - "Do you have a dick down there? Were you born without legs" - we're forced to recognise the humiliation Toole risks daily. And it's a humiliation known to all performers. Paul Capsis, camp and ageing, is a vision of showbiz shame as his hysterical tactics for wooing the audience start to look increasingly forlorn. Dancer Vivien Wood tells us that since she's 40 and in her last show, she doesn't care how little she is paid. Lawrence Goldhuber is simply fat. He weighs 330lb, and by way of apology he fixes us with the unwaveringly jolly smile required of the overweight. Not that this is a freak show. Not only are the 17 members of the cast talented dancers, singers and comedians, they portray extraordinarily unsentimental, sharp-featured personae. They give us acting of a high order, and director Lloyd Newson has done an impressive job in eliciting it. The problem is that he has too much material. Most performers appear on stage so briefly that we barely connect with them. And the work deliberately eschews the kind of formal structure that would knit the cast into some larger imaginative world, some larger journey. Our sense of being voyeurs isn't enough. Though we may momentarily feel warmth, discomfort or shame, our emotions are rarely more than pinpricks. Can We Afford This? is very, very entertaining, but it doesn't draw blood.  Until September 29. Box office: 020-7960 4242.

fields.headline: The Barretts of Wimpole Street
fields.standfirst:
Pleasance, London
****
fields.trailText:
Pleasance, London
****
fields.body:
The nature of truth and fiction, biography and creative writing, and the hidden agenda - conscious and unconscious - of writers, all come under scrutiny in this thoroughly entertaining production that sees Trestle Theatre Company, one of the pioneers of mask theatre in this country, bouncing back into the theatrical premier division.

The establishment of a new, permanent ensemble of actors bodes very well indeed. Working for the first time with an existing script, the company take Rudolf Besier's old potboiler, written years before the discovery of the correspondence that shed new light on the life of Elizabeth Barrett and her elopement with fellow Victorian poet Robert Browning, and render it fresh, insightful and very modern.

This is a piece of creative vandalism. Masks, integrated signing, books that flap their pages like angels' wings, a talking dog and a great deal of probing psychological detail all play their part in the triumphant success of a two-hour piece that is as endearing as it is eccentric.

The performances have the lightest of touches, with Janet Bamford outstanding as the spirited Elizabeth who nonetheless colludes in her own psychological imprisonment. Addicted to opium after a teenage accident, Elizabeth is portrayed as a bird in a cage. She is imprisoned by ill health, her fear of living life to the full and her tyrannical father. Only love sets her free.

One of the best things about the evening is the portrayal of Mr Barrett as a silent, masked figure, whose absence is almost as ominous as his presence. External reality and the workings of Elizabeth's mind collide in strange hallucinatory interludes, the large Barrett family clan is portrayed with an Alice in Wonderland-style invention, and at the end Elizabeth's escape is hauntingly depicted by an empty room transformed into a whirligig that represents the passing years of happy married life. A first-rate piece of theatre that is both fun and thoughtful.

 At the Pleasance, London N7 (020-7609 1800), tonight; the Swan, Worcester (01905 27322), from tomorrow till Saturday; and the Mechanics, Burnley (01282 664400), on Wednesday.

fields.headline: Chancellor's dilemma: to save or spend surplus
fields.standfirst:
Special report: New Labour in power
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: News Analysis: Gordon Brown faces one of the most difficult decisions of his political life...
fields.body:
Almost any previous occupant of 11 Downing Street would have been ecstatic at the news yesterday that the treasury's coffers are over-flowing with cash in time for next year's pre-election budget. Not Gordon Brown.

Forecasts from top City experts that Mr Brown may have a surplus of at least £15 billion in his war chest next spring - £10 billion more than he was predicting in March - come at the worst possible time for the chancellor in the wake of last week's fuel crisis.

Government attempts to plead poverty in response to the protests, claiming that the price of lower petrol duties would be cuts in public spending on schools and hospitals, are difficult to sustain when tax revenues are pouring into the exchequer.

With the Conservatives baying for tax cuts, the government now faces a dilemma. On the one hand, Mr Brown has the money in the bank to ease the tax burden next spring, thereby appeasing disgruntled swing voters seen as crucial to a second Blair victory. But, on the other hand, an over-generous package of tax cuts would run the risk of stimulating a Lawson-style inflationary boom, and would be certain to trigger higher interest rates from the Bank of England. The next six months will be spent trying to steer a path between the politics and the economics of tax cuts.

There is no doubt that 8 years of continual growth have left the public finances in rude good health. Yesterday's figures show that the Chancellor's ballooning surplus is due to a combination of higher-than-expected income from taxes and lower-than-expected public spending.

The strong economy and rapidly falling unemployment mean that tax receipts are growing much faster than forecast at the time of the Budget, when it was assumed that the number of people out of work and claiming benefit would average 1.16m this year. Last month's total of unemployed was 1.07m. Within months, the dole queues are likely to shrink below the 1m level for the first time since the late 1970s.

In March, Mr Brown predicted that central government receipts, which make up the vast bulk of government income, would grow from £335.1bn last year to £352.8bn this year, an increase of 5.3%. So far this year they have expanded by 9.1%, with income tax accounting for most of the increase, up 9.3% in the first 5 months of the financial year, against the Chancellor's full-year Budget forecast of 6.1%. More people are in work and paying tax, and self-assessment is a nice little earner for the inland revenue, with the honesty of tax payers increasing the yield.

Despite its claims, the government is reaping a windfall from higher oil prices, although the source of the extra cash is not the consumers but North sea producers. The Budget assumed that oil prices would average $22.40(£15.80) a barrel whereas it is currently well over $30(£21), giving the Treasury an extra £2-3bn as a result of higher production and bigger profits for the oil companies.

While cash is flooding in to the Treasury's coffers, ministers seem curiously reluctant to part with the cash they have been allocated, particularly on public in vestment, where spending last year was lower than under John Major.

Last year saw the public sector spending as a percentage of GDP fall to its lowest level for 37 years. The figures for this year show little sign of a quick turnaround. The Chancellor had predicted that current spending would rise by about 8% this year but so far it is up by 5-6%.

Jonathan Loynes, chief British econo mist at the consultancy Capital Economics, said the shortfall in spending was due to many factors, including bureaucratic delays, staff shortages in the public sector, the shrinking dole queue, which reduces social security payments, and falling interest payments on government debt. David Walton of Goldman Sachs warned that overall government spending could increase with big public investment projects due to come on stream later in the year. But he added: "The numbers are looking a lot better than appeared at Budget time."

Even allowing for a rebound in spending and a deterioration in the growth of tax receipts over the rest of the year, City economists say Mr Brown will be sitting on at least an extra £10bn compared to his Budget forecast. His surplus is likely to be near £15bn and may even be larger.

A simple extrapolation from the surplus for the first five months of this year, suggests a surplus of £24bn is possible.

Richard Iley of the Dutch bank ABN-AMRO said: "Faced with this embarrassment of riches and growing political problems, a tax cutting budget next March increasingly looks inevitable. But with the biggest fiscal stimulus for 25 years already in the pipeline, any further fiscal loosening will only further increase upward pressure on interest rates." That is Brown's dilemma. Although taxpayers are watching Mr Brown's every move, so too is the Bank of England.

webTitle: Future for borrowing costs is on a knife edge

fields.headline: Future for borrowing costs is on a knife edge
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Hawks on the Bank of England's rate-setting committee continued to press the case for higher interest rates despite a run of inflation-friendly data in August, according to the minutes of this month's meeting, published yesterday.
fields.body:
Hawks on the Bank of England's rate-setting committee continued to press the case for higher interest rates despite a run of inflation-friendly data in August, according to the minutes of this month's meeting, published yesterday.

For the second month in a row, the committee was split 5-4 in favour of leaving borrowing costs at 6%.

City analysts said the narrowness of the margin suggested future votes could go either way.

Glenn Davies of Credit Lyonnais said: "It suggests the situation is still really on a knife edge."

Renewed expectation of higher interest rates boosted the pound against the euro, up 0.0145 at 1.6676 on the day. A rise against the dollar was short-lived, however.

Deputy governors Mervyn King and David Clementi, independent member Stephen Nickell and chief economist John Vickers, attending his last meeting before becoming head of the office of fair trading, were unimpressed by falling earnings growth, saying it reflected "transitory movements in bonuses".

They also expressed worries about about the inflationary consequences of higher public spending.

"Given that there were no pressing reasons to postpone such a move, an immediate increase of 25 basis points in the repo rate warranted," the minutes said.

But the rest of the committee - governor Sir Eddie George, Christopher Allsopp, DeAnne Julius, Ian Plenderleith and Sushil Wadhwani - resisted, citing evidence of moderating domestic demand growth, a less buoyant world economy and falls in some measures of inflation.

While higher oil prices might boost inflation in the short term, they would merely push it closer to target. "In the long run the oil price might fall back in line with market expectations, and if it did not it would tend to dampen domestic demand both here and abroad."

fields.headline: Coronation of Poppea
fields.standfirst:
London Coliseum
***
fields.trailText:
London Coliseum
***
fields.body:
The gilded staircase has gone, replaced by a circular platform covering half the stage, and a collection of classical statuary. In the second instalment of English National Opera's Italian Season, the transformation of Stefanos Lazaridis's set gives Monteverdi's The Coronation of Poppea a very different environment from the previous evening's Manon Lescaut.

In fact, Steven Pimlott's staging does not make persistent use of the levels built into all that scaffolding. The goddess Love delivers the prologue from a platform high above the proscenium, Nero and Seneca conduct their argument across the heads of those sitting in the stalls, and Otho's escape in drag after his botched attempt to murder Octavia takes him on a circuit of the theatre at circle level - but the core of the drama is played out on that central disc, with the orchestra upstage behind it.

Monteverdi's masterpiece was written for a paying public in 1640s Venice. It was intended to be popular music theatre - one of the first operas to concern itself with real historical characters rather than mythical beings - and Pimlott emphasises that accessibility with Ingeborg Bernerth's mix of ancient and modern costumes. Sometimes, however, he pays more attention to the theatre than the music. The score has been tactfully cut, a couple of characters omitted and others combined, so that the action is pacy and the laughs come thick and fast. If any of the audience is in any doubt that the driving force of the piece is sex, the explicitness of much of the action, from the moment that Nero makes his first entrance naked, will soon convince them.

Words come across clearly, though in Christopher Cowell's strenuously demotic English translation, full of "tosspots" and "bastards", the natural stresses of the vocal lines often go hang for the sake of the verbal payoff.

If all the constant romping eventually becomes tiresome, the standard of the singing never flags. First and foremost there is Alice Coote's Poppea, a wonderful combination of fanatical ambition and allure. Sarah Connolly's Octavia is a real fire-breather, Michael Chance's Otho is affectingly desperate, and Susan Gritton makes a pert Drusilla. As Seneca, Eric Owens makes one of the great bores in opera more sympathetic than usual, while Anne-Marie Owens comes up with a real party piece in Arnalta's final number. Only the American counter tenor David Walker as Nero disappoints with his reedy, petulant-sounding tone.

Harry Christophers conducts, using a small band of strings, recorders and the usual array of plucked things. The pacing was not always as lively as it could have been, but with so much going on around him perhaps he is wise to take a back seat.

 In rep until October 21 and live on Radio 3 on October 12. Box office: 020-7632 8300.

fields.headline: Hedwig and the Angry Inch
fields.standfirst:
Playhouse, London
***
fields.trailText:
Playhouse, London
***
fields.body:
In the days when rock took itself deadly seriously, music fans despised rock theatre. You wouldn't be seen dead near The Rocky Horror Show. But now the time may be right for a musical that plays it louder and more lurid than the real thing. That would explain the American success of transsexual rocker Hedwig, who arrives in London trailing plaudits from the likes of David Bowie. For much of the show, Hedwig looks suspiciously like the new Frank N Furter - an innuendo-spouting wigs-and-tights creation coasting on mouldy 70s garage rock.

The invention of writer John Cameron Mitchell, Hedwig Schmidt (Michael Cerveris) was once Hansel, a pretty German boy who moves to the States and becomes Hedwig in a botched op that leaves her with the "angry inch" of the title. Later she moulds a clueless nerd into stadium rocker Tommy, and realises that he is the missing half of Hedwig's platonic hermaphrodite self.

This is an odd show, part hoary rock routine, part whorish drag stand-up. Endearingly clumpy with his muscular legs, Cerveris comes on in a huge blonde wig and a tassled cowgirl outfit that make him look like Madame de Pompadour masquerading as a Roman wrestler.

For much of the time Cerveris never quite brings Hedwig alive. The subtleties of Mitchell's eleganttext tend to get lost in his off-hand delivery and strangled drawl. But about an hour in Hedwig becomes a dramatic character rather than a routine - when she berates Tommy for not loving her properly, Cerveris really starts working our emotions. Stephen Trask's songs take off too: the anguished Bowie pastiche of the closing Midnight Radio is surprisingly stirring.

The narrative sketchiness means that Hedwig's other other half, scowling Croatian biker Yitzak, never becomes more than an on-stage running gag. Yet he (in reality she - Elizabeth Marsh, in convincingly thuggish scowl and stubble) more than matches Hedwig for moody presence.

Despite the play's theme of sexual and political identity, the point it makes most effectively is that American mainstream rock effectively desexed the punk tradition. Todd Haynes's glam movie Velvet Goldmine said all this, and to better music. Still, Hedwig's cult status stands a chance of travelling, although she treads a dangerous line between the retro and the just plain dated.

 Until November 11. Box office: 020-7839 4401.

fields.headline: Under the Blue Sky
fields.standfirst:
Royal Court, London
****
fields.trailText:
Royal Court, London
****
fields.body:
The playwright David Eldridge has been labelled "promising" ever since Serving It Up at the Bush four years ago. With this new play at the Royal Court's Theatre Upstairs, that promise is richly fulfilled. It's a kind of teachers' La Ronde, which deals, in wittily circular fashion, with romantic and sexual agony among the academic classes.

The play consists of three interlinked duologues. In the first Nick, a London comprehensive teacher, is cooking dinner for the adoring Helen; a crisis erupts when he tells her he plans to move to an independent school. The action cuts swiftly to a horny Hornchuch encounter between the voracious Michelle and the prematurely ejaculating Graham; as the randy maths teacher humiliates her partner, we realise the one-night stand is a means of avenging herself on the faithless Nick.

The off-stage drama is finally resolved in the third section, set in a Devon garden, where 58-year-old Anne breaks the pattern of platonic holidays with 42-year-old Robert, a colleague of all the previous characters.

Eldridge's point is that for teachers it's peculiarly difficult to harmonise public and private lives. They're meant to be moral guardians, yet they are subject to as much sexual confusion as the taught. You see this most clearly in the biliously brilliant middle section, where professional duties invade the bedroom. Michelle is a female Don Juan who regards her lovers as so many mathematical conquests; the shyly inexperienced Graham, who runs the school's Combined Cadet Force, plays the role of a wounded combatant.

Eldridge is extremely good on the devouring nature of teaching. I am less persuaded by his attempt to link the action to cosmic violence. The first scene takes place at the time of the IRA docklands bombing; in the final scene Anne has a long speech describing an aunt's romantic attachment to a first world war soldier. But although Anne's male chum suggests that "most of what's happened in the last 80 years has been because of that dreadful war", it's too big an issue to launch so late in the action.

But this is still an absorbing play, directed with cool precision by Rufus Norris and finely acted by the three couples. Justin Salinger and Samantha Edmonds invest their kitchen encounter with a sense of danger, Lisa Palfrey and Jonathan Cullen romp exquisitely in the bedroom, and Sheila Hancock and Stanley Townsend subtly suggest that mature teachers are best equipped to learn a lesson in romantic love.

 Until October 7. Box office: 020-7565 5000.

In the first Nick, a London comprehensive teacher, is cooking dinner for the adoring Helen; a crisis erupts when he tells her he plans to move to an independent school. The action cuts swiftly to a horny Hornchuch encounter between the voracious Michelle and the prematurely ejaculating Graham; as the randy maths teacher humiliates her partner, we realise the one-night stand is a means of avenging herself on the faithless Nick. The off-stage drama is finally resolved in the third section, set in a Devon garden, where 58-year-old Anne breaks the pattern of platonic holidays with 42-year-old Robert, a colleague of all the previous characters. Eldridge's point is that for teachers it's peculiarly difficult to harmonise public and private lives. They're meant to be moral guardians, yet they are subject to as much sexual confusion as the taught. You see this most clearly in the biliously brilliant middle section, where professional duties invade the bedroom. Michelle is a female Don Juan who regards her lovers as so many mathematical conquests; the shyly inexperienced Graham, who runs the school's Combined Cadet Force, plays the role of a wounded combatant. Eldridge is extremely good on the devouring nature of teaching. I am less persuaded by his attempt to link the action to cosmic violence. The first scene takes place at the time of the IRA docklands bombing; in the final scene Anne has a long speech describing an aunt's romantic attachment to a first world war soldier. But although Anne's male chum suggests that "most of what's happened in the last 80 years has been because of that dreadful war", it's too big an issue to launch so late in the action. But this is still an absorbing play, directed with cool precision by Rufus Norris and finely acted by the three couples. Justin Salinger and Samantha Edmonds invest their kitchen encounter with a sense of danger, Lisa Palfrey and Jonathan Cullen romp exquisitely in the bedroom, and Sheila Hancock and Stanley Townsend subtly suggest that mature teachers are best equipped to learn a lesson in romantic love.  Until October 7. Box office: 020-7565 5000.

webTitle: Wembley to bow out with a bang

fields.headline: Wembley to bow out with a bang
fields.trailText: Wembley stadium will host a charity ball hours before it is demolished, the event organisers and FA Cup sponsor Axa announced yesterday.
fields.body:
Wembley stadium will host a charity ball hours before it is demolished, the event organisers and FA Cup sponsor Axa announced yesterday.

Stars from Wembley past and present will gather in a five-storey high transparent tent during the event, scheduled for November 2.

The ball, part of which will be shown live on television, is expected to raise £1m for the charity National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children full stop campaign.

Bob Stubbs, the Wembley chief executive, said: "We are delighted that the old stadium will have such a fitting finale. Not just a celebration of all that is good about Wembley, but also such an important fund-raising event."

David Richards, the Premier League chairman, added: "The final ball gives everyone in sport, showbusiness and the business world the opportunity to pull together by paying their last respects to this magnificent venue."

An Axa spokeswoman said: "We have invited football contacts, blue chip companies and a range of stars and we've had an awesome response."

fields.headline: Newcastle close in on £2.25m Lua-Lua
fields.trailText: Cash-strapped Colchester have agreed to sell the teenage winger-cum-striker Lomano Lua-Lua to Newcastle for a fee of £2.25m.
fields.body:
Cash-strapped Colchester have agreed to sell the teenage winger-cum-striker Lomano Lua-Lua to Newcastle for a fee of £2.25m.

Although the Tyneside club had, of late, made little attempt to conceal their interest in Lua-Lua, Bobby Robson had not been expected to table a formal bid until after he had personally run the rule over the Zaire-born 19-year-old, possibly next week.

However, Robson was so distressed by the manner of his team's defeat at Southampton last Saturday that he sought permission from his board of directors to open negotiations with Colchester United.

The fee Colchester will get, after the player has undergone a medical at St James' Park later today, will be 15 times their previous record of £150,000, picked up four years ago when Mark Kinsella joined Charlton Athletic.

The deal also represents something of a coup for Robson, who has beaten off stiff competition from a host of clubs, including Rangers, Tottenham Hotspur, West Ham United and Birmingham City.

"We could have sat tight but we were fully aware that other clubs were interested in signing him," said Robson.

"I do see him as a very special talent. He does need to be nursed, cherished and developed but he is a most promising talent. We have bought for the future."

Robson conceded that his expensively assembled side's capitulation to Southampton last weekend had prompted him to open his corporate cheque-book yet again.

"We have to get our act together because I am not prepared to tolerate what I saw during the second half on Saturday," he said.

Robson lined up a second deal yesterday, taking on a two-week trial the Trinidad and Tobago international defender Dennis Lawrence, whom he spotted during a pre-season tour of the Caribbean.

Meanwhile the England coach Kevin Keegan has indicated that David Beckham is likely to start again in the centre of midfield for next month's World Cup qualifier against Germany.

The Manchester United player's encouraging performance in a central role against France in Paris earlier this month, coupled with injuries to a number of the alternatives, mean that Beckham may well be asked to perform a repeat performance at Wembley. "I will look at it," said Keegan. "It depends who turns up fit."

Uefa has revealed that its president, Lennart Johansson, fell ill during a trip to the Olympics and has been fitted with a pacemaker.

The Swede, who suffered a reaction to his flight to Sydney, is now recuperating after an operation.

fields.headline: Hall shuts door on Preston
fields.trailText: They came with genuine hope, but in the end the only upset last night was amongst the bedraggled Preston support.
fields.body:
They came with genuine hope, but in the end the only upset last night was amongst the bedraggled Preston support.

Paul Williams's second-half dismissal frayed Coventry nerves but a brace of first-half goals and a penalty from the manager's son, Gavin Strachan, after Moustapha Hadji had been felled virtually ensured the Premiership club safe passage into the Worthington Cup third round.

Coventry's tendency to self-destruct in ties such as this had Preston drooling in anticipation of a cup shock. Two years ago City tripped up against a Luton side which included Preston's right-back Graham Alexander, while last season they were left singing the Sky Blues after a 5-1 humbling at Tranmere.

With the home team invincible at Deepdale since early March, Alexander must have fancied his chances of rekindling a few happy memories.

But none of those 11 unbeaten games was against such lofty opposition as it took just four minutes for Premiership class to tell. Youssef Chippo had time to measure his left-wing cross. The diminutive Peruvian Ysreal Zuniga leapt while those around him remained grounded to plant a header beyond David Lucas.

The visitors doubled their lead on the stroke of half-time. Mustapha Hadji's corner was nodded back by a combination of Carlton Palmer and Preston's Rob Edwards and Mar cus Hall, unmarked on the edge of the area, volleyed home.

From such superiority, however, Coventry wavered two minutes into the second half as Williams was penalised for handling Paul McKenna's shot in the area. Alexander confidently dispatched the penalty beyond Hedman and, had Cartwright not air kicked when in front of goal moments later, parity would have been restored.

Williams, booked for a first half foul on Steve Basham, was dismissed after a scuffle with Cartwright and Preston poured through the hole left by his departure.

fields.headline: Campbell crocked and Sullivan sent off
fields.trailText:
Brentford 0 - 0 Tottenham Hotspur
A nasty night in West London and a wretched one for Tottenham who lost Sol Campbell with a suspected dislocated shoulder.
fields.body:
A nasty night in West London and a wretched one for Tottenham who lost Sol Campbell with a suspected dislocated shoulder that puts a doubt over his availability for England in next month's World Cup tie with Germany. They then lost Neil Sullivan to a second half red card.

That they did not also lose the game was down to more luck than judgement though they had the better chances to break the deadlock on a ground where Bristol Rovers recently scored six.

Wet Tuesdays at Griffin Park are presumably not why Sergei Rebrov turned down the chance to sign for AC Milan in preference for White Hart Lane. At least George Graham did a service to the competition in naming pretty much a full-strength side: cynics would argue that it is in fact Tottenham's only hope of silverware.

For the first few minutes Spurs could not get out of their half. They clearly weren't comfortable and it took them a decent time to get to grips with Brentford's uncompromising approach.

Neil Sullivan was busier than he had a right to expect and come the 14th minute he was reprieved when Gavin Mahon, emerging on the end of an instant cross from Martin Rowlands, forced his header too high.

The escape shook Spurs into a response but then they began to miss chances. The finish from Matthew Etherington was especially poor after Steffen Iversen had found a gap and Oyvind Leonhardsen had squared unselfishly.

Sol Campbell then prodded a free kick wide but the Spurs' captain remained on the field only another six minutes before injury forced him off. Brentford sensed their chance more than ever now though to be fair Campbell had been less than secure, discomforted by the aggressive leanings of the Brentford strikers who were prepared to compete for everything.

There was much to and fro but precious little end product. Rebrov, set up by Leonhardsen, finished poorly. It summed up Tottenham's night which then took another turn for the worse with the dismissal of their goalkeeper.

A huge hole opened up for Paul Evans following Robert Quinn's astute pass and as the midfielder pushed the ball wide of the onrushing Sullivan he was brought down yards outside the penalty area.

On came Ian Walker whose dismay at losing his place has produced in recent days a request for a transfer (granted) and a scathing attack on his manager. The replacement showed no rustiness as he went low to collect Evans's free kick.

Rebrov then produced a vicious shot which Olafur Gottskalksson did well to turn over. The final minute, however, belonged to Brentford and Andy Scott had a good sight of goal but finished wildly. A miserable night all round

fields.headline: Wenger to go all-out attack
fields.trailText: Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger will continue to rotate his forwards tonight as he attempts to reverse the failure to translate chances into goals that has hampered the team's progress.
fields.body:
David Seaman was enjoying his 37th birthday celebrations in the restaurant at Arsenal's training ground yesterday. But while the goalkeeper was presumably opening his barber's vouchers, Arsène Wenger's thoughts were focused on the other end of the field.

The Arsenal manager does not plan to make a habit of fielding four strikers, as he did to salvage a point at Chelsea. But he is considering starting with three, and for most defences that is terrifying enough.

His task of keeping four world-class forwards happy sounds as easy as outswimming Ian Thorpe in a space suit. Behind the pace of Thierry Henry and Sylvain Wiltord could soon lurk the craft of Nwankwo Kanu or Dennis Bergkamp, whom Wenger wants to keep for the rest of his career.

"I'm not ruling out that it could become a three, with one playing slightly behind," the manager said. "Kanu has shown he can play there and Dennis can play behind the strikers so we might try to experiment. I think if you ask Dennis he would prefer to play behind the strikers."

A failure to translate chances into goals has hampered Arsenal, though the adventure is unlikely to begin against Ukraine's Shakhtar Donetsk tonight. And much as Wenger is committed to attack - all the more so now his defence is weaker - he will go on rotating his forwards.

"We measured last season at Manchester United that Thierry Henry made 84 sprints between 10 and 15 yards, with an average recovery time of 27.5secs over 90 minutes," he said. "You cannot repeat that every three days, and a tired player is more likely to get injured."

After winning 1-0 at Sparta Prague, Wenger knows a victory tonight would be a "big step" towards the second phase, but the Frenchman says Lazio were flattered by their 3-0 win at Donetsk last week.

"Donetsk are a physically strong side with a lot of movement and when they win the ball they come out very quickly and directly. It's a bit like the Dynamo Kiev we saw at Wembley."

That Kiev side of two seasons ago included Sergei Rebrov, and the Spurs striker will be at Highbury to support Donetsk, his hometown club with whom he began his career.

"It's a young team with good discipline like Dynamo Kiev," Rebrov warned.

fields.headline: Gambling on limited funds
fields.trailText: Dick Advocaat fears Rangers are not rich enough to fulfil their lofty ambitions and tonight's match in the wealthy principality will surely be a sterner test than last week's run-out against Sturm Graz.
fields.body:
Money talks in Monaco, a principality which has the endearing quality of looking exactly as one expects a glorified gambling den to look, and the Rangers manager Dick Advocaat could be forgiven for dwelling on this stark fact of life as he led his players through final preparations for their second Group D match in the Stade Louis II tonight.

Advocaat is a convincing character, strong and gifted in his craft, but he has voiced one recurring theme throughout his time with Rangers - his fear that the Glasgow club is not rich enough to fulfil its lofty ambitions.

Tonight in Monte Carlo another test of this awaits. All the domestic fodder successfully dealt with in Scotland will not please at Ibrox like a gallant run in the Champions League.

Last week Rangers took Sturm Graz apart 5-0 but a few Monaco players, and one in particular, have convinced Advocaat that his team now face a much tougher test.

Shabani Nonda, the Congo striker whom Monaco bought for £13m from Rennes, was once targeted by Advocaat. His presence tonight for the French champions will only serve to remind the Dutchman that he would have represented an investment too far.

The Ibrox manager has had to learn in his two seasons that hoisting Rangers from the Scottish scene to the European stage has required a gambler's instinct. In some of his moves, he has not always proved lucky.

One of Advocaat's best investments was the gifted Dutch striker, Michael Mols, from Utrecht. It could be argued that Rangers' run in Europe last season ended the moment Mols left the field in Munich's Olympic Stadium to a year of cruciate ligament repair.

Mols played against Sturm Graz last week but he is still not fully fit. Along with Jorg Albertz, who has an eye infection, he is listed doubtful for Rangers. "We need 11 fit men against Monaco. They are the French champions, they are sharp and aggressive and everyone knows about their quality," said Advocaat.

Beside Nonda, Advocaat has pinpointed two other Monaco danger men: the 31-year-old striker Italian Marco Simone and the midfielder Ludovic Giuly, a £4m signing from Lyon capable of penetrating runs on the right.

"How we cope with these three will determine how well we do," said Advocaat, sounding like a man about to throw the dice.

webTitle: Champions League: Dvnamo Kiev 0 - 0 Manchester United

fields.headline: United show their mettle
fields.standfirst: Minute-by-minute match report
fields.trailText: Manchester United emerged unscathed from a testing encounter after a match in which all the gold stars went to their defenders.
fields.body:
Manchester United emerged unscathed from a testing examination here last night after a match in which all the gold stars went to their defenders.

For long periods they were forced into a rearguard action against a lively Dynamo side for whom Maksim Shatskikh twice struck the woodwork in the second half.

But on a night when the greasy surface played a significant contribution, and against a side that Sir Alex Ferguson has nominated as their main rivals in Group G, the United manager should be satisfied enough that his team avoided being sucked under in the near quagmire.

The average monthly income here is £32 but even with an admission price of £7 a crowd of more than 10 times Dynamo's usual league attendance had made it to the Respublikanski.

Semi-finalists two seasons ago, Dynamo's credentials make for heady stuff: 21 championships in 29 years, three league doubles in succession and 15 straight wins at home.

As if to demonstrate they meant business, the entire team visited a barber on Monday to have their hair shorn. Bad news, perhaps, for match commentators but United have a couple of 'grade ones' themselves so if it was intended to intimidate it was never likely to succeed.

A heavy pitch caused by 48 hours of dank, east European weather persuaded Ferguson it was an inopportune moment to recall Jaap Stam while he is troubled by a recurring achilles problem.

Never one to conform to predictability, the United manager re-united Andy Cole and Dwight Yorke for their first start of the season, with Teddy Sheringham relegated to the bench and Nicky Butt's combative talents preferred to Paul Scholes's attacking guile.

If that suggested Ferguson was intent on keeping things tight, it looked like an astute decision throughout the opening exchanges as Dynamo's brand of swift and incisive attacking threatened.

Once they had settled down, however, United started showing a few slick touches of their own, Yorke toe-poking a shot narrowly wide and Cole stretching the Dynamo goalkeeper Olexandr Shovkovskyi.

As United gradually began to take command, Cole also saw a powerful left-foot effort fly just wide before Roy Keane tested Shovkovskyi from 20 yards.

Dynamo remained potent, especially on the counter-attack, and Raimond Van der Gouw had to be alert to deny Valiantsin Bialkevich after he had manoeuvred a shooting opportunity from the edge of United's penalty area.

But United were struggling to get their game going and Kiev coach Valery Lobanovskyi's suggestion that United were "vulnerable" were given some credence early in the second half when the Uzbek forward Shatshikh eluded some debatable marking to drive a shot against the crossbar from the right of Van der Gouw's goal.

From the game's best moment the Dutch goalkeeper, deputising for Fabien Barthez, then turned a dipping 20-yarder from Shatskikh against the inside of his left-hand post, gratefully scooping up the rebound.

After that it always looked likely that the game would be settled by one goal - but with David Beckham well chaperoned, Ryan Giggs subdued and Roy Keane more often that not on defensive duty the ammunition for Cole and Yorke was meagre in its supply.

The Belgian side Anderlecht, who were comprehensively beaten 5-1 by United at Old Trafford last week, grabbed a 1-0 win in the other Group G game thanks to a goal by Dheedene against the Dutchmen of PSV Eindhoven.

Dynamo Kiev (4-4-2): Shovkovskyi; Dmytrulin, Vaschuk, Holovko, Nesmachnyi; Khatskevitch, Bialkevich, Kaladze, Husin (Fedorov 86); Demetradze (Kuzmichev 68), Shatshikh. Subs : Kernozenko, Guerassimenko, Yashkin, Bodnar, Serebrennikov.

Manchester United (4-4-2): Van der Gouw; Irwin, G Neville, Johnsen, Silvestre, Irwin; Beckham, Butt, Keane, Giggs; Cole (Solskjaer77), Yorke (Sheringham 67). Subs: Bosnich, Wallwork, Stam, P Neville, Scholes.

Referee: K Nielsen (Denmark).

Never one to conform to predictability, the United manager re-united Andy Cole and Dwight Yorke for their first start of the season, with Teddy Sheringham relegated to the bench and Nicky Butt's combative talents preferred to Paul Scholes's attacking guile. If that suggested Ferguson was intent on keeping things tight, it looked like an astute decision throughout the opening exchanges as Dynamo's brand of swift and incisive attacking threatened. Once they had settled down, however, United started showing a few slick touches of their own, Yorke toe-poking a shot narrowly wide and Cole stretching the Dynamo goalkeeper Olexandr Shovkovskyi. As United gradually began to take command, Cole also saw a powerful left-foot effort fly just wide before Roy Keane tested Shovkovskyi from 20 yards. Dynamo remained potent, especially on the counter-attack, and Raimond Van der Gouw had to be alert to deny Valiantsin Bialkevich after he had manoeuvred a shooting opportunity from the edge of United's penalty area. But United were struggling to get their game going and Kiev coach Valery Lobanovskyi's suggestion that United were "vulnerable" were given some credence early in the second half when the Uzbek forward Shatshikh eluded some debatable marking to drive a shot against the crossbar from the right of Van der Gouw's goal. From the game's best moment the Dutch goalkeeper, deputising for Fabien Barthez, then turned a dipping 20-yarder from Shatskikh against the inside of his left-hand post, gratefully scooping up the rebound. After that it always looked likely that the game would be settled by one goal - but with David Beckham well chaperoned, Ryan Giggs subdued and Roy Keane more often that not on defensive duty the ammunition for Cole and Yorke was meagre in its supply. The Belgian side Anderlecht, who were comprehensively beaten 5-1 by United at Old Trafford last week, grabbed a 1-0 win in the other Group G game thanks to a goal by Dheedene against the Dutchmen of PSV Eindhoven. Subs : Kernozenko, Guerassimenko, Yashkin, Bodnar, Serebrennikov. Manchester United (4-4-2): Van der Gouw; Irwin, G Neville, Johnsen, Silvestre, Irwin; Beckham, Butt, Keane, Giggs; Cole (Solskjaer77), Yorke (Sheringham 67). Subs: Bosnich, Wallwork, Stam, P Neville, Scholes. Referee: K Nielsen (Denmark).

webTitle: Heads accuse Blunkett of failing to deliver on school cash control

fields.headline: Heads accuse Blunkett of failing to deliver on school cash control
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Headteachers last night accused the education secretary, David Blunkett, of failing to deliver to them control over school budgets amid a lukewarm welcome to the government's plan to reform town hall funding.
fields.body:
Headteachers last night accused the education secretary, David Blunkett, of failing to deliver to them control over school budgets amid a lukewarm welcome to the government's plan to reform town hall funding.

A green paper on local government in England, published yesterday, "stopped short of what Mr Blunkett led headteachers to expect", said John Dunford, general secretary of the Secondary Heads Association.

Under the plan, Whitehall will identify separately the money it expects a council to hand to schools and the money it should keep back for local authority responsibilities. But a council would still have the power to move funding between the two categories or not spend it on schools at all. The green paper says ministers would be prepared to legislate to force councils to pass on the money to schools if insufficient progress were made. Education accounts for 40% of council spending.

David Hart, general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers, said: "It is all very well placing a moral obligation on local authorities to pass on the funding to which schools are entitled under this new approach.

"History, however, tells us that nothing short of a legal requirement on every local authority to give schools their money will do the trick."

The amount of money for education councils to pass on to schools under the current system varies from 79.8% in Cornwall, where the authority funds an extensive school transport system, to 89.8% in Southend.

Mr Blunkett is to insist that all councils delegate 90% of funding, putting about another £1bn into the schools.

The education secretary told the NAHT annual conference in June that he wanted separate school and local education authority budgets.

But he was opposed by a coalition of deputy prime minister John Prescott, the Treasury, and Jack Straw, the home secretary.

Theresa May, shadow education secretary, said: "David Blunkett promised that schools have control of their budget. This shows you can't trust what he says - he is all mouth and no delivery."

Lady Blackstone, the education minister, said: "We need to ensure that [funds] go through to schools. We really want to see an end to the arguments about LEAs failing to pass on funding." But she added: "David Blunkett has always made it clear that it is not possible to fund 24,000 schools from Whitehall."

A simplified funding formula will make it easier for schools to work out how much money they should be receiving. Funding will be calculated on a flat rate per pupil plus top-ups measured by the extent of deprivation, or by the difficulty in recruiting and retaining teachers.

Funding will be "levelled up" for hard hit authorities, ministers promise. The role of councils in education will be clearly prescribed to include school transport, ensuring every pupil has a school place, and support for help for special needs, youth service and under-fives education.

Other proposals in the green paper would make it easier for successful councils to borrow money for large capital projects.

webTitle: EMI/Warner merger: will it crash to earth?

fields.headline: EMI/Warner merger: will it crash to earth?
fields.standfirst: The stars do not bode well for the proposed deal, warns Maggie Hyde, the Media Medium.
fields.trailText: The media and entertainment industries are in the melting pot for the next two years, so the stars do not bode well for the deal. By Maggie Hyde.
fields.body:
EMI now awaits a decision from the European Commission after offering concessions on its proposed merger with Warner, but will the deal stick?

The media and entertainment industries are in the melting pot over the next two years as Jupiter and Saturn oppose deconstructive Pluto in the signs most associated with media and publishing: Gemini and Sagittarius. EMI's horoscope (March 29 1928) takes the full impact of these changes across its fiery, Sagittarian Ascendant.

EMI is a pioneering Aries with its Sun next to giant Jupiter and hi-tech Uranus. It is gifted at finding and creating new talent, but its defining quality comes from a trine of planets in water signs. Magical Mercury and musical Venus sit together in Pisces, aspecting a popular Cancer Moon next to collective Pluto, suggesting tribal and popular culture expressed through music.

Artists who connect with these water planets are EMI's big success stories. Robbie Williams (February 13 1974), for example, has cheeky chappie Mercury at 11 degrees of Pisces, joined to EMI's own Mercury at the same degree. Aquarian Williams also picks up on EMI's Mars-Neptune opposition, with its images of groups and bands, drugs, sex and rock 'n' roll.

Neptune may be fine for music and film but in the business world it often sows the seeds of confusion, and with EMI's Ascendant opposing this illusory planet now, the current merger is beginning to resemble a beached whale.

The advantages of the deal have never been obvious to most EMI shareholders, and the horoscope for its announcement (10am GMT, January 24 2000, London) has always seemed dodgy. The astrology is just as confused as the merger, but even if the EC lets it through, it still looks as if the matter won't be settled until late June and July next year. Before then, moves from EMI shareholders could sink the whole deal.

Email the Media Medium at: maggie@companyguide.co.uk

fields.headline: Dear President Wolfensohn
fields.standfirst: Hundreds of people have signed a joint letter to World Bank President James Wolfensohn expressing concerns about a new $60 million Bank internet initiative
fields.trailText: Signatories of the letter fear the Global Development Gateway plans will divert traffic from existing websites, while failing to consult with other organisations. The Bank will be seeking to generate support for its plans at the Prague meetings this week.
fields.body:
Signatories of the letter fear the Global Development Gateway plans will divert traffic from existing websites, while failing to consult with other organisations. The Bank will be seeking to generate support for its plans at the Prague meetings this week.

The Bank aims to create "the premier web entry point for information about poverty and sustainable development", at a cost of $60 million over 3 years. The Bank's plans include a global portal containing selected material on a wide range of topics aimed at donors, NGOs, researchers and interested readers. This would be complemented by Gateways specific to countries.

Hundreds of NGOs, leading academics and also representatives of private companies have expressed doubts about the World Bank's internet plans. Signatories include: Anriette Esterhuysen, Executive Director, Association for Progressive Communications (a leading internet service provider for community based organisations worldwide); Roberto Bissio, Director, Third World Institute, Uruguay; Frances Stewart, Director, International Development Centre, University of Oxford; Cândido Grzybowski, General Director, IBASE - Brazilian Institute for Social and Economic Analyses, Brazil; Alan G. Alegre, Executive Director, Foundation for Media Alternatives, Philippines;T. Peter Burgess, President and CEO , AfriFund Management Limited; Lawrence Haidome, TechAid-Nigeria; Dr. Ank Linden van Ruiten PhD, Information & Communication Policy Advisor, Royal Netherlands Embassy , Zambia; Dr.Magdi Ibrahim, Coordinator, ENDA Maghreb, and; Hans Klein, Chair, Computer Professionals for Social Responsibility.

Alex Wilks of the UK-based Bretton Woods Project, a World Bank/IMF watchdog group, said: "The letter shows very broad concern about the World Bank's new global internet plans. The Bank should recognise that it is overambitious and will divert resources and attention from more realistic and grounded net initiatives. Whilst claiming to be joining with others to build on their work, the Bank team's failure to listen has antagonised many people."

webTitle: Extra training,  Extra air miles, and EXTRAGOAL!

fields.headline: Extra training,  Extra air miles, and EXTRAGOAL!
fields.trailText: D'OH TO AUTUMN
fields.body:
D'OH TO AUTUMN

As the Fiver trundled into work this morning, splashing gaily through the puddles with a bluebird merrily barking on our shoulder, a thought struck us. How, on this splendidly wintry September day, could anyone be anything less than radiantly happy? Then we remembered that fashionable West London boutique Chelsea's of Chelsea had reopened for business under new management.

Claudio Ranieri - he's a breath of fresh air - took charge at Stamford Bridge today. Realising that the key to successful management is to put a few backs up, Claudio immediately announced that he would be ending the squad rotation system and doubling the amount of daily training. Dennis Wise was obviously excited by the news. "We're having a double session in the morning and afternoon. It's the first time we've ever had that," the Chelsea skipper raved. "Pre-season we've had it, but I'm not sure during the season. It's something different."

Even better news was in the offing for sex criminal Graham Rix and Ray 'Butch' Wilkins. The pair are unlikely to be kept on by Ranieri and were told as much this morning. "It's logical that they [Rix and Wilkins) have been doing a certain type of work and won't be able to continue doing exactly the same jobs they have been doing," Ranieri said matter-of-factly. It's not all bad for Wilkins though. He's been guaranteed a position at the club for a few months yet - as Ranieri's translator. Oh happy day!

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

ADVERTISEMENT

Free minidish and digibox from Sky. You pay for installation. Plus you can choose to subscribe to Sky digital - the home of sport.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

SCOT A LOT THEY'VE GOT

Say what you like about Scottish football, but it's certainly unpredictable. Just a little joke there, of course it isn't. However today, the Old Firm have done their best to shake things up a bit by speeding up their plans to get the hell out of Scottish football altogether.

Celtic and Rangers, along with PSV Eindhoven and their too-big-for-their-boots ilk, will confront Uefa with their proposals for a breakaway Atlantic League at a meeting in two week's time, and if the proposal is accepted Anderlecht away could be a regular fixture as early as 2002.

"There is a Uefa committee meeting in Malta on October 4 and 5 and we hope to present our case to the representatives there," Celtic's not-quite-left-yet chief executive Allan McDonald said today. "If we get Uefa's blessing, the new league could be in place by July 2002," he went on. "That's what we're working towards. Change is imperative - the future is bleak for us without it."

Oh yes. The silverware cleaning costs alone would be crippling. But the Old Firm should spare a thought for their Edinburgh rivals. All set to miss out on the last train to lucre, Hearts and Hibs are now the subject of a crackpot merger plan, dreamt up by none other than Graeme Souness.

"If they got together Hearts and Hibs could then take on the big boys," Souness opined today. "Both Hearts and Hibs should sell their stadiums and play at Murrayfield. I'd manage an Edinburgh United," said the manager of a mid-table First Division side with 11 points from their first seven games.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

BIG CUP FIRST GROUP STAGE, GROUP H, MATCHDAY 2, QUOTES OF THE DAY

"Football is all about players and they were marvellous."
David O'Leary rediscovers his rhetorical touch after Leeds' victory over AC Milan.

"One team concentrated on playing football and the other on ballroom dancing."
Angel Fernandez, vice president of Barcelona, after his side was spanked by lowly Besiktas.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

IT'S TANNED AND BROWN, IT'S UPSIDE DOWN, IT'S THE OFFICIAL OLYMPIC UPDATE!

Yippedee! That's the noise coming from Brazilian face holes today after the Golden Gang secured a place in Great Eight with a Japan-easy 1-0 win over, well, Japan. The vital snotch came from captain Alex, who used his neck muscles to thrust his head forward and connect with the ball in the fifth minute, propelling said sphere away from the forehead and towards the back of the net, where it duly arrived seconds later (a 'header').

Good news for the Kids from Carnival meant bad times for the Talent from the Townships as knockout leapt on South Africa's back after a 2-1 reversal at the feet, legs, torso, head, but not arms, of Slovakia. Juraj Czinge and Jan Slahor made the Slovak salad, and Benni McCarthy's late grab was the only wasp in the dressing. That means it's Japan and Brazil, not one of those two and South Africa that reach the GE.

Other contests saw a 2-0 happy day for Spain over Morocco and a traditional victory jig for Korea after a supershock 1-0 score over Chile. Spicy. The Special Ks were already out of the tourney and had only ten personnel units for 80 minutes, but a tactical strike from Lee Dong-Gook gave them the points. A special shout goes out to all the Gooks. Ringdinger!

Draw for the quarter finals:
September 23 - USA v Japan - Adelaide
September 23 - Brazil v Cameroon - Brisbane
September 23 - Italy v Spain - Sydney
September 23 - Chile v Nigeria - Melbourne

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Arsenal could be set to sign Japanese international Koji Nakata. A regular for the international side, Nakata is left-footed and plays a similar position to Emmanuel Petit. The Gunners have been watching Nakata's progress for the Olympic side in Sydney.

Former Arsenal striker Kaba Diawara could be set for a move to West Ham after Blackburn cancelled a year long-loan from Paris St Germain.

Real Madrid are reportedly considering a new £8m bid for Steve McManaman from an unnamed Premiership side.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Leicester will play their rescheduled Euro Vase first round, second leg tie against Red Star Belgrade in Vienna on September 28. The Foxes have been allocated 4,000 tickets for the match.

Coventry are footing a £3,700 bill after defender Paul Williams smashed the fourth official's electronic number board at Preston last night. Williams kicked the board in anger after being sent off during the Sky Blues' 3-1 Worthington Cup win at Deepdale. The Football League today issued Preston with a bill for the board but the First Division club passed it on to Coventry, who have agreed to pay it.

Sepp Blatter has said that the winners of World Cup qualifying in Oceania should go directly in to the tournament. Up until now, teams from Oceania (usually Australia and New Zealand) have had to playoff for a place.

Benfica have sacked former Real Madrid coach Jupp Heynckes.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: The Big Match - Live! (7pm) They don't come much bigger than Shakhtar Donetsk. Although Shakatak Donetsk were quite big in the eighties.

The Big Match (11.35pm) Notice this show is missing the affix Live! This is because Barry Venison is a member of the undead.

Football extra (3.15am) It's not late, it's matured.

ITV 2: The Big Match - Live! Monaco v Rangers (7pm) Four listings in, and still no mention of Ian Bishop.

Sky Sports 1: Futbol Mondial (7pm) Or Chris Kamara.

Soccer special (7.30pm) Or Matthew Lorenzo.

You're on Sky Sports! (10pm) Not to mention McCaff.

Sky Sports 3: The last word with Jimmy Hill (11pm) So who is there to have a pop at?

ONSport 1: Certainly not this lot, who kindly sent the Fiver a ream of listings this morning. "Despite the fact you only mentioned ONsport's exclusive coverage of the Uefa Champions League once last week," the nation's premier football broadcasters informed us, "We're going to try again." And you can't fault them for that.

Radio 5 Live: 5 Live football (7.30pm) All the football, without the hassle of watching it.

fields.headline: Hacker defaces HSBC websites
fields.trailText: HSBC bank faced an internet security scare today when a hacker defaced several of its website pages.
fields.body:
HSBC bank faced an internet security scare today when a hacker defaced several of its website pages.

The hacker broke into the bank's British home page and posted a picture of prime minister Tony Blair and a message in support of the recent fuel protests.

Sites in Spain and Greece were also affected.

The hacker, who identified himself as Herbless, has been behind a string of similar recent attacks on websites - including several local government agency sites and Legoland.co.uk.

A spokesman for HSBC described the breach as "an embarrassment", but added that the hacker did not have access to customers' records.

He said that the violated website was maintained by a third-party company that he refused to name.

"We are talking actively to that third party supplier about what has happened and how it has come about," he said.

Online banking services, where customers can make transactions and access their accounts, are maintained by HSBC internally.

"No transaction data has been affected. But it is an embarrassment and a nuisance and obviously we will try and take care that it does not happen again," he said.
