fields.headline: Brown soaks up the pressure
fields.standfirst:
 Eccleston affair: he denies lying
 Fuel: he is accused of provocation
 Pensions: he is told to act on party revolt
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The chancellor, Gordon Brown, was last night facing calls from the Conservative leadership to resign over allegations that he had lied about his knowledge of a donation to the Labour party from Formula One chief Bernie Ecclestone.
fields.body:
The chancellor, Gordon Brown, was last night facing calls from the Conservative leadership to resign over allegations that he had lied about his knowledge of a donation to the Labour party from Formula One chief Bernie Ecclestone.

During the height of the crisis almost three years ago, he said in a BBC interview he had not been told of the donation. But in a statement yesterday he was forced to admit that he had discussed the donation with Tony Blair three days before the interview.

On one of the roughest days in the political career of Labour's leading intellect, Mr Brown also faced accusations from petrol protesters that he was provoking civil disobedience by ruling out concessions on fuel duties.

A meeting of Labour's national executive committee also heard demands from all wings of the party that the chancellor must restore the link between pension and earnings if the government is to head off an equally explosive pensions revolt. The deputy prime minister John Prescott, promised to tell him of the strength of party feeling.

Mr Brown has called a special meeting of the party's economy commission tomorrow where it is expected to start drafting a crucial statement on pensions designed to prevent a damaging defeat at next week's party conference.

With Mr Brown's enemies at Westminster circling around him, the petrol protesters claimed that the chancellor's refusal to back down over duties indirectly led to yesterday's renewed panic buying of petrol across the country. The return of the queues, underlying the public's febrile mood, was triggered by false rumours on local Welsh radio that protesters were reinstating their blockade of refineries.

The government's travails over fuel duties have already prompted one of the most sudden and spectacular reversals in a political party's poll fortunes. Today the Conservatives, buoyed by their four-point lead in yesterday's Guardian/ICM poll, will try to deepen Labour's agony by promising to cut fuel taxes if returned to power.

Michael Portillo, the shadow chancellor, is expected to pledge the party to a cut of at least 5p a litre, and claim that the loss of £2.5bn in revenue will not result in any cut in spending on schools, hospitals and other services. Tory advertisements are expected to target Mr Brown's "intransigence" in refusing to cut fuel duties.

Yesterday, however, the chancellor was in the deepest immediate difficulty over his role in the Ecclestone affair. The allegations that Mr Brown and, to a lesser extent, the prime minister lied about their handling of the Formula One donations resurfaced when the Daily Mail published extracts from the book by Observer commentator Andrew Rawnsley.

Labour is also bracing itself for further allegations when the Mail serialises a book written by Geoffrey Robinson, the former paymaster general. Labour sources estimate that the Mail has recently paid out nearly £500,000 in serialisation rights for books damaging the government.

William Hague claimed the allegations that Mr Blair knowingly misled the public were the most serious made against a serving prime minister in living memory. Mr Portillo said Mr Brown had admitted he had lied on a matter of very important public policy. He should resign, or he should be sacked by the prime minister. "You cannot have a chancellor of the exchequer whose word is not his bond," he said.

During the BBC interview in 1997 Mr Brown was asked whether the party had received money from Mr Ecclestone.

He replied: "You'll have to wait and see, like I'll have to wait and see when the list [of donors giving more than £5,000] is published because I've not been told and I certainly don't know what the true position is."

At the time of Mr Brown's Today programme interview, the government had not con firmed the existence of the Ecclestone donation, let alone its size. Mr Brown's spokesman defended the answer, saying that he had not at the time known the full details of the donation.

"He knew the issue was a large corporate donation but he didn't know the full details," the spokesman said.

"Mr Brown had and has no responsibility in relation to Labour party donations and was never privy to the list of Labour donations prior to their publication. As Mr Brown also said during the interview it was completely inappropriate for him as chancellor to make announcements about donations to the Labour party."

Andrew Rawnsley's book claimed that the chancellor returned to the Treasury after the interview in a "red mist", having realised that he should not have made a false statement. The book said: "Brown raged at his staff: 'I lied. I lied. My credibility will be in shreds. I lied. If this gets out I will be destroyed'. "

Rawnsley is restricted by his publisher and the Mail from giving full interviews but the author's supporters last night said his version was accurate.

Alastair Campbell, the prime minister's spokesman, last night rejected the calls for Mr Brown's dismissal, saying he was "one of the most successful chancellors this country has ever had. There is no question of doing what Mr Portillo is asking for."

fields.headline: The right to fight
fields.standfirst: The acquittal of 28 Greenpeace protesters who destroyed an experimental maize crop has given the green movement a timely boost in the wake of the success of the oil blockades, writes environment editor Joanna Griffiths
fields.trailText: The acquittal of 28 Greenpeace protesters who destroyed an experimental maize crop has given the environmental movement a timely boost in the wake of the success of the oil blockades, writes environment editor Joanna Griffiths.
fields.body:
Today, when Lord Melchett and 27 Greenpeace protesters were cleared of causing criminal damage by wrecking an experimental crop of genetically modifed maize in Norfolk, it was a vital moment for green activists.

The ruling is timely - it comes in the aftermath of the abject failure of the green movement to react during the fuel crisis.

For the whole of last week, as protesters rallied and drivers complained of rising petrol prices (which have not risen since spring, but that did not stop anyone from spitting bile) environmentalists appeared cowed and silent.

This week, their own brand of protest was upheld by Norwich crown court.

While the people on the oil blockades claimed their protests were peaceful, they disrupted emergency services and schools and inconvenienced millions.

But they, and the vast majority of the public who supported their case, claimed that they had a democratic right to object to fuel taxes.

This democratic right they uphold is the right to expect no sacrifices for the future of the planet, merely to accelerate its descent into global warming and destructive freak weather conditions.

The Melchett verdict proves there is another sort of democratic right - the right to act destructively, if such actions prevent the greater destruction of the environment.

Norwich crown court decided that the rights of a farmer and the rights of a government are less significant than the rights of individuals to protest against the disruption of the balance of nature.

Whether the jury agreed with the actions of Lord Melchett and his followers is not known, but they supported the spirit in which the demonstration was carried out.

This is an extraordinary decision, which offers a substantial incentive for further field invasions and protests against experimental crop sites.

Under government plans, 25 fields are to be planted with trial crops of maize and oilseed rape, and 30 more with either sugar or fodder beet by the end of this year.

Herbicide resistant GM crops will be planted in one part of the sites and non-GM crops will be planted in the remaining acres. There will be more farm trials for the next two years, with results to be evaluated in 2003.

Two of the 31 farms selected for trials have already decided not to participate in the trials. After today's decision other farmers may think carefully about conducting GM tests on their land.

Some say the trials need to take place in order to guarantee the safety of the crops. But whether GM food can be proven 'safe' or not, few consumers want to buy it and, consequently, few supermarkets want to stock it.

The government can hardly expect the nation to support the testing of crops which can serve little function in the food production of the country. It seems that only bully tactics and duplicitousness will persuade people to consume GM.

The US government, supporting the interests of multinational GM-producing companies such as Monsanto, has threatened sanctions on European Union exports if EU supermarkets label GM foods as GM foods.

This only points up just how aware the US government is of public hostility towards genetically modified food. Only by naming GM products as "not GM" will people be tricked into buying it.

Whether the decision in Norwich today is a beginning of a new acknowledgment by the law of the rights of the land remains to be seen.

For years, the Deep Ecology movement, founded by the Norwegian philosopher Arne Naess, has argued that the continuation of the life of the earth is more important than the concerns of any individual species, even humanity.

The Norwich crown court ruling could lead the law towards reform which recognises this. Nature, having no means to petition barristers and governments, might be more frequently perceived as a passive and endangered entity, to be protected from the more rigorous attempts of humans to obliterate it.

While people continue to fight for their prerogative to queue at garages and force the last drops of fuel into overflowing tanks, no one can be too concerned about the damage we are wilfully, ignorantly inflicting upon the planet.

This ruling opens up a new world for environmentalists, in which to protesting on green issues does not mean being hurled into a subculture, hounded by the police and disdained by the courts.

Today's decision also offers a brief, welcome respite from the self-interested protesting about a commodity that causes global destruction.

fields.headline: Black kings are old hat
fields.standfirst:
Colour blind casting is already standard in theatre. It is cinema that needs to examine its racial mix
Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: The Guardian reports the RSC is claiming to have "broken the mould" by casting a talented black actor in the title role of Shakespeare's Henry VI. I find it hard to believe that anyone at the RSC regards this casting as mould-breaking in any way, given the company's track record in employing black and Asian actors. At a time when the National Theatre tended to cast black actors only in black roles, the RSC was asserting the principle of non-traditional casting and simply getting on with it.
fields.body:
The Guardian reports the RSC is claiming to have "broken the mould" by casting a talented black actor in the title role of Shakespeare's Henry VI. I find it hard to believe that anyone at the RSC regards this casting as mould-breaking in any way, given the company's track record in employing black and Asian actors. At a time when the National Theatre tended to cast black actors only in black roles, the RSC was asserting the principle of non-traditional casting and simply getting on with it.

From the 60s onwards, Alton Kumalo, Oscar James and Joe Marcell, among others, were regular members of the company. Jeffrey Kissoon, John Matshikiza, Josette Simon - all distinguished themselves in roles where race was never specified. When Trevor Nunn asked me to take over Hotspur from Tim Dalton in 1983 in the production of Henry IV which opened the Barbican theatre, he did so in the face of opposition from distinguished members of the company - my colleagues if not my friends. That casting decision was arguably mould-breaking; this one is not and should not be. The RSC has been here before and it really is no big deal.

What is more interesting to me is that editors appear to think their readers would find this newsworthy, believing perhaps that Outraged is still alive in Tunbridge Wells and will soon be penning furious missives at the affront to both history and to Shakespeare at the casting of a "veritable Negro" as a British monarch. But I wonder whether this may not be a misreading of the public mood, and certainly a misunderstanding of Shakespeare's history plays.

Is it not clear that he used history imaginatively to write about things other than history? Henry VI is not ultimately about Henry VI. (Henry VI is not actually the major role, but never mind.) It is about power, ambition, the grip of one generation on another: universal themes.

Do we really still need to argue that if Shakespeare really does have universal appeal, then that appeal goes beyond race and colour, and an actor should be permitted to interpret him regardless of race and colour. Casting in the classical repertoire has been much more receptive to the principle and the practice of non-traditional casting. I find it heartening that Peter Brook asked Adrian Lester to play Hamlet and not Othello, a role written for a white actor in black make-up.

Let us hope that directors on this side of the channel follow suit when casting roles such as Macbeth, Falstaff, Lear. There is an unanswerable case for non- traditional casting, not just in the area of so-called colour-blind casting: if Shakespeare and the classical repertoire are not to be made a massive irrelevance to the lives of a modern audience in this millennium, that audience must see itself reflected on stage. Well-spoken white actors shouting the lines of dead white males to a predominantly white audience must become a thing of the past. We must encourage young actors to speak Shakespeare not to recite him, to make his characters recognisable on stage, using a variety of accents. Then, perhaps Guy Ritchie might go to the RSC next time he is casting a film. But I fear we shall have to wait many more years before the cinema and television industries catch up with the classical theatre when it comes to non-traditional casting.

There the principle still seems to be that black actors play black roles, except of course in deep space, where the only condition is that you speak with an American accent and keep a straight face, (though exceptions are made for distinguished RSC actors). There are still conventions which govern the playing of Shakespeare, some of which are long past their use-by date.

My hope is that a new generation of actors - black, white, Asian, male and female - will question these conventions and create new ones which will, in turn, be questioned by a later generation. And I hope it is in this spirit that Michael Boyd has cast David Oyelowo, because of what he brings to the role, not because of how well he has learnt the conventions.

You can take issue with the RSC on a number of grounds - I have done in the past - but not, I think on its commitment to the principle of integrated casting. It might have been newsworthy if the RSC had appointed a black or Asian director or senior manager, but non-traditional casting is, has been and should be a given.

My worry is that after all the "Colour-blind casting shock!" headlines, David Oyelowo will be subject to the scrutiny of those self-styled arbiters of taste and standards in the classical theatre, some of whom are unable or too lazy to look beyond an actor's colour to his talent. It would be mould-breaking indeed if one of these critics wrote a review without reference to the actor's colour. But it is not only the classical theatre that has its outworn conventions.

fields.headline: Blair - bitch or boss? At issue: a government's right to govern
fields.standfirst:
Special report: New Labour in power
Latest ICM polls
Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: A breakfast show DJ on the London dance station, Kiss FM, summed up the current political mood with the question: "Is Blair our bitch or our boss?" He proceeded to give this answer : "I say he's our bitch, 'cos he's there to do what we tell him. And if he doesn't wanna be our bitch, then we gonna get rid of him".
fields.body:
A breakfast show DJ on the London dance station, Kiss FM, summed up the current political mood with the question: "Is Blair our bitch or our boss?" He proceeded to give this answer : "I say he's our bitch, 'cos he's there to do what we tell him. And if he doesn't wanna be our bitch, then we gonna get rid of him".

One may shudder at the phraseology, but the DJ was doing no more than articulating the current political zeitgeist: the politician as bitch. Mr Blair himself would surely resile from the language, but he could hardly quarrel with the DJ's sentiment. For the Kiss FM vision of modern-day politics is little different from that promoted by the prime minister's close adviser, the pollster Philip Gould.

Mr Gould is fond of quoting the political insights of Dick Morris, Bill Clinton's former political adviser. Mr Morris believes that politics has moved from representational (Madisonian) to direct (Jeffersonian) democracy. "Voters", he says, "want to run the show directly and are impatient with all forms of intermediaries between their opinions and public policy." In Mr Morris's view every day is election day in modern America. Ideology is dead and the fundamental choice facing leaders is their character projection. "The most basic decision a modern politician must make is whether to be aggressive or conciliatory."

One doesn't have to admire Mr Morris to see in these words an uncanny foretelling of recent events in this country. The truckers of Grangemouth and Stanlow wanted to run the show directly. Blair was their bitch, with (count them) 56 days in which to come to heel. And the government responded to these threats with an uncertain mixture of aggression and conciliation.

Is it now dawning on New Labour that this Gouldian mould of Method Politics is an arid and ultimately doomed business? Citizens are not merely consumers, nor can politics replicate a business model in which the consumer dictates to the producer. Something more - call it vision if "ideology" no longer chimes - is needed, and needed fast.

It has always been reluctant to make a frank and public case for progressive taxation, preferring to do things by stealth. The alternative is a deathly drift on the tides of tabloid and shock-jock- mediated public opinion. There is a crisis of politics, pointless to deny it. But maybe this is just what New Labour needed.

webTitle: The funding scandal that just won't go away

fields.headline: The funding scandal that just won't go away
fields.standfirst:
How a new book has reopened an old wound for the government
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The Bernie Ecclestone affair has come back to haunt Tony Blair and Gordon Brown nearly three years after Labours high command hoped it had heard the last of the controversy.
fields.body:
The Bernie Ecclestone affair has come back to haunt Tony Blair and Gordon Brown nearly three years after Labours high command hoped it had heard the last of the controversy.

The prime minister and his chancellor were forced on to the defensive yesterday over allegations that they lied in television and radio interviews about a £1m donation the party received, and another £1m it planned to pocket until it was advised not to by Lord (then Sir Patrick) Neill, chairman of the commission on standards in public life.

William Hague called for an inquiry and the shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, demanded Mr Browns resignation after the accusations in Observer columnist Andrew Rawnsleys book, Servants of the People, were splashed across four pages of the Daily Mail.

Mr Rawnsleys version based on an analysis of statements made during the November 1997 sleaze crisis that engulfed what was supposed to be a squeaky clean government, and backed up by a series of anonymous quotes has revived the furore at the moment when the fuel crisis has left the government at its weakest.

The Ecclestone affair erupted on November 9 1997, when the Sunday Telegraph revealed that the motor racing tycoon had switched his financial support from the Tories to Labour in what appeared an astonishing political u-turn.

The papers then political correspondent, Tom Baldwin, had contacted Downing Street three days earlier after a tip-off and had been stonewalled. But Mr Blairs press secretary, Alastair Campbell, and the partys then director of communications, David Hill, realised that, after making Tory sleaze a key election issue, Labours financial ties to Mr Ecclestone could backfire badly.

Mr Ecclestone gave Labour £1m only months before the election and was in talks over another £1m. Yet on October 16 he had been to Downing Street to meet Mr Blair and lobby him to exempt formula one racing from a tobacco advertising ban, arguing that as many as 200,000 jobs could be lost.

No proper minutes were kept and on November 4 it emerged in Brussels that the anti-smoking health minister, Tessa Jowell, was arguing for a formula one exemption. The fallout rocked the government for a week.

Yesterday the Labour machine tried to play down the latest controversy, saying it had already been covered in detail in the first edition of a Peter Mandelson biography by Donald Macintyre. Mr Macintrye quotes a Downing Street insider as saying that the government was lucky that Britain did not have US-style public prosecutors to investigate such incidents.

Mr Rawnsley alleges that Mr Blair slipped into mendacity in an interview with John Humphrys on BBC 1s On The Record on November 16, a week after the original Sunday Telegraph story.

Stung by leaks about the scale of the donations and Lord Neills advice that the money should be returned, Mr Blair attempted to draw a line under the affair.

Mr Rawnsley alleges that the letter sent to Lord Neill about the donation did not refer to the original £1m gift, but to a second one Mr Ecclestone planned to make.

In fact, the fourth paragraph of the letter from Labours then general secretary, Tom Sawyer, states: "The party accepted a personal substantial donation in January this year from Bernie Ecclestone for the general election campaign. The position which we have adopted thus far had been to refuse this further donation, but we wish to be advised whether this is a position we need to maintain".

Mr Rawnsley also alleges that Mr Blair in his On The Record interview pretended he had referred the issue of the donations to Lord Neill before the Sunday Telegraph contacted Downing Street about the donation. Mr Baldwin contacted No 10 about his story on November 6, and the government decided to refer the donation to Lord Neill the following day. The reference to Lord Neills committee was not made public by Downing Street until November 10, when Lord Neill said the government should not only reject future donations but return the previous one.

However, the transcript of the BBC1 interview is more ambiguous. Labour claims the transcript only suggests that Mr Blair had decided to reject further donations from Mr Ecclestone.

The prime minister stated in the interview: "When at the beginning of last week it was eventually decided, and the minister wrote to a European colleague saying we actually want a specific exemption for formula one, and this is in line with what many other countries do, at that point in time, and I want to emphasise this, I said, 'Of course we cannot accept any further donations from Mr Ecclestone'- before any journalist had been in touch."

The person who claimed the party had referred the issue to Lord Neill before Mr Baldwins inquiry was Peter Mandelson. He told ITVs Dimbleby programme on the same day as Mr Blairs interview that before any contact from the Sunday Telegraph, the prime minister had decided that the original donation should be returned and the further donation should not be accepted.

Mr Rawnsley also claimed that the chancellor lied about the donation in an interview with Radio 4s Today programme on November 10, the day after the initial story.

Misquoted

Mr Browns team last night said he was first told of Mr Ecclestones gift on Friday November 7 1997 when he was being driven back to Downing Street with Mr Blair after the Anglo-French summit at Canary Wharf. The chancellors aides claim he was misquoted in the Rawnsley version published by the Mail, which subtly changed the context of his reply.

A transcript of the Radio 4 Today interview on November 10 1997, shows that Mr Brown was asked about the donation at the end of an interview on the economy and Europe.

The interviewer, John Humphrys, said: Let me turn to another subject if I may briefly, your relations the governments relations with the formula one industry before the decision to change your minds about whether to ban tobacco advertising at formula one races. Did Bernie Ecclestone, the man behind formula one, did he make a financial contribution to the Labour party? The transcript shows, with two interruptions, that the crucial exchange went as follows:

Brown: Well, you will have to wait and see, like I will have to wait and see Humphrys: Why? Brown: when the list is published. Humphrys: Why should we wait? Brown: Because I have not been told and I certainly dont know what the true position is.

The version published yesterday in the Mail left out the "Because and changed true position to truth. The Brown camp claimed that the omission of "Because" changed the context of the rest of the reply, with the chancellor asserting that he had not been told whether the Ecclestone gift would be on the partys list of donations, rather than whether any cash had been received.

Others, however, believe that the Mail version did not significantly alter the thrust of Mr Browns version, which they insist was evasive.

The chancellors aides insist, however, that he did not know the scale of the controversial donation, claiming he had backed Mr Campbells plan to make the details public.

Mr Rawnsley also claimed that Mr Brown had returned to the Treasury in a red mist after the interview and quoted one witness as saying ÒGordon went mental and raged at his staff: "I lied. I lied. My credibility will be in shreds. I lied. If this gets out, I'll be destroyed", he was alleged to have said.

Charlie Whelan, the chancellors then press secretary, went on the Today programme yesterday to deny that, dismissing it with a word "beginning with a b and ending with s" - bollocks.

"He didn't return to the Treasury, we got on a train and went up to Birmingham for the CBI," Mr Whelan said. A Treasury statement issued on behalf of Mr Brown said: "The facts are, Mr Brown never met or discussed any aspect of finance with Mr Ecclestone, nor did Mr Brown ever see any papers or documents related to Mr Ecclestone's donation.

"Mr Brown was never privy to the list of Labour donations prior to their publication. When Mr Brown gave the [BBC] interview, the letter asking Lord Neill whether the donation should be accepted had been sent and the reply was yet awaited."

Mr Rawnsley, a respected reporter who achieved a scoop when he revealed in early 1998 that Mr Blair or one of his closest allies believed Mr Brown had "psychological flaws", said his book was "meticulously sourced" and based on detailed conversations with hundreds of people "up to the very apex" of government. Mr Blair is know to be have been interviewed for the book, among many others.

What they said

November 10 1997

Asked on BBC Radio 4's Today programme if Mr Ecclestone had given money to the party, chancellor Gordon Brown, in a reference to Labour's annually published list of major donors, said: You will have to wait and see like I will have to wait and see, when the list is published... I've not been told and I certainly don't know what the true position is"

Later the same day, Mr Ecclestone said in a statement: "I met Mr Blair in July 1996 and was very impressed with him and his plans for our country. In January 1997, I was asked by a colleague to make a contribution to New Labour, which I did. I have never sought any favour from New Labour or any member of the government, nor has any been given."

webTitle: Duchess's former aide overdoses before arrest

fields.headline: Duchess's former aide overdoses before arrest
fields.trailText: A former aide to the Duchess of York, arrested on suspicion of murdering her boyfriend, was tonight in hospital after taking an overdose.
fields.body:
A former aide to the Duchess of York, arrested on suspicion of murdering her boyfriend, was tonight in hospital after taking an overdose.

Scotland Yard launched a nationwide search for Jane Andrews following her disappearance after the body of her 40-year-old partner Thomas Cressman was found at the couple's home in London.

Ms Andrews, 33, who was once the Duchess of York's dresser, had disappeared from the house in Fulham, south west London, and the Metropolitan Police issued an all-ports alert to find her. She was found by officers today in a "distressed state".

It is believed she had taken an overdose of the painkiller Nurofen, but was still conscious when found and an ambulance did not have to be called to the scene.

She was taken by police to Derriford Hospital in Plymouth where she was undergoing medical tests. She was expected to remain in hospital for some time.

Uniformed Devon and Cornwall Police officers in a patrol car spotted Ms Andrews's white VW Polo at 6.45am today, in a lay-by on the eastbound carriageway, near the Island Shop exit of the A38, near Liskeard.

The officer spoke to her and she was arrested on suspicion of murder and taken to an undisclosed location.

Although she was in the "distressed state", it is believed she was conscious and an ambulance was not called.

Police are understood to have taken her to Derriford Hospital, Plymouth, for a medical examination.

The Metropolitan Police was told of the arrest early this morning and officers were deciding when to travel to the south west to speak to Ms Andrews.

Superintendent John Green, who is based at Liskeard, said: "Officers carried out diligent searches throughout the night and once again good work by all officers has resulted in an arrest."

Police were first alerted to Mr Cressman's death when a colleague of his visited the house, in Maltings Place, off Bagleys Lane, Fulham, on Monday afternoon.

A post mortem examination at Fulham mortuary showed he was stabbed to death.

Ms Andrews, now a sales assistant at the Theo Fennell jewellery shop in Fulham Road, worked for the Duchess of York for nine years until 1997, and accompanied the duke and duchess on foreign tours.

She and Mr Cressman had been together for two years and had recently returned from a holiday in Italy and France.

Detective chief inspector Jim Dickie said yesterday that officers were keeping an open mind as to the circumstances of Mr Cressman's death.

Ms Andrews had reverted to using her maiden name after divorcing her husband, Christopher Dunn-Butler, in 1996. She hit the headlines in 1995 after £250,000-worth of the Duchess's jewellery was stolen by a baggage handler, from a suitcase which she checked into an aircraft hold in New York.

The duchess yesterday expressed shock at the news of Mr Cressman's death.

webTitle: Lembit Opik MP: Party conference diary

fields.headline: 'Media history occurred this morning'
fields.standfirst: Lembit Opik, MP for Montgomeryshire
fields.trailText:
Media history occurred this morning when I made my appearance on the Big
Breakfast - a mixture of political roulette and light
entertainment. And it rained.
fields.body:
Media history occurred this morning when I made my appearance on the Big Breakfast - a mixture of political roulette and light entertainment. And it rained.

Later, I addressed a fringe meeting on voter apathy, which was good for a few obvious jokes and a worthy consensus that "things have to get better".

The strangest aspect of the day was a series of meetings ranging from a campaigning pressure group to one-to-one chats with various candidates. I suppose it's part of the job, but sometimes it's the "motivational" sessions which leave you feeling knackered and unmotivated yourself.

But things took their usual turn for the farcical at the Glee Club, a late-night venue where we got together and sang silly songs about the events of conference all night. Country and Western singers would have loved it.

fields.headline: The supermarket that delivers
fields.standfirst:
Sceptics should curb churlishness

Net news
fields.trailText: Retail doomsters preaching restraint over Tesco's flyaway share price were left wandering the aisles without an audience yesterday.
fields.body:
Retail doomsters preaching restraint over Tesco's flyaway share price were left wandering the aisles without an audience yesterday.

A further 8.5% was added to the company's value as chief executive Terry Leahy produced another trolley full of goodies: robust sales, strong profit growth, oh, and continuity of management. There were also signs that international expansion plans could soon begin to pay-off.

The sceptics on the Tesco story are worried about gathering storm clouds at home. How, they ask, can Tesco (and other retailers who have collectively enjoyed a 20% re-rating since February) be given premium market treatment against their European rivals when here in Britain there is a competition commission report cooking, pressure on domestic sales is growing and margins are supposedly under threat from the Wal-Mart-empowered Asda?

Analysts, such as those at Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, are also worried that international expansion involves heavy capital expenditure, diluting returns deep into the foreseeable future.

But Mr Leahy was bold enough yesterday to dismiss the so-called Wal-Mart effect. Also, he seems extremely confident that any government interference will amount to tinkering rather than fullblooded interference in shelf pricing. Since Mr Leahy has a reputation for delivering what he says (and he was announcing a 10% increase in UK operating profits as he spoke), there was no particular reason yesterday to question his word.

At the same time, the undeniably tight market at home is clearly the spur to an aggressive rollout of Tesco's new hypermarkets across eastern Europe and in the far east where, it seems, the company is having real success trampling weak local competition.

This business amounts to a national retailing champion. It has real international ambition, and while the vast bulk of its value may still lie in its core British operation, questioning the vision and competence of its management at this point is simply churlish.

Trading ring

The ring for the job of chief executive, London Stock Exchange, is quickly becoming crowded with hats.

So far declared, in a no-fingerprints sort of way and in chronological order, are: Per Larsson, chief executive of OM Gruppen (who has fashioned his application letter in the form of a takeover document); Phillip Thorpe, managing director of the financial services authority; Hugh Freedberg, chief executive at the Liffe futures market; and Edmond Warner, chief executive of Old Mutual Securities.

Now the name of Richard Kilsby crops up. Strangely, the man threw up a regular City trading career for a desk at the exchange itself some years ago, before rescuing his CV with a move to Instinet, Reuter's electronic stockbroking subsidiary which acts as the backbone to the Nasdaq market in the US.

Last year Kilsby moved on once again - to Tradepoint, London's alternative electronic exchange which launched six years ago using software imported from the Vancouver stock market, but which has always struggled to fulfil its "upstart" credentials in the City.

He became chief executive as part of a funding deal, which saw Reuters join a string of investment banks pumping money into Tradepoint to keep it alive as an effective insurance policy against the LSE falling over one day.

It proved a timely investment. While Tradepoint still handles fewer than 1% of trades in London, its listing on the Alternative Investment Market capitalises the company at just under £200m; the mighty LSE, meanwhile, is valued at less than £900m.

As Kilsby's proposer (a senior figure in the London market) pointed out yesterday: "One of those prices is wrong."

It is time IG Index, or one of the other financial spread betting firms, gave us some proper guidance on the matter.

Not right yet

fields.headline: Dot.com dominance
fields.standfirst:
100% growth is the boast

Special report: e-finance
Net news
fields.trailText: Tesco likes to do things in a big way. Britain's largest grocer, it has also grabbed the top spot in cyberspace. Yesterday it claimed 750,000 registered customers and the strongest penetration in the world through 90% coverage of the British market.
fields.body:
Tesco likes to do things in a big way. Britain's largest grocer, it has also grabbed the top spot in cyberspace. Yesterday it claimed 750,000 registered customers and the strongest penetration in the world through 90% coverage of the British market.

Orders taken by Tesco.com are running at 60,000 per week which brings in sales worth £5m every seven days. Like-for-like growth is up 100% in the first six months of this year with demand escalating strongly since the creation of the website in April.

In Britain 300 of the 759 Tesco stores offer dot.com deliveries, mainly food but increasingly other goods including books, CDs and mobile phones. Personal finance products are sold on the web, too.

Tesco also has an arrangement with Grattans for mail order sales and has agreed a joint venture with i-Village the women's internet site.

While rival food retailers such as Sainsbury have been struggling to find the right formula for online sales, analysts believe Tesco benefited from six years of home shopping experience. Sainsbury, under new chief executive Sir Peter Davis, is aiming to cover 60% of the country by next March through the relaunch of "Sainburystoyou".

Tesco based its dot.com operation on a store-by-store basis rather than dedicated distribution centres. These proved difficult for Sainsbury which is now using depots and local stores.

Tesco claims its success is based around a sophisticated computer model which ensures the supply chain works smoothly. David Reid, deputy chairman, says half the online turnover is from new customers; the rest from existing customers spending more. Next up is to follow up aggressive physical expansion worldwide with a rollout of its online services, starting in Dublin.

webTitle: Parents: Polly Highton on parenting the deaf

fields.headline: How life prepared me for Brookside
fields.standfirst: Actress Polly Highton tells  Bernadette Moore  how her role in Channel 4's soap came to mirror her own life when she had to play a mother with a deaf child
fields.trailText: Actress Polly Highton tells Bernadette Moore how her role in Channel 4's soap came to mirror her own life when she had to play a mother with a deaf child.
fields.body:
When Polly Highton read the script for her current role in the Channel 4 soap Brookside, she went to pieces. The actress knew that her character, Barbara Newton, was a foster mum - but she had no idea that one of the children was deaf.

For Polly's real-life son, Louis, is also deaf. "I thought I had ruined my audition because my nerves went once I realised the screen foster child, Andrew, was deaf. But the part felt so right for me," says Polly who, with her actor/musician husband Paul, has a daughter, Nina, nine, as well as eight-year-old Louis.

She believes her experience with Louis has enriched her understanding of the role. "I instinctively knew how to relate to Andrew - always maintain eye contact and never talk with my back to him," she says.

"I am aware that deaf children's emotional development is slower and they can have behavioural problems. That helped me understand what my expectations of Andrew should be around the house."

The storyline centres round allegations that Sinbad, one of the series' main characters, abused nine-year-old Andrew. We have now discovered that these rumours are false and that Kevin, Andrew's older brother, set Sinbad up because he felt he was getting too close to his little brother.

Polly says she completely understands the dynamics of the relationships. "It is very common for siblings of deaf children to be overprotective; my little girl Nina is just the same with Louis. When they are at parties or on trips out she assumes responsibility for him and has always got one eye on her brother."

As a mother of both a hearing and a deaf child, Polly knows just how Barbara feels towards both children. "When all the trouble started, Barbara felt guilty that she hadn't given Kevin enough attention and I totally appreciated what she was going through. I have felt the same about Nina and I have had to take very special measures to ensure that she does not feel left out," she admits.

Polly, who was born and raised in Liverpool, believes that Brookside has portrayed Andrew's deafness in the best possible way. "A lot of soaps hammer home a disability or an issue but Andrew's deafness is just part of him.

"I was delighted that Andrew has hearing aids but that they're never referred to. Not to make a big deal of his deafness is far more true to life," she says.

But Polly confesses that initially Louis's deafness, which is a lot worse than Andrew's, was a huge issue - one that dominated the family's life for several years.

When he was diagnosed at nine months old, Polly and Paul were devastated. "I still can't believe that we were told our baby boy was profoundly deaf and left to walk out of the hospital without any form of counselling or help. It was an horrendous time," she recalls.

And it is a credit to Polly that Louis, who goes to a partial-hearing unit attached to Gifford primary school in Northolt, is now a bright, happy child who loves talking.

For 18 months she drove to Portsmouth twice a week to a pre-school centre for deaf children and their parents, where they both learned to deal with the practical and emotional problems of deafness. Louis then went to a special summer camp in Los Angeles before starting at nursery. "Up until Louis was nearly four, deafness was the prevailing issue in our family. Then it just became a way of life and we are so proud of Louis and all he has achieved," says Polly.

webTitle: Something stirring in the enemy camp

fields.headline: Something stirring in the enemy camp
fields.standfirst: Home and away:  The diary of a part-time father
fields.trailText: Home and away: The diary of a part-time father
fields.body:
Two weeks have passed and I have had no reply to my bridge-building letter to Dilys, the one I composed with such strained civility and posted like a fugitive in the middle of the night; two weeks of doubt and fluster during which I've given birth (metaphorically) to millions of kittens, given vent (literally) to gallons of cold sweat and given rein (quietly hysterically) to my deepest secret fears about my future as the part-time father of growing-up Gloria (12), drawn-in Jed (9) and bubbling-over Billy (7).

I haven't got into this state over the actual content of any letter Dilys may be preparing in response. (Or may not: since she is the mother of all mother superiors, there seems every chance she will not stoop to responding to my generous overtures.) The likelihood is that any observations she might commit to paper will do nothing worse that get up my nose - an acceptable price for opening the conciliatory dialogue I promised Gloria that I would try to foster. No, what's really been gnawing at me as I've lain in daily wait for the postman to arrive is the thought of the parental capital that Dilys and her nincompoop partner Chris PBE (Pillock of the British Empire) could be making at my expense.

Will they have discussed my letter with the children? Will they have told them - utterly erroneously - that it is a tissue of lunacy, threats and lies? Will they have used it to support their favourite insinuation that the way things are done here in the grubby, grumpy, tough-lovey Stone household is "inappropriate" (their word), and similar bullshit (mine)?

Probably. Of course, that's the risk you take when opening communications with the Sultan and Sultana of Relentless Self-Regard. Even so, the impact on my equilibrium of this diplomatic foray has caught me unawares.

Hostility, I suppose, has become something to hang on to: a consoling conduit for my feelings of utter helpless in the face of D and C's assaults on my credibility in the eyes of G, J and B. The status quo may be imperfect, but at least it's reliable. Might jaw-jaw be still more painful than war-war?

Still, as Angie said one family-of-three evening as we watched Estelle give swimming lessons to her toy ducks in the bath: "They can't help it, you know." It was generous of my missus to see Chris and Dilys as driven by compulsions beyond their own control. Too generous, in truth. But I've decided I must take a similar view. Perceiving the gruesome twosome as fundamentally defective assists me in my efforts to rise above the fray.

"Just remember," Angie reminds me when froth collects too conspicuously at the corners of my mouth, "they are even more mad than you."

I have managed to remember. I have remembered every time the clatter of the letterbox has signalled only offers of generous APRs and home-delivery pizza menus. More importantly, I have remembered with each coming and going of Gloria, Jed and Billy between their "other home" and this. Though they have arrived in awkward tempers, I have sustained a game veneer of cheeriness ("Hello, hello, hello! Don't all kiss me at once!"). And though they've gone away in light and bouncy moods that I instinctively interpret as rebukes rather than evidence of the happiness that I have planted in their hearts, I have told myself that their joie de vivre is proof of my lesser insanity.

Grimly, too, I have resisted interrogating them too closely about the impact of my letter upon Dilys, this despite appalling provocation.

Gloria, apparently forgetting that I had written it primarily for her sake, made clear that the matter was no longer for discussion. She snapped: "It's inappropriate for you to make me feel stressed." As for Jed and Billy, they exchanged nervous glances and ducked behind the hedge of noncommitment.

"Dunno," they shrugged in unison, not meeting my eyes.

This stonewalling was vexing for a fellow in my tumultuous spiritual condition, especially because of what it clearly signified. I know my children, and I know when they've been nobbled by their mother. Gloria's prim speech was so obviously rehearsed, so obviously taken from her mother's massive repertoire of self-righteous indignation. And when the effervescent Billy not only keeps his counsel, but also looks edgily for confirmation to his impenetrable older brother, it's clear to me that something is stirring in the enemy camp. But what?

fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst: The Question: Should we have a code of conduct on junk food advertising aimed at kids, as the government is currently considering?
fields.trailText: The Question: Should we have a code of conduct on junk food advertising aimed at kids, as the government is currently considering?
fields.body:
Joanna Blythman
Author of The Food Our Children Eat and mother of two

I don't believe guidelines will achieve enough - children's junk food ads should be banned altogether on TV. The ads here encourage them to buy burgers, sweet cereals and sugary drinks without any health warning so they consume more junk. It is hard for parents not to give in. Much advertising gives the illusion of health - such as listing vitamins in breakfast cereals - but omits the fact that they're 49% sugar. In-school, marketing should also be stopped. Children are so easy to manipulate. Give parents a break: cut out those adverts.
Verdict: No (to guidelines)

Jan Parker
Co-author of Raising Happy Children and mother of three

Our children are bombarded with advertising and many parents would welcome guidelines that offer sanctuary, including moving sweets away from checkouts and controlling advertising on TV and in "educational" materials given to schools. Effective guidelines should also include soft drinks and fruit juices, whose high sugar content is known to contribute to food refusal at mealtimes. But the occasional bag of chips or chocolate bar is going to do less harm than making food a battleground. Parents also increase the desirability of junk food by offering it as a treat.
Verdict: Yes

Mandy Wagstaff
Food writer and stylist and mother of two

There should be guidelines. Because I work with food, my children eat well at home but they are starting to ask for junk food. My eldest, who is five, is reaching the age where peer pressure is highly influential. It only takes one child to see the advert for a trend to start. I've noticed that when we're on holiday with other children and mine are allowed things they don't usually have, they get excited about having a treat. But they end up leaving most of it because these cheap products marketed at kids are often rather unpleasant.
Verdict: Yes

Gaynor Bussell
Professional dietitian and mother of two

The freedom to choose is essential. There are no bad foods, just bad diets. Junk food can be included in a healthy diet but only as a treat. Because my children are used to eating real food they don't like junk. It is the parent's responsibility not to give in to pestering but it's easier to blame something else. Of course advertising influences children but supply and demand comes into effect. I'd like to see good food being advertised in the same way. I don't think any food should be banned or advertising stopped, but sweets at checkouts put unnecessary pressure on parents.
Verdict: No

Liz Earle
Author and broadcaster and mother of two

Anything that protects the health of our children is a good idea. Ideally companies should be self-policing and show better awareness of the damage junk food can do. As a parent, I object to children's advertising interfering with how I bring up my children. They will always prefer the meal that comes with the free Pokemon, which will inevitably be the least healthy. Junk food as a treat is a myth - it's creating the wrong values at a formative age. It is a sad day when the government has to intervene, but if companies remain irresponsible, it is the only option.
Verdict: Yes

Caroline d'Auria
Full-time mother of two

I would definitely agree with strict guidelines. Parents should be more aware of the dangers of food additives too. I have been made aware of carcinogens in pre-prepared food through my husband being treated for cancer. I've become particularly aware of the sweetener aspartame, which I hear is banned in the US and is so much in children's food and drink. I now always buy the full sugar products. My 10-year-old son fell for the Sunny Delight ad at first but when I explained how much sugar and additive was in it, he didn't want it any more.
Verdict: Yes

fields.headline: American Mom
fields.trailText: Of all the US states, Virginia holds a special place in the imagination of Americans. Birthplace of presidents Thomas Jefferson and George Washington, Virginia is shorthand for stars-and-stripes patriotism, liberty, and intellectual freedom.
fields.body:
Of all the US states, Virginia holds a special place in the imagination of Americans. Birthplace of presidents Thomas Jefferson and George Washington, Virginia is shorthand for stars-and-stripes patriotism, liberty, and intellectual freedom.

At least, it used to be. Now the state is associated with something less auspicious - the Great American Spanking Debate. It's a discussion that has exercised parents far beyond Virginia's borders, and one that shows no sign of abating. "How the state can even suggest that spanking is okay and possibly of benefit to a child is impossible to comprehend," fumes Jordan Riak, executive director of Project NoSpank, based in California.

There are 8,000 children in foster care in Virginia, and in June the State Board of Social Services admitted there were not enough foster parents to care for them. Attempts to recruit more were proving difficult, and, it was revealed, spanking proved the sticking point.

It is against the law in Virginia (as in 21 other states) for foster parents to spank charges in their care. If they do, they risk prosecution. City officials admitted that when informed of the corporal punishment law, many prospective foster parents backed out. So social services voted to allow foster parents to use "non-abusive" corporal punishment (ie mild spanking).

fields.headline: The greatest loss of all
fields.standfirst: Amid all the reactions to Paula Yates's death, one question comes up again and again: how will it affect her children?  Sally Weale  on life after losing a parent so young
fields.trailText: Amid all the reactions to Paula Yates's death, one question comes up again and again: how will it affect her children? Sally Weale on life after losing a parent so young.
fields.body:
When my little boy is worried or upset, and I'm in bed with him comforting him, trying to make him feel better, he sometimes asks me when I'll die. He says he doesn't want me to die; he wants me always to look after him; if I have to die, he wants to die with me. At exactly the same time.

These conversations are among the most difficult we have. I am desperate to comfort him, but I don't want to lie. So I tell him that most people live until they are 70 or 80. I tell him that most of us live until our children have their own children. Look at grandma and granddad, and nanny and grandpa, I say. They're still alive. They help me to look after you, and I'm looking forward to helping you look after your children. That's what normally happens, I tell him.

And I remind him about all the wonderful people who love him and help look after him - his dad and his aunts and uncle, and his cousins. And we usually leave it at that. He drifts off to sleep and, lying next to him, I worry about what I've said and what I haven't said. I can't quite bring myself to say to him yet that there are other people who will look after him if I die. Yes, in a way it would be reassuring. But it also suggests that there is a chance that I might die when he is still a little child, and I don't want him to confront that. Not yet.

This week there have been a hundred different photographic images of Paula Yates. Young, sexy Penthouse model, glitzy rock chick, grieving widow and desperate, dishevelled woman on the brink. The ones that stick in the memory, are those of her with a little girl in her arms, resting on her hip. A mother cuddling a little girl in long woolly tights and red T-bar shoes; a little girl with a crazy name who lost her father before she had a chance to know him and who found her mummy in deep, deep sleep in bed, surrounded by the debris of drink and drugs, and couldn't wake her.

Perhaps Yates had the same conversation with her daughters on sleepless nights. "What happens if you die, mummy?" It's something every parent and every child consider at some point.

But for most us, even as we consider it, we comfort ourselves that the odds are that it won't happen. I'm not lying to my son. Most of us do live until we are 70 or 80 and have become grandparents ourselves. But what happens to the sons and daughters of those of us who do not? What happens to Fifi Trixibelle, Peaches and Pixie, who fortunately have their father? What happens to Heavenly Hiraani Tiger Lily, who finds herself an orphan?

Orphan. The very word sounds antique, Victorian. It doesn't belong to this era of medical miracles, healthier lifestyles and longer life expectancy. We hear it used in connection with the developing world, where parents die young and children grow up without them. But not here.

Diana Crossley is a clinical psychologist working with Winston's Wish, a charity set up to try to help bereaved children and their families. In the eight years since the charity was launched, she and her colleagues have seen more than 2,000 children who have lost parents. Of those, only a handful have lost both: it is still mercifully rare. "Your expectation is that your parents will survive until you are in your 40s or 50s before they die. So the impact of a parent dying when you are young is going to be huge. The full impact of both your parents dying by the time you are four is something you will have to deal with for the rest of your life. You question the world enough when one parent dies. To have both die, it's like - God, there really is nobody now."

And what of the way that you die? To lose a parent after an illness is one thing - there will at least be time to prepare a child for their parent's death. But to die in despair, crippled by drink or drugs is another. Or is it?

"For a young child it is not necessarily always the way somebody dies that's the issue, it's the fact that they've died," says Crossley. "When you are four it's the practicalities that matter. Where am I going to live? Is my routine going to carry on? Am I still going to have fishfingers for tea? It's those things that are important. It's not until they are five, six or seven that they start to respond in an emotional way and grieve.

Dr Dora Black, consultant child psychiatrist, runs a clinic for children who have been exposed to death under acutely traumatic circumstances. Her patients have included the son of Rachel Nickell, who witnessed his mother being violently murdered on Wimbledon Common. Statistically, she says, a child who loses a parent is four or five times at greater risk of developing some kind of psychiatric disorder as they grow older, particularly depression. "The most important factor is the adequacy of the substitute care arrangements that are made. Between the ages of three and four is probably the worst age at which something like this can happen. It's at the height of your attachment to that parent. But provided the child is well looked after by parent substitutes, and she has good-quality bereavement counselling, she has a good chance."

Crossley adds: "If nobody talks about it and it's brushed under the carpet, you are going to have problems later on. A lot of children are amazingly resilient. With the right support - and that's not years of therapy, but an openness, an honesty and a willingness to discuss what's happened - people can grow up and be the people they always would have been.

"You learn a lesson very early on that maybe you should not have had to learn until a lot later. Yes, you know life is not as safe as houses. But a lot of children we see become very compassionate, very caring to their peers who may experience something similar."

So, just because one of your parents dies when you're a child doesn't mean that you grow up irreparably damaged. But throughout your life there will be those milestones when it's all much, much harder. The first day of school and your mother's not there; sports day and your dad's not in the crowd to see you win; getting married and he's not there to give you away; having your first child and she's not there to help you. It's a life-long adjustment.

Every parent hopes his or her children will be spared, but there's no point in lying. When my son gets a bit older, and he can't sleep and he tells me that he's scared of me dying and being left on his own, I'll tell him again that most people live until they're 70 or 80. But occasionally - not very often - they don't. And if anything happens to me, isn't he lucky he's got a brilliant dad, and all those other fantastic people to care for him? He'll never be on his own.

fields.headline: The best of both worlds
fields.standfirst: Debbie Beckerman was adamant that her son and daughter should be brought up bilingual, just as she was. So far, she says, her strategy has worked wonders
fields.trailText: Debbie Beckerman was adamant that her son and daughter should be brought up bilingual, just as she was. So far, she says, her strategy has worked wonders.
fields.body:
"Which language do you prefer?" my six-year-old son asked his four-year-old sister yesterday in French. "I prefer French," he continued. "Me too," she boldly agreed. Overhearing this exchange made my heart burst with joy: they clearly felt as bicultural and as bilingual as I did. All the effort was paying off.

My French mother died some years ago, but I am in touch with her family, especially her sister. She and her husband have no children, so they are de facto surrogate grandparents to my children. Yet, as they speak no English, it would be inconceivable for any children of mine not to speak French if our frequent trips to see them were not to become hopelessly uncommunicative. I passionately wanted my children to have access to my French history and for me to maintain a bond with my mother. Our maternal language and culture is part of what defines us: I felt I owed it to my children to pass it on.

From the moment my son was born, I vowed to speak to him only in French. Having grown up in a bilingual family, I knew the importance of consistency and firmness from the start. Nowadays, it would never occur to me to speak to my children in anything other than French.

Only when their friends are round and I need everyone to understand do I switch to English, although I must admit it is particularly useful to be able to tell my children off in French: other people don't usually understand and my children do not lose face.

On a day-to-day basis, as my husband understands French, we have developed triangular conversations: my children and I speak to each other in French, they communicate with their father in English and he and I speak in English as well.

This system works so smoothly that we are not even conscious of it, although some outsiders find it bewildering to understand only half of our exchanges - a little like hearing one half of a telephone conversation.

However, now that school is encroaching on the children's lives, they are beginning to tell me things in English as well. Understandably, if you've been talking all day about Jigglypuff and Charmander, it's a pain to translate that into Roudoudou and Salamèche. I remember driving my mother to total distraction when I used to come home from school and answer her automatically in English, despite being spoken to in French.

I was not doing it maliciously. I was simply living and breathing English all day long. So when the children speak English to me, I ask them to repeat their English sentence in French. I try to turn the whole exercise into a game, help them to remember any words they are searching for, and endlessly heap praise on them.

This may sound distinctly cumbersome but children will take as normal any pattern which is established at home, so mine are well used to having to do a bit of simultaneous translation over tea. I draw the line, however, at doing maths homework in French, unless my son tips subconsciously into that language whilst doing his sums.

Speaking is one thing, but a country's language is indivisible from its culture. To successfully pass on the former implies passing on the latter on as well. So it was that I introduced my children to French nursery rhymes and children's books (to this day I have only ever read a handful of English books to them) as well as food and even - don't laugh - music. I am proud to say that the children now love singing along to 70s cool dude Jacques Dutronc, complete with his deeply sexist but ironic "J'aime les filles" (it's all in the lyrics, believe me).

As culture is also a way of life, we now go to France every school holiday, and last year we spent the four-month ski season in our alpine village, during which time the children went to the local école maternelle (infant school) and made many firm friends. That, as much as anything, cemented in their minds the notion that they were both French and English, as it had done for me when I had done similar stints in French schools as a child. Once a child feels proud to be part of a country, he or she will want to keep speaking its language.

I am regularly asked whether my children ever get muddled between the two languages. Although my children would say, particularly when they were younger, "sauce tomato" or "switch off the fire"(as in " éteindre le feu "), they have known ever since they were two that fire is English and feu is French. I confess that I too still come out with occasional Anglicisms in French and Gallicisms in English but I consider that a price worth paying for feeling at ease in two languages in all other respects.

Yes, they probably were slower to speak than their monolingual friends. Indeed, I remember a well-meaning health visitor who recommended that we see a speech therapist when my daughter spectacularly failed to mumble more than a few words in either language at her two-year health check. "Well," she sighed, "it's not normal not to know the word for cupboard and chair at this age."

I ignored her and, needless to say, Natasha now suffers from severe verbal diarrhoea. Others were less fortunate. I know of two cases where the parents of three-year-old children whose speech was not as developed as that of their peers were told by speech therapists to drop temporarily the second language, even though in both cases it was the maternal language. Sadly, by the time their English improved (which it probably would have done with time and speech therapy alone), the link with the mother's language had been broken and was never fully re-established.

As for the common fear that a child might one day reject one of the languages, either as a reaction against a parent or out of embarrassment, I can confirm that there were indeed periods (in adolescence, especially) when I did not speak much French. However, it was sufficiently part of my life that the hiatus was only ever temporary. Anyway, let's face it: a teenager has to react against something and if it isn't their parent's language, it will be something else.

Bringing up truly bilingual and bicultural children can be achieved, but it is not a task for the faint-hearted. It requires much effort and determination and, once begun, it is not easy to backtrack. There are downsides, naturally, some of which I have experienced myself, but these have been hugely outweighed by the enjoyment and enrichment that bilingualism brings.

I want my children to have all the same opportunities as I have had. I would also like in some way to repay my mother for all the years of hard work she put into me. As she used to say when I would moan about having to speak back to her yet again in French: "You don't realise it now but you'll be grateful to me later."

fields.headline: Gameplay.com chief bullish about Yahoo! venture
fields.standfirst: Gameplay.com strikes e-commerce deal with Yahoo!
fields.trailText: The chairman of Gameplay.com remains bullish about the company's e-commerce venture with internet portal Yahoo!Europe.
fields.body:
The chairman of online gaming company Gameplay.com is bullish about the company's e-commerce venture with internet portal Yahoo!Europe, despite Amazon.com's decision to drop a similar deal because it failed to attract enough customers.

Mark Strachan said Gameplay.com will sell computer games on the Yahoo! shopping site in the UK, France, Germany and Spain, and promised similar pan-European agreements in the future.

The announcement comes in a week when online bookseller Amazon.com ended its three-year partnership with Yahoo!, which directed web surfers to the online bookseller's site. Amazon.com is now setting up a venture with Yahoo!'s US rival AOL.

"I don't know why Amazon.com has decided to move away from Yahoo!, but I believe there is still significant growth to be had in e-commerce, and especially in selling computer games," added Strachan.

He said the deal proves Gameplay.com is now a pan-European business, following the acquisition earlier this week of Spanish rival the CentroMail Group for £7m.

Strachan was unwilling to go into detail about the length of the contract, or the revenue sharing arrangements, but revealed that Gameplay.com will run the games section of the Yahoo! shopping site and pay the portal a commission on sales.

Gameplay's AIM-listed shares rose 9p to 251.5p on the news.

fields.trailText: Gameplay.com, the online gaming company, has formed an e-commerce venture with internet portal Yahoo!Europe, despite Amazon.com's decision to drop a similar deal because it did not attract enough customers.
fields.body:
Gameplay.com, the online gaming company, has formed an e-commerce venture with internet portal Yahoo!Europe, despite Amazon.com's decision to drop a similar deal because it did not attract enough customers.

Gameplay will sell games on the Yahoo! shopping site in the UK, France, Germany and Spain, with the company promising similar pan-European agreements in the future. The AIM-listed company said at the beginning of the week that it had agreed to buy Spanish games retailer CentroMail Group for £7m.

The news comes after online bookseller Amazon.com ended its three-year partnership with Yahoo!, which directed web surfers to the online bookseller's site. Amazon is now setting up a new venture with US giant AOL.

Mark Bernstein, Gameplay's chief executive, said: "Yahoo!'s network of local sites will provide us with unrivalled opportunities to target the large and diverse game-playing communities across Europe with our latest, scalable e-commerce offerings."

Gameplay shares rose 9p to 251.5p in early trading.

fields.headline: Bottom tops BBC repeats
fields.trailText: September 20: A quarter of BBC2 autumn schedule is made up of repeats, reports Matt Wells.
fields.body:
It is the time of year when broadcasters traditionally roll out their expensive new schedules, but viewers of BBC2 could be forgiven a sense of deja vu this autumn.

For among a smattering of new programmes in the first week of October, more than a quarter of peak time shows are repeats. The BBC's own target for new programmes is 83% of annual output.

Seven months ago, the culture secretary, Chris Smith, warned the BBC about the number of reruns, but there is only one day in the week ending October 6 when BBC2 screens a whole evening of original shows. Even on the Friday, which should be one of the strongest evenings of the week, there are three repeats, totalling an hour and 30 minutes of the four hours 30 minutes of peak viewing between 6pm and the start of Newsnight at 10.30pm.

It is a sign of the broadcasting times that many of the re-runs are old comedies. Schedulers have slotted in two episodes of Rik Mayall's Bottom, a rerun of an episode of The Good Life, a reshowing of Harry Enfield's sketch show, another airing for Gimme, Gimme, Gimme and a repeat of a Red Dwarf episode.

BBC2 defended the schedule. "The increased number of repeats on BBC2 throughout the year is negligible compared to last year. The autumn schedule is beginning to kick in, with Attachments [a new drama from the creator of This Life], and our landmark series the History of Britain."

webTitle: Pseudo.com latest video streaming site to close

fields.headline: Video streaming website Pseudo.com folds
fields.trailText: September 20: Pseudo.com, the high-profile US video streaming website, has shut up shop, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Pseudo.com, the high-profile American video streaming website, has become the latest online broadcasting-related site to shut up shop.

The site, which was one of the first to produce live original content on the internet, closed its doors this week and laid off its 175 staff after a financial saviour failed to materialise. Potential suitors were said to be Richard Li's Pacific Century CyberWorks, which is setting up its own internet broadcasting venture, Network of the World (NOW.com), but clearly Mr Li didn't see a strong enough fit between Now and Pseudo to justify the $40m (£26.8m) investment to keep Pseudo afloat.

In its six years, Pseudo produced more than 8,000 shows. However, it was said to be burning through more than $2m (£1.3m) each month. As recently as May, Pseudo had raised $14m (£9.4m) from a consortium of investors that included the media arm of French luxury conglomerate LVMH, following the $18m (£12m) it had raised the year before.

Pseudo is the latest in a growing list of high-profile companies producing original-streaming video content to feel the pinch in recent months. Digital Entertainment Network shut down earlier this year after running out of money, while Pop.com, the DreamWorks SKG and Imagine Entertainment vehicle, decided it was pointless even making it to market.

webTitle: News International to close educational website Learnfree

fields.headline: News International's learnfree website to close
fields.trailText: September 20: Learnfree, the Times Educational Supplement website for parents, is to be wrapped up at the end of this month. Amy Vickers reports.
fields.body:
Learnfree, the Times Educational Supplement website for parents, is to be wrapped up at the end of this month with the loss of 12 editorial jobs and other commercial and marketing executives.

The website, the latest in a growing line of high profile News International websites that have been called into question, was only relaunched in March this year but founded itself operating in a very crowded marketplace. Notable education-oriented websites include Schoolmaster.net, which recently bought Schoolsforschools.com, the winner of Channel 4's E Millionaire Show, SchoolsNet and Guardian Media Group's Learn.co.uk.

Rumours started circulating at the end of August suggesting that Learnfree was facing closure unless a buyer could be found within the month. The speculation suggested that Learnfree executives spoke to Freeserve, AOL and Tesco.com over possible rescue packages, but no deal materialised. In all, it is believed that some £5m has been spent on Learnfree, of which £2m was spent on a marketing campaign which broke in April.

Staff at Learnfree, including the eight staff that only started in May, have been told that the site will close at the end of September. A source close to the company said the move underlines the speculation that Rupert Murdoch is getting cold feet about the internet, particularly after all the changes of strategy at News International's digital arm News Network.

The news of Learnfree's closure comes in the same week that Revolver.com, News International's recruitment site, has relaunched with plans to spend £3m on marketing over the next six months.

In July this year, the erstwhile new media division of News International was shaken up and 30 staff were made redundant, the majority of which were laid off from the ailing auction site FiredUp.com.

webTitle: BBC1 sitcom gets off to a flyer

fields.headline: BBC1 sitcom gets off to a flyer
fields.trailText: September 20: BBC1's new sitcom My Family attracts 8 million viewers for first episode.
fields.body:
British audiences gave the thumbs-up to the well-hyped attempt to bring US sitcom success to BBC1 last night.

My Family, created by one of the brains behind Seinfeld leading a five-strong team of British and American writers, yielded a chunky 8 million viewers for BBC1 at 8.30pm - one of the best sitcom starts in recent years with a 35% share of the audience.

The viewer-friendly combination of Robert Lindsay and Zoe Wanamaker was also blessed with a lead-in from EastEnders, albeit a lower one of just 10m viewers, and lost only 300,000 viewers through the half-hour episode.

On ITV, the undistinguished TV Nightmares suffered in comparison, with 6.3m viewers (28% share) at 8.30pm. But no one bets on a sitcom's future on the strength of one episode.

Better news for ITV primetime was Emmerdale, which put up a strong fight against BBC1's hour-long Olympic round-up, Day Down Under, at 7pm. Despite home medal successes, the soap pulled in 9.4m and a 46% share, nearly 5m more than BBC1 at 7pm. The Olympics rallied at 7.30pm, however, to battle neck and neck with The Bill until 8pm and peaking at 8.1m.

The last in the two-part special of Bafta-winning The Cops beat last night's pull of 1.7m by 100,000, with viewers possibly defecting to Channel 4's acclaimed documentary series, A Very British Murder, which attracted 2.3m viewers, a 10% share of the available audience.

In the mornings, The Big Breakfast's downward plunge continues apace, with the Channel 4 breakfast programme again struggling at 8am.

webTitle: Nolan appointed editor of In Style

fields.standfirst: You magazine editor in shock resignation
fields.trailText: Time Life has confirmed the appointment of Dee Nolan, former editor of Mail on Sunday's You magazine, as the new editor of celebrity-based style title In Style. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Time Life has confirmed the appointment of Dee Nolan, former editor of Mail on Sunday's You magazine, as the new editor of In Style.

The UK magazines industry has been avidly awaiting news about the launch of the celebrity-based style title, whose super-glossy, tips-based format has been a phenomenal success in the US.
