fields.headline: Yahoo! and Amazon part
fields.standfirst:
E-merchant loses most favoured bookseller status

Special report: e-finance
Net news
fields.trailText: Surfers using the internet's most popular portal, Yahoo!, will no longer be advised to buy books at Amazon.com after a parting of the ways between the two big-name hi-tech companies.
fields.body:
Surfers using the internet's most popular portal, Yahoo!, will no longer be advised to buy books at Amazon.com after a parting of the ways between the two big-name hi-tech companies.

Amazon walked away from its partnership with Yahoo! after the end of a three-year agreement on Monday.

Under the tie-up, anyone entering a query on Yahoo! was offered the chance to buy books on the subject at Amazon.

The end of the agreement was seen as a blow to California-based Yahoo! Analysts said several internet vendors had renegotiated agreements with web portals after deciding that the number of customers generated was disappointing.

Yahoo said the partnership had been ended "mutually". It moved swiftly to fill the gap, naming Barnesandnoble.com, as its "preferred bookseller" in the US. On other national sites such as Yahoo.co.uk, Amazon will still be recommended in the short term, although there was speculation that agreements elsewhere were likely to be re-examined.

Yahoo's president, Jeff Mallett, put a brave face on the news, stressing the potential of the deal with Barnesandnoble.com, even though it has only a third as many customers as Amazon. "This displays our continued commitment to offering convenient, quality resources and services to our millions of users," he said.

Barnesandnoble.com is a joint venture between Barnes & Noble, the US chain of "bricks and mortar" bookshops, and Mannesmann, the telecoms company owned by Vodafone. Barnesandnoble shares surged 30% on hopes the tie-up would raise the profile of the business.

Amazon said it intended to concentrate on an alternative agreement with America Online. A spokeswoman said: "This was more compelling to us for a variety of reasons."

Amazon is thought likely to have been impressed by AOL's merger with Time Warner, which could offer more opportunities for co-promotion.

The online bookseller has been making an effort to cut marketing costs recently, following concerns about its business model.

Amazon is often cited as an example of the trend for markets to generate sky-high valuations for dot.com companies with few assets and no record of profits.

In addition to being the number one bookseller on the net, Amazon is the leader in selling videos, compact discs and DVDs.

AOL's president, Bob Pittman, said: "Amazon.com is one of the best known online retailers in the world and I'm pleased to extend a relationship that has clearly been successful for both of us."

Amazon's top selling lists are seen as a bellwether for the popularity of books and music. Among its latest bestsellers are JK Rowling's novel Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire and the Barenaked Ladies' album Maroon.

webTitle: Boots will post your snaps on the web

fields.headline: Boots will post your snaps on the web
fields.standfirst:
Special report: e-finance
Net news
fields.trailText: Leading highstreet retailer Boots has teamed up with internet search engine Yahoo! to provide an internet photo service.
fields.body:
Leading highstreet retailer Boots has teamed up with internet search engine Yahoo! to provide an internet photo service.

The joint venture will mean that pictures can be transported quickly and easily and sent via e-mail all over the world.

Boots is following the lead of the Netscape technology entrepreneurs Jim Clark and Jim Barksdale, who are hoping to make a fortune from online photo processing companies.

Boots is investing £9.5m in the new service. It offers the traditional development and printing of film, and the option to upload pictures onto personal websites for free. Photos will be able to be copied to Yahoo UK and Ireland, so the images can also be sent around that network.

Links on the Yahoo site will make it easy for customers to access Boots photo services.

Francis Thomas, spokesperson for Boots, said: "Research shows that more and more people will use the technology and send photos online. It is therefore vitally important that Boots has first user advantage. New links with Yahoo gives us another strong link to the internet."

The service marks a further move by Boots to diversify away from its chemist origins. The company plans to open fitness centres next year and offer advice on health.

The company also hopes that this service will encourage people into their 14,000 stores, where they might be tempted to buy something else as well.

"It literally is clicks to bricks," Mr Thomas concluded.

fields.headline: The final analysis
fields.standfirst: Lawrence Booth rounds up the county season, team by team. How did your side do?
fields.trailText: Derbyshire
fields.body:
Derbyshire

Ch'ship Div 1 9th
NCL Div 2 9th
B&H Group stage
NatWest 4th round

How to put this politely? Even without the usual bouts of back-stabbing and bile, Derbyshire still managed to self-destruct: bottom of both leagues, just seven wins in all competitions, eight points deducted for a dodgy wicket, and a batting line-up that often made West Indies look like Australia. One collapse, against Surrey, from 68 for 0 to 97 all out (Saqlain Mushtaq 7-11) plumbed the darkest depths. The seam bowling (they don't do spin in Derby) fell short of its customary penetration, and no-one took more wickets than Kevin Dean's 38. It's hard to know where Derbyshire go from here (apart from the second division of the Championship), especially as Dominic Cork could miss a big chunk of next season on England duty.
Most memorable moment Cork's 200* against Durham, shortly before going in at No.9 for England in the fifth Test
Biggest disappointment Michael Di Venuto, whose total of 725 runs at 32.95 was a poor return for an overseas player

Durham

Ch'ship Div 1 8th
NCL Div 2 7th
B&H Q-Final
NatWest 4th round

After the big strides under little David Boon, Durham took two steps back this summer, losing 20 games in the two leagues - a figure matched only by Hampshire. The bowling wasn't a problem: Simon Brown took 50-plus wickets yet again, and Melvyn Betts, John Wood and Steve Harmison were always a handful on the moist strips at The Riverside. The batting, though, was dreadful. Only Western Australia's Simon Katich (1089 runs at 43.56) averaged more than 30, and five times Durham failed to reach 100 in the Championship. After that illusory triumph over Surrey in the opening match of the season, there was just one more first-class win. Grim stuff up North.
Most memorable moment Eighteen-year-old Nicky Peng's matchwinning 98 in that win over Surrey
Biggest disappointment Peng's subsequent failure to pass 23 in his remaining 13 Championship innings

Essex

Ch'ship Div 2 2nd
NCL Div 2 5th
B&H Group stage
NatWest 4th round

As for Essex, read Ronnie Irani. Ten scores of fifty or more in 28 knocks at 55.95, plus 42 wickets at 24.00 was one of the main reasons why Essex sneaked into Division One of the Championship. The other was Stuart Law who churned out the runs (1352 at 56.33) with the appetite of a man who desperately hungers for international recognition. Australia's loss has been Essex's gain. But if they're going to survive in the upper echelon, they'll need another wicket-taker (apart from Irani, only Ashley Cowan, with 47, claimed more than 34 victims), and another batsman to score heavily. Stephen Peters, who dazzled Warwickshire on the final day of the season with 77*, could be the man.
Most memorable moment Warwickshire's generous declaration in the same game which left Essex needing 201 from 56 overs to secure promotion. They did it with more than 17 overs to spare
Biggest disappointment Poor old Nasser, whose cobbled together just 41 runs in five innings

Glamorgan

Ch'ship Div 2 3rd
NCL Div 2 6th
B&H Final
NatWest Q-Final

Not quite the golden summer of 1997, but promotion, a Lord's final and the first triple-century in the county's 79-year Championship career will do nicely, boyo. At one point it looked like it would be even better: four wins in July, including successful run-chases of over 300 in consecutive matches, rocketed Glamorgan to the top of Division Two. In the end, though, they needed bonus points at the death against Middlesex to go up. Matthew Elliott was outstanding (four hundreds, 1042 runs, average 54.84) and at last they seem to have found a keeper who can bat: Adrian Shaw may not be a Colin Metson behind the stumps, but an average of 42.30 says he knows which end of a bat to hold. The bowling, again led by Steady Steve Watkin (48 wickets at 22.22) was good enough this year, but will need more firepower in 2001.
Most memorable moment Steve James's 309* out of 718 for 3 against Sussex at Colwyn Bay, and Matthew Maynard's 109 off 115 balls against Surrey in the B&H semis
Biggest disappointment The batting of two young hopefuls, Alun Evans and Wayne Law, who totalled 130 runs from 13 innings. And Robert Croft's outburst after being - deservedly - dropped by England.

Gloucestershire

Ch'ship Div 2 4th
NCL Div 1 Winners
B&H Winners
NatWest Winners

Get the sports psychologists down to Bristol and bottle whatever it is they drink. A team whose captain is nicknamed Boo Boo and whose biggest star is a piece of frozen poultry (the magic chicken attended all their games en route to Lord's) lifted all three one-day cups to go with the two they won last season. And they missed out on promotion to the first division of the Championship by only two points, despite winning one more game than third-placed Glamorgan. Aussie Ian Harvey's slower one became as almost as famous as Franklyn Stephenson's, and Mike Smith was unhittable with the new ball. The batting was vibrant when the maximum was 50 overs, but in the longer form no-one scored more than Matt Windows's 790. Jon Lewis (56 wickets at 22.94) was consistently incisive and Jack Russell more mischievously brilliant than ever.
Most memorable moment Leicestershire's failure to score 20 runs off five overs with five wickets left in the NatWest fourth round. Gloster really began to believe this was their year
Biggest disappointment The collective failure of the batsmen in the Championship. Only three passed 500 runs.

Hampshire

Ch'ship Div 1 7th
NCL Div 2 8th
B&H Q-Final
NatWest S-Final

A season that began with a bang ended with a whimper as Hampshire joined Derbyshire and Durham in the bottom three in both their leagues. No team in either division secured more than Hampshire's 48 bowling points but only two (Kent and Derbyshire) scored fewer than their 20 in the batting. It was just awful. Lawrence Prittipaul came in at the end and did well, and Will Kendall (979 runs at 39.16) improved as the season went on, but the rest were nowhere. When he wasn't losing his rag with journalists, Robin Smith was on his way to an average of less than 20 and there were just six first-class tons to speak of. Shane Warne (70 at 23.14) and Alan Mullally (49 at 16.97) took more than half the wickets and all but one of the 11 five-fors between them. Even if Warne does return, it's hard to see Hampshire escaping from the lower league next season.
Most memorable moment The arrival of Warne
Biggest disappointment Losing to Surrey by two runs at the beginning of June when a win might have kickstarted Hampshire's season

Kent

Ch'ship Div 1 6th
NCL Div 2 5th
B&H Group stage
NatWest 4th round

On the face of it a faceless season, but when you're missing two of your strike bowlers (Dean Headley and Dr Julian Thompson) for the entire time, and one of them (Martin McCague) for most of it, survival becomes the aim. Kent achieved that in both leagues with a little to spare. A few players shone, none more brightly than the Star of India, Rahul Dravid, who overcame a sticky start in damp Canterbury to average nigh on 50 and score almost twice as many runs as the next man - Robert Key with 558. Kent's total of 18 batting points was the lowest in the country. The bowling was held together by the under-rated Martin Saggers (57 wickets at 20.14), but Kent were ill-equipped to bowl out the best sides twice: their four wins all came against the three sides who came below them. Still, at least Paul Nixon was finally picked for England.
Most memorable moment Beating relegation rivals Hampshire by 15 runs at the end of August. A 24-point swing helped them finish 28 points clear by the end
Biggest disappointment The young guns: Ed Smith, Matthew Walker, Key and David Fulton, who between them scored 1971 runs at 23.19

Lancashire

Ch'ship Div 1 2nd
NCL Div 1 8th
B&H S-Final
NatWest S-Final

England thought 31 years were painful enough. For Lancashire the wait is more than double that - it's now 66 years since they last won the title outright. And they've become so obsessed that they even forgot how to win one-day games, although long-term injuries to Peter Martin and Ian Austin gave them an excuse. No Lord's final and, even more amazingly, relegation from the top flight of the National League, a competition that used to be theirs by right. Clearly second best to Surrey in the Championship, Lancashire lacked a few vital ingredients: a successful and popular overseas player (Sourav Ganguly's top score was 99, he kept running people out, and on one occasion he turned to salute the team balcony after reaching a one-day fifty, only to find it empty); a genuine strike bowler (Mike Smethurst picked up 43 wickets, Glen Chapple 44); and a free-scoring batsman (Neil Fairbrother's tally of 754 was the best).
Most memorable moment Andy Flintoff's 135* from 111 balls in the NatWest quarter-final thrashing of Surrey at The Oval, an innings described by Viv Richards as "awesome"
Biggest disappointment The increasingly obvious rift between Ganguly and the others. Can one man really be so aloof he has to be ostracised?

Leicestershire

Ch'ship Div 1 4th
NCL Div 1 4th
B&H Group stage
NatWest 4th round

Mid-table but not mediocre, solid but not spectacular. Leicestershire were 23 points behind Yorkshire in third, but another 20 ahead of Somerset in fifth. They knew it wasn't going to be their season when old foes Surrey racked up 505 at Oakham School and then skittled them for 143 and 184. Five draws followed in eight games and Leicestershire settled for safety. The problem was that Anil Kumble (45 wickets at 25.17) didn't come close to his annus mirabilis in 1995 when he picked up 105 scalps for Northants. The rest of the bowling was below par too: Phil DeFreitas took 33 wickets at a rate of one every 14 overs and generally looked more of a batsman, while no-one averaged less than 25. Rumours are that Lance Klusener might be gracing Grace Road next season. It looks a canny move, but they need wickets, not quick runs.
Most memorable moment Aftab Habib's 172* early on against Somerset. It showed he wasn't too traumatised by his England experience last summer
Biggest disappointment Darren Maddy, whose tally of 581 runs at 26.40 suggests he may have well have been traumatised by his England experience last winter

Middlesex

Ch'ship Div 2 8th
NCL Div 2 4th
B&H Group stage
NatWest Q-Final

Oh dear. Despite Herculean performances from four players, Middlesex continued on the downward slope they began two years ago. Justin Langer (1472 runs) and Mark Ramprakash (1088) averaged more than 60, while Phil Tunfell (65 wickets) and Angus Fraser (48) averaged under 24, but there was precious little else to get excited about. Richard Johnson took 50 wickets and Andrew Strauss is an opener for the future, but Middlesex usually looked like small fish in a big pond, especially when early-season downpours limited their B&H experience to 127 all out against Kent. It was also the end of an era: Mike Gatting, a pillar of the club for 25 years, was sacked as coach before the end of the season. His successor will have a tough job, though he could start by leaving Lord's, which seems to be doing to Middlesex what it used to do to England.
Most memorable moment Ramprakash's run of scores after being dropped by England: 101, 83, 40, 110*, 112, 84, 49. Mental glitches are temporary, class is permanent
Biggest disappointment The NatWest quarter-final defeat by Hampshire, when Middlesex were dismissed for 127 - again.

Northamptonshire

Ch'ship Div 2 Winners
NCL Div 1 3rd
B&H Group stage
NatWest Q-Final

Only Gloucestershire and Surrey had better summers. But Northants had been in real trouble. They began the National League with four straight defeats and by the first week in June were bottom of the Championship. Oxford Universities had beaten them as well. Then the Wantage Road worm turned. Out went Devon Malcolm and left-arm spinner Michael Davies, who had an attack of the yips, and in came left-arm seamer Paul Taylor, back from injury, and Jason Brown. Brown pitched into Taylor's footmarks, picked up 50 wickets in seven games, and, with the batting re-energised, Northants won five Championship games on the trot and nine of their last 12 one-day league games. Their one worry is that captain Matthew Hayden (1270 runs at 57.72) is likely to be on Ashes duty with Australia next summer.
Most memorable moment Reducing Sussex to 13 for 6 on the way to 65 all out in a crucial match at Eastbourne
Biggest disappointment Mal Loye, who failed to pass reach 100 in 18 innings and was eventually dropped. Another promising player bites the county dust.

Nottinghamshire

Ch'ship Div 2 7th
NCL Div 2 2nd
B&H Group stage
NatWest 3rd round

They used to look over their shoulders at the glory years of Richard Hadlee and Clive Rice in the early '80s. Now they look over their shoulders at Rice simmering in the pavilion. Because despite their promotion to Division One of the National League, this will go down as another season of underachievement at Notts. Just two wins in the Championship - it was a scandal that this kept them in contention for promotion until the final match of the summer - and no bowler with more than Andrew Harris's 44 wickets. The one big plus was Usman Afzaal, who cranked it up to score over 1000 runs at 44.26 and was rewarded with an England A spot. But they really need some young blood in a top order that contains Darren Bicknell (aged 33), John Morris (36) and Paul Johnson (35).
Most memorable moment The opening stand of 406* against Warwickshire by Bicknell (180*) and Guy Welton (200*)
Biggest disappointment Failure to make the most of the greentops regularly seen at Trent Bridge

Somerset

Ch'ship Div 1 5th
NCL Div 1 6th
B&H Group stage
NatWest 4th round

Not good enough to challenge for honours, but not bad enough to go down, Somerset, like Leicestershire and Kent, were the mid-table men. In fact, they suffered because of their integrity: Taunton is one of the few wickets in the country which don't. offer lavish help to the seamers. The result was, well, not many results as Somerset struggled to bowl sides out twice and had to live off batting points and draws, a tactic which might not be enough if the points system changes for next season. Andy Caddick collected 25 wickets in three matches, but of the regular bowlers Steffan Jones with 40 was the most successful. Peter Bowler held together the batting with four hundreds and an average of 57.36.
Most memorable moment Marcus Trescothick's international debut at The Oval against Zimbabwe. He made 79 and a West Country star was born
Biggest disappointment Humbled for 58 by Middlesex in the NatWest fourth round and throwing away the lead in the National League.

Surrey

Ch'ship Div 1 Winners
NCL Div 2 Winners
B&H S-Final
NatWest Q-Final

We always knew that it's bowlers who win matches, but Surrey reminded us that they can win trophies too. While no-one reached 1000 runs, four men took 47 wickets or more. And they did it as West Indies used to do it - hunting in pairs of pairs. Martin Bicknell (60 at 17.53) and Alex Tudor (47 at 22.78) made the early incisions, before Saqlain Mushtaq (66 at 15.39) and Ian Salisbury (52 at 18.92) went in for the kill with their mixture of offies, leggies, googlies and doosras. Beautiful, clinical and irresistible. Put your money on Surrey to make it three in a row in 2001, something no side has managed since Yorkshire in 1966-68.
Most memorable moment Ally Brown's 295* against Leicestershire at Oakham School, an innings that surgically took care of one potential rival
Biggest disappointment The decline and fall of Ben Hollioake (142 runs and 11 wickets). A change of county could be the solution.

Sussex

Ch'ship Div 2 9th
NCL Div 1 9th
B&H Q-Final
NatWest 4th round

As close to a one-man batting line-up as any on the circuit. Michael Bevan, with five Championship tons and more runs in the National League (706 at 117.67) than anyone else, held things together for a while with a little help from Chris Adams. But when he disappeared on international duty, Sussex fell apart, losing two games in a week to Northants and starting a slide that even Bevan was unable to halt when he returned. At least the bowling had two dimensions to it: James Kirtley (63 wickets at 24.74) and Jason Lewry (51 at 29.54), but that was it. So Sussex did a Derbyshire, finishing bottom of both their leagues, and regaining the wooden spoon they last held in 1997. At least things can't get any worse.
Most memorable moment Successive scores of 151*, 166, 174, 30 and 173* by Bevan
Biggest disappointment The reliance on you-know-who

Warwickshire

Ch'ship Div 2 6th
NCL Div 2 3rd
B&H Group stage
NatWest Final

You'd expect a side coached by Bob Woolmer to do better than sixth in Division Two - particularly when they averaged nearly three batting points (or at least 300 runs) per first innings. But things didn't work out in the final day melting-pot and promotion in the one-day league along with defeat in the NatWest Final had to do. Warwickshire fell short chiefly because their often absent new-ball pairing of Allan Donald and Ed Giddins took just 38 wickets between them. Ashley Giles was a revelation with ball (52 wickets at 23.07) and bat (444 runs at 40.36), and Dominic Ostler (1021 at 48.61) returned to form in his benefit year. But however many runs they scored, they rarely took enough wickets. The result was 11 draws in 16 games.
Most memorable moment Giles's figures of 8-90 at Northampton, which moved him instantly up the spin-bowling pecking-order
Biggest disappointment The disintegration of Giddins, from Man of the Match in the first Test against Zimbabwe at Lord's to not being offered a new contract at the end of the season

Worcestershire

Ch'ship Div 2 5th
NCL Div 1 7th
B&H Group stage
NatWest 3rd round

A season of two halves. By the middle of June Worcester were top of two divisions and could do no wrong. But like Sussex, they haemorrhaged badly after losing Glenn McGrath for a fortnight and went into terminal decline, failing to win any of their last nine National League matches and bowling like Sri Lanka might without Muralitharan in the Championship. They even had to replay their third-round NatWest match with Gloucestershire after one of their players was ruled ineligible. They lost. McGrath shouldered the burden of a weak attack like the champion he is, taking 76 wickets at 13.77, and without the support of Stuart Lampitt (50 at 21.00) and the runs of Vikram Solanki (1062 at 46.17), Worcestershire would have been in even deeper trouble.
Most memorable moment McGrath charging in for one last effort on the final day of the season and picking up 8-41 against Northants as Worcestershire tried in vain to secure a promotion place
Biggest disappointment Alamgir Sheriyar, who took 59 fewer wickets than in 1999 (27 to 86) and ended up being allowed to leave

Yorkshire

Ch'ship Div 1 3rd
NCL Div 1 2nd
B&H Q-Final
NatWest Q-Final

Every season Yorkshire convince themselves that this time, surely this time, we'll do it. So while most counties would be doing cartwheels after coming third and second in the two leagues, the Yorkies think they've failed again. In truth, they did pretty well. Their batting was increasingly reliant on the prolific Darren Lehmann (1477 runs at 67.13) and, when he was available, Michael Vaughan (697 at 49.78), while the seam bowling remains over-rated - often devastating at Headingley, not quite so efficient elsewhere. In fact no-one passed 50 wickets (Matthew Hoggard's haul of 46 was the biggest), and Yorkshire should take most heart from the performance of their offspinner James Middlebrook (27 wickets at 24.07). Overall, they are still in Surrey's shadow.
Most memorable moment The Headingley Test, when local lads Darren Gough, Vaughan and Craig White did the Western Terrace proud
Biggest disappointment The batting of Richard Blakey, who averaged just 17.46 despite being given numerous chances to build an innings at No.3 and ended up in the seconds.

Even without the usual bouts of back-stabbing and bile, Derbyshire still managed to self-destruct: bottom of both leagues, just seven wins in all competitions, eight points deducted for a dodgy wicket, and a batting line-up that often made West Indies look like Australia. One collapse, against Surrey, from 68 for 0 to 97 all out (Saqlain Mushtaq 7-11) plumbed the darkest depths. The seam bowling (they don't do spin in Derby) fell short of its customary penetration, and no-one took more wickets than Kevin Dean's 38. It's hard to know where Derbyshire go from here (apart from the second division of the Championship), especially as Dominic Cork could miss a big chunk of next season on England duty. Most memorable moment Cork's 200* against Durham, shortly before going in at No.9 for England in the fifth Test Biggest disappointment Michael Di Venuto, whose total of 725 runs at 32.95 was a poor return for an overseas player Durham Ch'ship Div 1 8th NCL Div 2 7th B&H Q-Final NatWest 4th round After the big strides under little David Boon, Durham took two steps back this summer, losing 20 games in the two leagues - a figure matched only by Hampshire. The bowling wasn't a problem: Simon Brown took 50-plus wickets yet again, and Melvyn Betts, John Wood and Steve Harmison were always a handful on the moist strips at The Riverside. The batting, though, was dreadful. Only Western Australia's Simon Katich (1089 runs at 43.56) averaged more than 30, and five times Durham failed to reach 100 in the Championship. After that illusory triumph over Surrey in the opening match of the season, there was just one more first-class win. Grim stuff up North. Most memorable moment Eighteen-year-old Nicky Peng's matchwinning 98 in that win over Surrey Biggest disappointment Peng's subsequent failure to pass 23 in his remaining 13 Championship innings Essex Ch'ship Div 2 2nd NCL Div 2 5th B&H Group stage NatWest 4th round As for Essex, read Ronnie Irani. Ten scores of fifty or more in 28 knocks at 55.95, plus 42 wickets at 24.00 was one of the main reasons why Essex sneaked into Division One of the Championship. The other was Stuart Law who churned out the runs (1352 at 56.33) with the appetite of a man who desperately hungers for international recognition. Australia's loss has been Essex's gain. But if they're going to survive in the upper echelon, they'll need another wicket-taker (apart from Irani, only Ashley Cowan, with 47, claimed more than 34 victims), and another batsman to score heavily. Stephen Peters, who dazzled Warwickshire on the final day of the season with 77*, could be the man. Most memorable moment Warwickshire's generous declaration in the same game which left Essex needing 201 from 56 overs to secure promotion. They did it with more than 17 overs to spare Biggest disappointment Poor old Nasser, whose cobbled together just 41 runs in five innings Glamorgan Ch'ship Div 2 3rd NCL Div 2 6th B&H Final NatWest Q-Final Not quite the golden summer of 1997, but promotion, a Lord's final and the first triple-century in the county's 79-year Championship career will do nicely, boyo. At one point it looked like it would be even better: four wins in July, including successful run-chases of over 300 in consecutive matches, rocketed Glamorgan to the top of Division Two. In the end, though, they needed bonus points at the death against Middlesex to go up. Matthew Elliott was outstanding (four hundreds, 1042 runs, average 54.84) and at last they seem to have found a keeper who can bat: Adrian Shaw may not be a Colin Metson behind the stumps, but an average of 42.30 says he knows which end of a bat to hold. The bowling, again led by Steady Steve Watkin (48 wickets at 22.22) was good enough this year, but will need more firepower in 2001. Most memorable moment Steve James's 309* out of 718 for 3 against Sussex at Colwyn Bay, and Matthew Maynard's 109 off 115 balls against Surrey in the B&H semis Biggest disappointment The batting of two young hopefuls, Alun Evans and Wayne Law, who totalled 130 runs from 13 innings. And Robert Croft's outburst after being - deservedly - dropped by England. Gloucestershire Ch'ship Div 2 4th NCL Div 1 Winners B&H Winners NatWest Winners Get the sports psychologists down to Bristol and bottle whatever it is they drink. A team whose captain is nicknamed Boo Boo and whose biggest star is a piece of frozen poultry (the magic chicken attended all their games en route to Lord's) lifted all three one-day cups to go with the two they won last season. And they missed out on promotion to the first division of the Championship by only two points, despite winning one more game than third-placed Glamorgan. Aussie Ian Harvey's slower one became as almost as famous as Franklyn Stephenson's, and Mike Smith was unhittable with the new ball. The batting was vibrant when the maximum was 50 overs, but in the longer form no-one scored more than Matt Windows's 790. Jon Lewis (56 wickets at 22.94) was consistently incisive and Jack Russell more mischievously brilliant than ever. Most memorable moment Leicestershire's failure to score 20 runs off five overs with five wickets left in the NatWest fourth round. Gloster really began to believe this was their year Biggest disappointment The collective failure of the batsmen in the Championship. Only three passed 500 runs. Hampshire Ch'ship Div 1 7th NCL Div 2 8th B&H Q-Final NatWest S-Final A season that began with a bang ended with a whimper as Hampshire joined Derbyshire and Durham in the bottom three in both their leagues. No team in either division secured more than Hampshire's 48 bowling points but only two (Kent and Derbyshire) scored fewer than their 20 in the batting. It was just awful. Lawrence Prittipaul came in at the end and did well, and Will Kendall (979 runs at 39.16) improved as the season went on, but the rest were nowhere. When he wasn't losing his rag with journalists, Robin Smith was on his way to an average of less than 20 and there were just six first-class tons to speak of. Shane Warne (70 at 23.14) and Alan Mullally (49 at 16.97) took more than half the wickets and all but one of the 11 five-fors between them. Even if Warne does return, it's hard to see Hampshire escaping from the lower league next season. Most memorable moment The arrival of Warne Biggest disappointment Losing to Surrey by two runs at the beginning of June when a win might have kickstarted Hampshire's season Kent Ch'ship Div 1 6th NCL Div 2 5th B&H Group stage NatWest 4th round On the face of it a faceless season, but when you're missing two of your strike bowlers (Dean Headley and Dr Julian Thompson) for the entire time, and one of them (Martin McCague) for most of it, survival becomes the aim. Kent achieved that in both leagues with a little to spare. The bowling was held together by the under-rated Martin Saggers (57 wickets at 20.14), but Kent were ill-equipped to bowl out the best sides twice: their four wins all came against the three sides who came below them. Still, at least Paul Nixon was finally picked for England. Most memorable moment Beating relegation rivals Hampshire by 15 runs at the end of August. fields.headline: Voices of dissent
fields.standfirst: Report says lack of speech aids is a 'national disgrace'
fields.trailText: Report says lack of speech aids is a 'national disgrace'
fields.body:
Ministers are being urged to set up a central fund to end the "national disgrace" of poor availability of electronic communication aids for people who cannot speak.

Disability charity Scope says in a report today that people who need such an aid, but cannot afford one, are being denied a basic human right to talk freely. The aids each cost at least £6,000.

Scope's report, Speak for Yourself, is based on questionnaires completed by 317 users of aids. Almost one in two had not received any state help to buy their device, even though they had been assessed as needing one.

One user, 37-year-old Alan Martin, from Merseyside, relied on limited sign language until he acquired an aid six years ago. It has, he says, changed his life and he is now working on his autobiography.

Sixteen-year-old Katie Caryer, from London, says her aid has enabled her to attend a mainstream school where she is preparing for GCSEs. She argues: "If you can't see properly, you get glasses; if you can't hear properly, you get a hearing aid; if you can't speak, you get nothing."

James Ford, the report's author and Scope campaigns officer, calls the situation a national disgrace. "This equipment can make the difference between taking part in life or being excluded from every aspect of mainstream society. The government has an urgent responsibility to set up a central fund that will ensure that anyone who has been assessed as needing a communication aid gets the right equipment and training to use it, without having to pay for it themselves."

 Speak for Yourself is available at £12.50 inc. to professionals and organisations (£3 to individuals) from Scope's information office on 020-7619 7340/7341

fields.headline: Risks pay off
fields.standfirst: Entrepreneurial ethos boosts the government's New Deal programme to create jobs.  Patrick McCurry  reports
fields.trailText: Entrepreneurial ethos boosts the government's New Deal programme to create jobs. Patrick McCurry reports
fields.body:
Getting the long-term unemployed back into jobs has been one of the hardest nuts for the government to crack. But according to those behind a scheme operating in unemployment black spots, allowing former civil servants to act like entrepreneurs is reaping benefits.

Working Links, a company set up by the Employment Service (ES), Manpower and Cap Gemini Ernst & Young, expects to have placed about 1,000 long-term jobseekers in work by the first week of October. "This far exceeds our target of 650 and represents a success rate twice that of the government's New Deal programme for long-term unemployed," says the chief executive, William Smith.

A former finance director at the New Deal for young people, Smith is just one of many former civil servants working for the company, which has a two-year contract with the Department for Education and Employment to place long-term jobless in nine of the 15 government-designated employment zones. These range from Tower Hamlets and Brent, in London, to south Wales, Middlesbrough and Glasgow.

The company works with individuals who have been unemployed for at least 12 or 18 months, depending on the zone, although in practice many individuals have been out of work for far longer periods. Smith argues that the success of the scheme is largely attributable to the greater flexibility and risk-taking ethos of the company, compared with the more bureaucratic and constrained ES, which runs much of the New Deal programme.

Because the company is paid by results, rather than how it gets those results, it has been free to develop an innovative approach. This includes involving jobseekers in strategies to get them work, motivational sessions with trainers and getting them a bank account early on in the process.

For the public sector to take such risks would be very difficult, Smith argues. "You can buy someone clothes and tools and get them a bank account and they can do a runner. That risk-taking would be very hard for a public sector organisation to justify, but we've found that on balance it works well."

As an example of how jobseekers are treated as individuals, he cites the example of the Brent scheme, where new referrals are treated conspicuously courteously, offered tea or coffee and asked to wait on the sofa to meet their personal adviser. "Many of these individuals are not used to being treated like that and it helps our advisers to build up a rapport with them quickly," says Smith.

The company's management team is made up of former ES staff as well as people from Manpower and Cap Gemini Ernst & Young. Five of the nine zone directors are ex-ES staff. "Six months ago these people were civil servants who wished they could be more innovative in areas like aftercare, but were constrained by the public sector," Smith says. While praising much of the ES's work in the new deal, he claims it is often bound by red tape, cumbersome contractor agreements and pressure to implement national strategies rigidly. He would like to see ministers shifting more resources to the new, flexible alternatives.

Dave Simmonds, director of the Centre for Social Inclusion think tank, agrees that civil servants can often be more productive outside the constraints of the public sector. "The ES is trying to modernise, but has had a reputation as a top-down organisation where it's hard for people on the ground to be flexible. Civil servants I've dealt with have often felt liberated by working in partnerships with the private or voluntary sector and like the added flexibility at local level."

The main tool of Working Links is the "personal job account"(PJA), which can total £1,200 over six months and can be used to buy training, tools, clothes or other services or items needed in getting work.

A 58-year-old Brent man, who wanted to work as a delivery driver, was given financial help to tax, MOT and insure his van. Working Links also opened a bank account for him. Another success story is a Middlesbrough plater, unemployed for 18 months, who is now working in London at Chelsea football ground after the company paid for his site safety certificate.

Under its contract, the company's main income - £2,500 for each jobseeker - is only paid when somebody has been in work for 13 weeks. This means there is an incentive to provide "aftercare" support to those individuals settling back into employment.

So strong is this incentive, in fact, that one Working Links adviser has even been to jobseekers' homes in the first weeks of a new job to ensure they get to work on time. "Many employment schemes have found that the first two weeks of work are the most difficult for jobseekers, which is why we're on hand to provide support," says Smith. "And, of course, it's in our financial interests."

fields.headline: Xeno phobia
fields.standfirst: Organ transplants from animals to humans create a life and death dilemma, argue  C Ray Greek and  Jean Swingle Greek
fields.trailText: Organ transplants from animals to humans create a life and death dilemma, argue C Ray Greek and Jean Swingle Greek
fields.byline: C Ray Greek and  Jean Swingle Greek
fields.body:
Agreatly troubling decision is arising in our foreseeable medical future. A matchstick of a child has heart disease. She is pale, her little body weakened from chronic illness and drug therapies. Her life hinges on the availability of a healthy donor organ. But there aren't any human donors. A pig heart transplant might save her life, but may harbour potentially deadly viruses that could spell the end of civilisation. What to do?

This quandary concerns xenotransplantation. From the Greek, xeno means foreign or strange. Today, we use the word to mean the transplantation of cells, tissues and organs from one species to another. The current situation society now faces focuses mainly on organs from pigs meant for humans and it has recently made headlines.

Understandably, neither patients nor their families can really make life or death decisions based on public good rather than emotional or personal wellbeing. This inability is one of the forces pushing the xeno- transplant issue on to health agencies' priority agendas the world over. If those whose lives depend on the need for transplants can't make unbiased decisions, public agencies must.

To mass produce pigs for their organs, pigs must be cloned. Last month's issues of the journals Science and Nature had reports on the first pigs to be cloned. However, the journals also reported new details about the risks of placing pig organs into humans. The editor of Nature made a compelling case for a moratorium on clinical trials of xenotransplants because of the risks, which are myriad. Although humans and other animals share many bacteria and viruses, the impact of these microorganisms is not necessarily the same in different species. A viral example, herpes B, won't kill monkeys but it will kill humans. Aids kills humans, but not chimpanzees.

Viruses are small and adaptable. While some viruses have little or no effect, others deplete systems and bring on disease. Some kill. They can lie dormant for years, like HIV, then suddenly become deadly. All viruses mutate, many times a year. They figure out how best to thrive, adapt and move on. Again, just as visible species adapt to Earth by natural selection and evolution, so too do the microorganisms living in our bodies.

Some of the early success from developing pigs as donors centred on eliminating viruses from the pig - so-called "pigs without virus".

But the question was never asked: which viruses? One of the thousands we already know about or one of the thousands of others we have not yet discovered or experienced? Presumably, pig organs could be screened for known viruses, as blood now is for HIV. However, as many have pointed out, you can't screen for disease agents that you don't know about. Pigs may contain viruses in their cells that have not yet been discovered and that do not affect them but may kill humans.

Ian Wilmut, the scientist who cloned Dolly the Sheep, recently announced plans to stop experiments that would have eventually led to producing pigs for organ transplants. He cited concerns that these pigs could harbour viruses that could be passed from the pigs to people.

Wilmut was quoted as saying: "I think the concern is mainly unknown viruses. That's the frightening thing. If you know what the disease is, you know how to look for it. It's possible there could be viruses we don't know about that could be released into the human population."

Recently, scientists found out that some viruses "turn on" other viruses. Interestingly, they found these "pro-viruses" in pigs.

Pigs also contain porcine endogenous retroviruses (Pervs) and these viruses can infect human cells. All pigs contain several copies of Pervs. Viruses related to PERV are associated with cancers of the blood. And how will these viruses that jump the species barrier mutate?

We already know that viruses have jumped the species barrier as a result of xenotransplants. Patients who underwent "splenic perfusions" in Russia tested positive for Perv DNA. In the US, a man who received a baboon liver in an experimental transplant became infected with baboon-specific CMV virus.

All viruses mutate. Will the pig viruses mutate so they can be spread like the common cold yet have the symptoms and mortality of Ebola, Aids or the Marburg virus? This is not science fiction or a Stephen King novel. This is very real and very possible.

We cannot screen for viruses we don't know exist, we can't eliminate the proviruses, we can't guarantee pig organs without Pervs and we can't rely on the physicians, scientists and vested interest groups to act responsibly. So what is driving this insanity?

According to the investment firm, Salomon Brothers, the xenotransplant market could exceed $6bn per year. Others consider that to be a conservative estimate. Nature magazine recently stated: "The momentum towards clinical trials of xenotransplantation is seemingly unstoppable, powered as it is by multi- million dollar investment by bio- technology companies."

The vested interest groups who hype xenotransplantation portray it as making life-saving organs available to people. They shrug off the threat to the human population from species-jumping infectious agents that could trigger worldwide epidemics. And they have influence over government agencies.

Dr Jonathan Allan, a virologist at the Southwest Foundation for Biomedical Research, Texas, was quoted in a Nature Medicine article as saying: "I'm not optimistic that they (public health service agencies) will do the right thing and put public health first."

As long ago as January 1998 Dr Fritz Bach, a leading xenotransplant scientist from Harvard medical school, Boston, asked: "Is the risk to the public - which we can't quantify but we know is greater than zero - justified by the help we are going to give individuals?"

Bach and Dr Harvey Fineberg, Harvard University provost and former dean of Harvard's public health department, led a nine- member group calling for a temporary halt to animal-to-human transplants before the pressures to do such experiments become "well-nigh irresistible".

Fortunately, we have promising alternatives to such transplants. They include stem cells, organ donation card education programmes, opt-out programmes, organ donor coordinators at hospitals, expanding the organ donor bases by allowing the donations of organs from older individuals, the use of artificial organs, and well-proven preventive approaches such as not smoking or drinking alcohol, exercising regularly and eating a proper diet.The preventable deaths of children and adults due to a lack of organs are tragic. But it only takes one transplant to start an epidemic, and the risk to society as a whole cannot be over- estimated. The only way to prevent an infectious agent being passed into a human from a xenotransplant is not to perform the operation. There is simply too much risk to do otherwise.

 Ray Greek is president of Americans For Medical Advancement and Europeans For Medical Advancement (tel 020-7722 8934; website: www.curedisease.com.

He is co-author, with Jean Swingle Greek,of Sacred Cows and Golden Geese: The Human Cost of Experiments on AnimalsEuropeans For Medical Advancement

fields.headline: Spying on the psychiatrists
fields.standfirst: Insider who has challenged the treatment of mental illness
fields.trailText: Insider who has challenged the treatment of mental illness
fields.body:
Tell Rufus May that "doctor knows best" and he would have a few words to say about it. When he was just 18, a psychiatrist diagnosed him with paranoid schizophrenia and told him he would have to take medication for the rest of his life.

May, who was suffering from delusions, was admitted to psychiatric hospital. He did take his medication for a while, but became so upset by its disabling sedative effects that he started to refuse. It was then that he experienced psychiatry's powers of compulsory treatment, when six nurses pulled his trousers down to his ankles, pinned him to the ground and injected tranquillisers into one of his buttocks.

May was left traumatised and unable to trust his doctors. So after his discharge, and against all advice, he never returned to hospital. Instead, he went to live in a squat and, despite his confused state of mind, came off all medication. He eventually got a job as a night security guard at Highgate cemetery in north London.

Thirteen years on and May has not taken anti-psychotic medication since. His recovery is one that few patients - let alone mental health professionals - would go through. Yet May is now a clinical psychologist and is using his experience of being a psychiatric patient to challenge the traditional medical model for treating those who, like him, are diagnosed with severe mental illness.

"When I was a patient I felt misunderstood and written off," he says. "I thought I was treated cruelly. When I was forcibly treated and injected, it felt like rape."

May, who still suffers nightmares of being readmitted to hospital and being compulsorily medicated, channels his anger productively, arguing that as long as psychiatry's medical model continues to understand severe distress as rooted in biology, rather than experience, thousands of patients will be denied a fair chance of recovery.

With psychiatry's compulsory treatment powers, and a tendency to confuse the withdrawal effects of medication with symptoms, May fears vulnerable patients quickly become dependents. And, as it was for him, May believes that too often the mental health service handles patients inappropriately right from the beginning.

Before his admittance to hospital, May had been living in a "day-dream fantasy world" to escape a dull job as a draughtsman. He entertained theories that he was a spy and the television was broadcasting messages to him. When he was referred to two psychiatrists, they both listened as he told them his perception of the world. They scribbled notes. But not once did they question him about his views.

May was in and out of hospital for the next seven months - long enough to feel treated like a "social, moral and genetic outsider". But it was different when he joined the squatters, with whom he could share his bizarre thoughts without being seen as relapsing.

He came off his medication without professional help and managed to see through the surges of mania and restlessness which accompany withdrawal. But he was still too afraid to return to his psychiatrist. So he used his friends, and those he met at community centres and churches, slowly to rediscover his social skills and confidence.

After a number of casual jobs, May embarked on a psychology degree and, in what became a remarkable recovery, finally trained as a clinical psychologist at the University of East London. Yet throughout six years of study, he never revealed his past diagnosis.

This secret led to some tense encounters, particularly when May went to do placements in hospitals close to where he had been treated. He would bump into nurses and other patients whom he knew from his own patient days. "I remember one meeting when I saw it dawn on a nurse's face that he recognised me," he recalls. "Afterwards, the nurse told me not to worry and said my diagnosis was confidential and he would not tell anyone. I felt like an undercover agent spying on psychiatry. I had become the spy that I was in my delusions."

It was only after May had qualified that he "came out" to his colleagues about his schizophrenia diagnosis. May is now into his second year working as a clinical psychologist in Tower Hamlets, east London. He prefers to use a more "collaborative" approach when treating those diagnosed with psychotic illnesses. The first thing he will do is, quite simply, talk openly with patients.

"When I was a patient it was believed that talking about psychosis made it worse," he says. "But I prefer making sense with a person about their experience."

May has spent much time reflecting on what happened to him and believes his problem could have been more accurately defined as a severe identity crisis triggered by the breakdown of a relationship. "I believe that time, rest, low levels of short-term medication and dis cussing my experiences would have been the quickest route to a restoration of good mental health," he says.

Above all, May, who has built alliances with the mental health user movement, believes professionals should start redefining their relationships towards patients. "It is not right to say 'doctor knows best'. Psychiatrists and other professionals do have an expertise. But treatment will fail if they do not engage with clients who have an expertise about their own life. We should be coming to an agreement with clients about their treatment, rather than trying to impose it. Often, compulsory treatment is not necessary - it just drives people away from asking for help. And that can be dangerous."

He came off his medication without professional help and managed to see through the surges of mania and restlessness which accompany withdrawal. But he was still too afraid to return to his psychiatrist. So he used his friends, and those he met at community centres and churches, slowly to rediscover his social skills and confidence. After a number of casual jobs, May embarked on a psychology degree and, in what became a remarkable recovery, finally trained as a clinical psychologist at the University of East London. Yet throughout six years of study, he never revealed his past diagnosis. This secret led to some tense encounters, particularly when May went to do placements in hospitals close to where he had been treated. He would bump into nurses and other patients whom he knew from his own patient days. "I remember one meeting when I saw it dawn on a nurse's face that he recognised me," he recalls. "Afterwards, the nurse told me not to worry and said my diagnosis was confidential and he would not tell anyone. I felt like an undercover agent spying on psychiatry. I had become the spy that I was in my delusions." It was only after May had qualified that he "came out" to his colleagues about his schizophrenia diagnosis. May is now into his second year working as a clinical psychologist in Tower Hamlets, east London. He prefers to use a more "collaborative" approach when treating those diagnosed with psychotic illnesses. The first thing he will do is, quite simply, talk openly with patients. "When I was a patient it was believed that talking about psychosis made it worse," he says. "But I prefer making sense with a person about their experience." May has spent much time reflecting on what happened to him and believes his problem could have been more accurately defined as a severe identity crisis triggered by the breakdown of a relationship. "I believe that time, rest, low levels of short-term medication and dis cussing my experiences would have been the quickest route to a restoration of good mental health," he says. Above all, May, who has built alliances with the mental health user movement, believes professionals should start redefining their relationships towards patients. "It is not right to say 'doctor knows best'. Psychiatrists and other professionals do have an expertise. But treatment will fail if they do not engage with clients who have an expertise about their own life. We should be coming to an agreement with clients about their treatment, rather than trying to impose it. Often, compulsory treatment is not necessary - it just drives people away from asking for help. And that can be dangerous."

fields.headline: Hungry for funds
fields.standfirst: The Guardian Christmas appeal offers the chance to win readers' support for your favourite charity
fields.trailText: The Guardian Christmas appeal offers the chance to win readers' support for your favourite charity
fields.body:
Here is your chance to give a boost to your favourite charity, by nominating it for this year's Guardian Christmas appeal. We are looking for three charities which will benefit not only from readers' donations, but also from publicity in the Guardian over the Christmas period.

Last year, readers gave a total of more than £200,000 to the appeal charities. The three chosen from your nominations were the Family Welfare Association, the Fairtrade Foundation and Ockenden International. A fourth charity, Friends for Deaf Young People, was chosen from the winners of the Guardian's annual award for smaller social welfare charities. And the approach will be the same this year. We are inviting readers to propose charities in three categories -domestic poverty, overseas aid and the environment. A fourth charity will again be selected from the winners of the Guardian's award, results of which will be announced next month.

As last year, we are limiting nominations to charities with turnover of less than £10m. And while smaller charities will be considered, the general aim will be to help those medium-sized organisations that are continuing to find the going tough in the increasingly competitive voluntary sector. That means the three that are chosen from readers' nominations are likely to have a turnover in excess of £500,000.

Readers will be able to make a general donation, to be divided among the appeal charities, or identify which one they would like their money to go to. The fourth charity, selected will receive an allocation from general donations in proportion to its size.

During the period of the appeal, the Guardian will carry articles about the work of each of the charities. There will also be regular advertisements, setting out how readers may make donations.

Nominations should be made on the form below, or a photocopy, and must include all the information requested. Particular attention will be paid to the reasons given for why Guardian readers should help the nominated charity this year. Supporting material may be enclosed, but is not necessary.

The deadline for nominations is Friday, October 6. A panel of senior Guardian staff will make the final choice. Charities which have already submitted applications this year need not reapply, provided all necessary information has been supplied.

fields.headline: Readers' letters
fields.body:
Write response

I was very interested to read your artice about the difficulties that arise when you can't sign your name (Stripped of power, September 13).

I have suffered with rheumatoid arthritis for nearly 20 years and earlier this year had an operation to replace the knuckle joints on my right hand. The rehab process takes 13 weeks and I knew that I would not be able to sign my name for that period of time.

When I contacted my banks (I have two separate accounts), I was astounded to learn that the only option they could offer for payment in shops by debit card was to obtain a power of attorney. I pointed out that I was still quite capable of managing my own affairs and just had a temporary problem of physically signing my name.

In the event, one bank issued a letter to advise that my signature might not match the one on the card and gave a telephone number for retailers to ring. I was able to produce a semblance of a signature with my left hand and, since my right hand was encased in a very obvious splint, not one retailer objected to the childlike handwriting.

It is important that issues such as this are given publicity, and remedies found, and I congratulate Christine Barton on her persistence to maintain her independence.
Carole Bonner, London

Local accountability

Patients are central to the government's proposals for the NHS and community health councils (Muzzling the watchdog, September 13)

The new scrutiny role for local government members is key to the proposals. Patients get new advocates who will be able to sort out complaints and problems for them. There are also safeguards - a complaints system, forums and advisory panels - if serious matters occur.

The new role for local government is welcome and challenging. London boroughs are already working to provide high quality services. They have gained from their experience as members of community health councils and know the needs of their communities. This welcome extension of the scrutiny role builds on this and will generate a fresh partnership to deliver the high quality health care expected of the NHS.

What matters to patients is the care they get when they need it. The health secretary's proposals shift the emphasis to making this happen rather than clearing up problems later. With new resources and structures, we can ensure that the NHS works for patients and the whole community.
Sir Robin Wales, chair, Association of London Government

Priced out of social work

The extension of social work training to three years is welcome news and long overdue (Steep learning curves, August 30).

Sadly, however, there is still a serious issue of unequal opportunities. Formerly, social work students were disadvantaged by length of training. In future, they will be disadvantaged financially.

During the good years for university education, when students did not have to pay tuition fees and received grants, social work alone among the professions was limited to two years. The extension to three years has only been granted now when many working-class, mature students can no longer afford to go to university. Three years' accumulation of debt is even more daunting than two.

Nursing students do not have to pay tuition fees and may get some support. Social work students deserve and need to be treated equally.

My own observation of students on access courses indicates that some are choosing nursing simply because of affordability. I do not think it is in the long term interest of the nursing profession to have so many recruits who, in a situation of equal opportunities, would have chosen differently.

The loss to social work will not necessarily be a gain to nursing.
Gwyn Gwyntopher, London

Caring con trick

In simple language, Barbara Hutton described in a nutshell the reality of life in Britain now not only for the elderly, but also for those who are disabled or chronically sick (Letters, August 23).

My own experience in north Yorkshire tallies with hers - acute need is all too often met with bureaucratic impassivity ("that is not covered by the regulations") unless you are able to pay.

Community care is a con trick inflicted on us by one unscrupulous government and, to their shame, perpetuated by the present lot. I thank Barbara for at least having the spirit to try to alert the rest of us. Things will not change unless we all make an effort to force improvements.
Raye Whitten, Skipton

 Barbara Hutton asks if people realise what community care amounts to. The answer is no.

My son, totally physically disabled by cerebral palsy, lives independently in London with the help of "carers". He is transferred from bed to wheelchair and from wheelchair to toilet with the aid of slings - and he hasn't had a bath for years. This might be helpful to carers, but I can assure readers that it increases disabilities. Cleaning appears to be of little importance.

I am 83 and I know that, like the disabled, others decide what is good for us oldies - and dish it out accordingly, often wasting money on unsuitable and unused aids.
Hilda Davies, Birkenhead

Without region

"Britain's big provincial cities are on the march" it says here (Seven up for it, September 13). Look in vain in the article for Glasgow and Cardiff. Look further, and it seems the writer means "England's". If this is what we can expect from "the Guardian's regional affairs correspondent" it shows there's still a long way to go.
George Czernuszka, Oldham

fields.headline: No looking back
fields.standfirst: From the ashes of the mining and manufacturing industries in Ollerton, the seeds of a new, hi-tech future are emerging.  John Cunningham  reports
fields.trailText: From the ashes of the mining and manufacturing industries in Ollerton, the seeds of a new, hi-tech future are emerging. John Cunningham reports
fields.body:
When coal-mining ended at Ollerton, Nottinghamshire, in 1994, 700 men lost their jobs; now about 300 women will join the dole queue with the closure before Christmas of the town's biggest remaining factory.

Other communities would be flattened by such setbacks, but in this east Midlands town they have turned the tables and flattened the colliery site. They plan to use it as an energy-efficient, environmentally-sustainable village. Coal will be a taboo word.

It's a bold bid for economic survival in a town of 11,000 with an unemployment rate of just over 5%. The first stage - reclaiming the land, at a cost of £4m - is almost finished, but the earthmovers are silent at the moment, waiting for the last 12 families of sandpipers, a protected species, to quit their nests in a sandbank.

But on a ridge overlooking the vast Nottinghamshire site, there is a visual display of plans so that locals can get an idea of how the 90 derelict acres will be zoned for eco-friendly housing, hi-tech industry and leisure. There will be an exhibition centre and a large park.

The view is long term. Though the first batch of houses, probably to be self-built, will be up within a year or so, it will be anything from five to 10 years before Sherwood Energy Village, as it is already known, is complete and functioning with 400 or more jobs. And to signal the new era of energy generation, there will be a biomass power station.

In the short term, Ollerton is concerned with the effect of closure of the Coats Viyella factory. It is one of four to go in the region as the company ends its long links as a clothing supplier to Marks & Spencer. Whole families depend on the plant - all five of Sandy Houston's sisters, for instance. "Two full-time, one part-time, two outworkers," he says. "My mum's worked there for years, too. They've no idea what they'll do." Sandy was at Coats until last month when he quit to become a driver with a relative's taxi firm. He can hardly believe his luck in getting out.

Quite a few women at Coats are sole breadwinners, wives of former miners, says Dennis Walker, leader of the town council. For months, there were rumours that M&S's troubles would hit Ollerton, though that did not lessen the shock when the announcement came.

The disappearance of Coats marks the end of an enduring industrial marriage of a type contracted in many coalfields over 50 years ago. Hosiery and knitwear manufacture was started specifically to give work to wives and daughters of pitmen and to provide a second income.

Now, two generations on, Ollerton is on the cusp of change, though some older residents can hardly believe in the coming hi-tech era. They are still in mourning for mining, in the lunchtime emptiness in the vast miners' "welfare", where once top comedians and Tamla Motown groups used to come. Memories of the 1984-85 miners' strike - in which a man died on the Ollerton picket line - linger in endless streets of homes with uniform net curtains at the windows and concessionary coal in the fireplace.

To glimpse the future, step into the office of Carla Jamison, manager of the energy village. It is emphatically not the case that the community has turned its back on coal, she says. On the contrary, "coal was taken away from us".

What happened, she says, is that a public meeting to air concerns about the pit's future was scheduled for the very night, in March 1994, that its closure was officially announced. So the discussion changed from "What if...?" to "What now?" The community held strongly that the area should not be allowed to decline, with production ending at four of five local mines. "People wanted to build a sustainable future," Jamison says. "They said we've got to fight to replace the jobs lost and create a diverse economic base." They were adamant on one other point: "No more muck." Muck had become a dirty word. Recently, local groups have pitched in with specific ideas for their presence in the energy village: the scouts would like to erect a solar-design hut; the women's centre wants to self-build a meeting place.

Given that Ollerton miners were known for their moderation in industrial relations (though support for the breakaway Union of Democratic Mineworkers caused clashes), the plan they supported for using the land once the pit closed was startlingly radical. By 1996, they had acquired the site from the coal board for £50,000 - the money borrowed from the board itself - and opted for a structure to transform it that would, while bringing in outside investors, ensure control remained in local hands.

An industrial and provident society was set up, with all participants having just one vote, whether they held a single share or many thousands. Grants of £4m enabled reclamation work to begin last January. Recycling as much as possible of the industrial debris was a key goal.

In keeping with the masterplan, which has been drawn up on strict principles of sustainability, there must be no carbon dioxide emissions by the industrial companies that eventually come, and householders will use solar heating. In environmental terms, says Jamison, "there'll be nothing else like it".

A big breakthrough will be when the first of the hoped-for sunrise firms makes a solid commitment to move in. But there have been a few setbacks. It was hoped to convert one of the grassed-over tips, which ring much of the site, into a ski run. That has been abandoned.

Also, the most promising source of employment was a major supermarket not on the site itself, but next to it. Originally, it was to have opened about now, which would have been ideal for absorbing many of the Coats' staff. However, Walker says there have been delays with the company handling the deal. "I understand plans have been set back till 2001," he says. "I'm very disappointed with that."

But he is stoical. Dramatic change comes to communities that once passed as staid, but it happens slowly. Often its preceded by rumour - as with the death of the pit and the knitwear factory. By the same token, positive events unfold gradually.

Perhaps that is the pace that feels comfortable to communities relying on a narrow economic base. Because, for all the careful planning by the energy village team, and for all its excellent educational and missionary work about a clean future, there are still old wounds, dating from the miners' strike.

The dispute was 15 years ago, but still seems a short time ago to some. Walker was NUM branch president for part of the strike. "There was strong feeling," he recalls. "Brother against brother, father against son. There's still a little bit of feeling about that."

Walker is 70 and has been involved in the town for 35 years. He is all for the energy village, the new supermarket, a new business park. But he knows also that the days when Ollerton supplied men to work in four other nearby pits are over. Only one, Thoresby, is still operating.

He remembers, too, that he was made redundant when the strike was over. "We've been let down before," he says, "so we're taking it all quietly."

Pits and the pendulum

Almost 36,000 jobs were lost in the Nottinghamshire coalfield between 1980 and 1997 as the industry collapsed. Today, there are just four pits left: Clipstone, Harworth, Thoresby and Welbeck, which together employ some 1,900 workers.

On top of the direct job losses, many thousands more would have gone in industries supplying and servicing the pits. And thousands more again would have gone previously, as the pit workforces systematically shrank ahead of closure. In 1974, the Ollerton mine employed 1,355 - almost twice as many as were working there at the end.

Despite this dramatic slump in the deep-mined coal sector, Nottinghamshire recorded a net gain of 14,500 jobs in the period 1993-97. But there has been an imbalance across the county in jobs lost and jobs created.

While new, mainly service sector employers have been attracted to the south of the county - particularly around Nottingham itself - the north has not benefited to anything like the same degree. Former mining communities have generally fared worst, with Ollerton suffering a net loss of 500 jobs in 1993-97.

The government says it is devoting more than £1bn a year to regeneration of local authority areas with coalfields. But critics point out that this extends beyond ex-mining areas and also includes money for housing and welfare-to-work schemes.

David Brindle

House boots
Worn-out boots discarded by sewage workers in Staffordshire are being successfully recycled as homes for water voles. Stoke Sentinel, 30.8.00 (DP Hughes, Crewe)

Baby alarm
The parents of an 11-month-old child have enrolled him as a member of the AA in case anyone's car in which he is a passenger breaks down. Epsom and Ewell Chronicle, 30.8.00 (S Cannadine, Epsom)

Dogged service
Members of a cricket club in Bridgend, south Wales, have named a trophy after a labrador which has saved them hundreds of pounds in recent years by finding balls hit into bushes and long grass. Western Mail, 1.9.00 (Alexander Welsh, Llanidloes)

Wide-eyed and legless
Customers at a village pub near Yelverton, Devon, were stunned when bailiffs walked in and removed all the tables and chairs. Western Morning News, 30.8.00 (Nicola Neale, Sidmouth)

The kiss-off
The referee of a local football match in Hove, Sussex, sent off a striker who celebrated scoring a goal by snogging his girlfriend on the touchline. Birmingham Evening Mail, 1.9.00 (David Spilsbury, Birmingham)

Jail bait
A car thief was caught in Hammersmith, west London, when he tried to break into an unmarked van which police were using as a surveillance vehicle. News North West, 6.9.00 (Gillian Oakes, Cheadle)

Soaps wash-out
A course at Sunderland University on TV soaps has flopped because it was scheduled to run on Thursday evenings, when it would clash with Emmerdale and EastEnders. Newcastle Journal, 3.9.00 (David Carter, Middlesbrough)

Shaky evidence
Police responding to a 999 call from a terrified woman who reported drilling sounds outside her house in Worthing, Sussex, traced the noise to a faulty sex aid vibrating in a bedside drawer. Evening Argus, 8.9.00 (Elaine Sweetman, Brighton)

Easy pickings
A thief who broke into a house in Margate, Kent, had a bath, a cup of tea and a bacon sandwich before stealing the television, stereo and video. Birmingham Evening Mail, 24.8.00 (JC Davies, Birmingham)

V-signs?
A deaf, speech impaired man at a hostel in Blackburn, Lancashire, was arrested after a member of staff translated the torrent of abuse he was giving in sign language to police officers. Lancashire Evening Telegraph, 2.9.00 (John Shorter, Clitheroe)

Out of step
A planning application to convert two chicken sheds near Solihull, West Midlands, into a ballroom dancing studio has been refused because the site is on green belt land. Solihull Times, 1.9.00 (Brenda Langmead, Solihull)

Winner gives all
The manager of an independent advice centre in Halifax, Yorkshire, is using money he wins gambling on horse racing to help keep it running. Big Issue, 21.8.00 (John Rossington, Bradford)

Off the peg
A farmer from Honiton, Devon, believes that students stole tweed jackets from three of his scarecrows because the clothes are considered to be trendy. Sunday Independent, 27.8.00 (Ray Rose, Plymouth)

fields.headline: Give them a break
fields.standfirst: Disability charity's campaign to ease burden on families
fields.trailText: Disability charity's campaign to ease burden on families
fields.body:
Research shows that "shared care" schemes can play an invaluable role in giving a break to disabled children and their families. But an acute shortage of carers means 5,000 children can't get the service.

The Shared Care Network charity is next week running an awareness campaign under the slogan "give a little time and make a big difference". The campaign, to be launched on Saturday by 100 disabled children and their carers at the Millennium Dome, is aimed at recruiting people able to offer short breaks ranging from one evening a week to a weekend each month.

To coincide with the campaign, a study funded by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation is showing that current short-break carers tend to have professional or personal experience of disability. Many get involved because they know a child or family needing support.

The study, by researcher Beth Prewett, involved interviews with 53 carers providing breaks for 93 children with complex needs or challenging behaviour. Most carers said they enjoyed their role, were committed to the children and did not do it for money. Nevertheless, payments were inconsistent, and a source of irritation, and there was concern that expense did deter other people from coming forward.

Prewett found that most carers were reimbursed costs and received an extra payment, but the amount varied widely and there was lack of clarity about what it was for. Some carers complained that their full costs were not covered. One said: "The money is no good at all: it needs complete review. We're either a valuable resource or we're not."

The government's social services inspectorate has said that shared or short-break carers, also known as family link or respite carers, are "almost universally regarded by parents as a critical service". Disabled children gain experience of new environments, develop new relationships and engage in new activities, while their parents have time to relax or focus on their other children.

Shortages of carers are most acute in respect of children with severe disabilities and those from minority ethnic groups. Sue Mennear, development worker with Shared Care Network, says: "There is a growing awareness of the need for foster carers, thanks to the government's recruitment campaign, but many people simply do not know they can look after disabled children for regular, short periods of time."

Margaret and Norman Eskriett, from Nottinghamshire, decided to become short-break carers after they retired. They look after a child and a teenager. "I felt I needed to do something to give my life more purpose," says Margaret. "The children will give you more than you ever give them."

 Shared Care Network is on 0117-9731142. Further details of the Prewett study, Committed to Caring, are at www.jrf.org.uk
