fields.headline: Bernie Ecclestone
fields.trailText: Hot on the heels of a very long week in politics for the Labour government, there's fresh misery with accusations that the chancellor, Gordon Brown, lied about details surrounding a donation of £1m from Formula 1 boss Bernie Ecclestone. But just who is this man - and why is his gift creating such a stir? We explain.
fields.body:
Hot on the heels of a very long week in politics for the Labour government, due to the petrol crisis, there's fresh misery with accusations that the chancellor, Gordon Brown, lied about details surrounding a donation of £1m from Formula 1 boss Bernie Ecclestone. But just who is this man - and why is his gift creating such a stir? Claire Porter explains.

Who is Bernie Ecclestone?
He may be a short man - 5ft 4in - but he is a rich one, and one of the biggest names in international sport. He owns Formula One Holdings, which is the biggest and most influential company in motor racing, and also has a long-running contract with the sport's governing body, the Federation Internationale de L'Automobile (FIA), to sell television rights. This, therefore, gives him a huge standing and commands him a great deal of respect from both sportsmen and businessmen the world over. He has homes all over Europe and is believed to have a personal fortune of £2bn, though much of the company is owned by his Croatian-born wife Slavica - a 6ft 2in former Armani model. A degree in chemical engineering from Woolwich Polytechnic in south east London set the young, entrepreneurial Ecclestone on his way to success, but it was time spent at his car and motorbike dealership in Kent that got him hooked on motor racing. In the 1970s he established the Brabham racing team and even turned his hand at driving before a crash forced him to quit a career on the track. He is now a driving force in the FIA, enjoying a spell as second-in-command, and was listed as number 20 in last year's Rich List, cataloguing Britain's most affluent people. He is also a Labour supporter.

So what's the problem?
A £1 million donation to Labour in 1997, just after the party was elected to power, may have been a good and generous one, it's just the timing could have been a tad better. It came only weeks before the government announced motor racing would be exempt from a newly-introduced ban on tobacco sponsorship and just days after Ecclestone had joined a Downing Street delegation pointing out to the prime minister what a devastating effect such a ban would have had on the sport. The subsequent fall-out and cries of "sleaze" were described as Labour's worst week in power. Obviously that was before last week  oh, and this week.

What happened?
Tony Blair gave back the 'dirty' money and announced a shake-up of rules governing the disclosure of large party political donations. But that was not before members of Labour's ruling national executive (NEC) - including new London mayor Ken Livingstone - had demanded an independent inquiry into the party's dealings with Ecclestone.

Surely that's all in the past now?
Well, no. The issue has been raised again, with the publication of Observer commentator Andrew Rawnsley's book, Servants of The People, which claims that chancellor Gordon Brown had misled a radio interviewer about the extent of his knowledge of the donation. The shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, seized on the moment and called for Mr Brown's resignation because he said the chancellor knew about the donation three days before he was interviewed on the BBC radio programme Today, claiming he did not. Mr Brown had told the interviewer: "You'll have to wait and see, like I'll have to wait and see when the list (of donors giving more than £5,000) is published because I've not been told and I certainly don't know what the true position is." But Mr Portillo says the chancellor's spokesman later let slip about a meeting Mr Brown had with Mr Blair before the interview at which they'd discussed the £1m. The chancellor, of course, denies this and says that, while he spoke to the prime minister about the donation, he did not know how much it was or any other in-depth details. Mr Blair is sticking by him and rejecting calls for his resignation.
Useful Links:
Portillo calls for chancellor's head
The Observer extracts from Andrew Rawnsley's book

fields.headline: Frederick Forsyth to publish online
fields.trailText: Thriller writer Frederick Forsyth is set to follow Stephen King's example by publishing and selling his latest book exclusively on the internet
fields.body:
Thriller writer Frederick Forsyth is set to follow Stephen King's example by publishing and selling his latest book exclusively on the internet.

The Day of the Jackal author announced yesterday that his next book, Quintet, will comprise of a series of five short stories, published separately on the net. Customers will have to pay around £2 for each story, which will be protected by special software to deter people from downloading the book for free.

Forsyth follows in the footsteps of US horror writer Stephen King, who published his new novel, Riding the Bullet, on the web earlier this year and is currently releasing his latest book, The Plant, chapter by chapter. However, he is believed to be having problems recovering payment (see our Book trade column), reporting a "widening disparity between downloads and payments."

Fay Weldon is releasing her new novel, Woodworm, exclusively on the political website yougov.com, but is not charging readers.

According to Forsyth, publishing on the internet is the future for writers: "Having been writing since 1970, I consider myself something of a veteran author," he said. "I believe the advent of e-books is one of the most exciting developments in my experience as a professional writer. It offers the authors a whole range of new opportunities and freedom."

The first two stories, The Veteran and The Miracle, will be published by online originals later this month.

Managing director, Phil Rance, whose company up until now has only dealt with first-time authors, said that online publishing looks set to expand: "With rapid developments in handheld technology, and authors of Frederick's calibre being lured online, we predict a growth in appetite for e-books and a shift in power away from traditional publishing."

webTitle: Advertising Agency Register takes on first head of marketing

fields.headline: AAR hires marketing head for first time
fields.trailText: 12.15pm: The Advertising Agency Register has appointed its first head of marketing, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
The Advertising Agency Register has appointed its first head of marketing, Michelle de Young, who joins from the media and advertising headhunters, the Stevens Company.

De Young has previously worked in marketing roles at the Observer, BBC Magazines and John Brown Publishing.

She said: "The AAR started as almost a cottage industry, but it has developed into a huge service across many disciplines. We get lots of our work through word of mouth and I hope that continues, but this is a business and we have to market it."

De Young will report to Martin Jones, managing director of the AAR, who said: "Over the years the business has expanded into design, direct marketing, media planning and buying, public relations and sales promotions, and Michelle's role is to promote our total offering to the client community. We approached her because of her breadth of experience and understanding of marketing and new business development."

The AAR is also launching a through-the-line marketing campaign using the line: "AAR shortlists from long, long experience." The ads also feature some handy lists for clients such as "some off-the-cuff questions to ask at a media pitch" and "five things you'll never hear in a pitch".

webTitle: Plagiarists' paradise launched online for young essay writers

fields.headline: Plagiarists' paradise launched online for young essay writers
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Two Manchester-based undergraduate entrepreneurs yesterday launched a website carrying scores of A-grade essays which students are free to pass off as their own work.
fields.body:
Two Manchester-based undergraduate entrepreneurs yesterday launched a website carrying scores of A-grade essays which students are free to pass off as their own work.

The site is the latest enterprise of Nick Rose and Jordan Mayo, both 19, who published GCSE revision guides while at Manchester grammar school and went on to launch the revise.it website while in their first year at Oxford.

They claim their new essay bank, aimed at A-level students and new undergraduates, is the largest free collection ever made available online.

The site has already been warmly welcomed by students and condemned by teachers as an incitement to cheating.

Subjects on which essays are available include languages, history of art, religious studies, economics, history and politics.

Mr Rose, studying philosophy, politics and economics at Lady Margaret Hall, admits spending much of his first university year working on his website. He passed his exams only with the help of friends' essays which he doctored to conform to his own style.

"I've never been very good at essay writing," he confessed. "We don't see the essay bank as a cheating mechanism. It's an incredibly valuable resource and the essays are there for everyone to share.

"You can learn an awful lot by reading other people's work on the subject. And if you are short of an essay at 8.30 on a Monday morning, decide to copy one of ours and don't get caught, that's fine.

"Exams are a fight. It's us against them. If they don't catch us, we win. If they do, well ..."

Essay titles include How Noble is Othello? ("The Moor should be seen as a complex being who himself cannot decide who he is or what he stands for") and Is My Own Existence Really Necessary? ("For Descartes, the cogito marked the end of his hyperbolic doubt").

The site also offers GCSE essays, including an account of a day at a Roman circus from a charioteer's point of view: "The Circus Maximus could be best described as a bastion of bourgeois respectability."

The website suggests students add bogus quotations and attribute them to genuine authorities. "Popular people to use are Douglas Hurd (1980s) or Disraeli (any time 1827-80)."

Teachers have begun to post disapproving comments on the site: "As a teacher of English who has recommended your site to my pupils, I am appalled that you have the audacity to encourage students to cheat and copy essays."

Students who have contacted revise.it disagree. "Once again you have saved my bacon," one says. "Thanks."

fields.headline: Kidnapped journalists escape Filipino rebels
fields.trailText: Two French television journalists who were held hostage by Muslim rebels on a southern Philippines island since July have managed to escape.
fields.body:
Two French television journalists who were held hostage by Muslim rebels on a southern Philippines island since July said today that they managed to escape while their captors fled from a massive assault by the Filipino military.

Jean-Jacques Le Garrec, 46, and Roland Madura, 49, who were among 19 people still being held by the Abu Sayyaf group on Jolo, used the cover of darkness to slip away from the rebels while they were crossing a road.

"We hid for some minutes and, after that, we ran on the road," Mr Le Garrec said at a news conference at the presidential palace in Manila.

"We spent the night hiding in the jungle in case they would be looking around for us."

He added: "This morning at four o'clock ... the noise of the rain gave us the opportunity of moving ourselves without being heard. We walked until daytime, having the feeling that we were going towards Jolo [town] and expecting to meet the checkpoint.

"Actually, since we didn't know exactly where we were, we were going away from Jolo, but at the daytime we hid again in the jungle along the road and we waited for a jeepney or truck to pass by."

The two men flagged down a military truck on the road. They were taken to a military camp and then airlifted to the capital Manila.

The two France-2 television journalists are the first of 19 hostages to be recovered since the Philippines government launched a military campaign against Abu Sayyaf at the weekend.

The group has kidnapped scores of people since March but most have been released, with Libya and Malaysia reportedly paying more than $15m for 19 foreigners.

The rebels are currently holding an American, three Malaysians, a Filipino kidnapped from a Malaysian diving resort in April, and 12 Filipino Christian evangelists.

Seven rebels have been killed and 20 captured in the five days since the military assault began, while six government troops were wounded, military officials said.

Early today, a bomb exploded on a passenger ferry shortly after it arrived at Zamboanga city, near Jolo, killing at least one person and injuring six others, two critically, officials said. The military said it suspects that Muslim rebels were responsible.

fields.headline: My father, the hero
fields.standfirst: Muhammad Ali's daughter Hana tells  Emma Brockes  why her father really was the greatest - and not just in the ring
fields.trailText: Muhammad Ali's daughter Hana tells Emma Brockes why her father really was the greatest - and not just in the ring.
fields.body:
Hana Ali doesn't look much like her father, but she sounds like him, rattling through stories at a speed that suggests she has never, in her 24 years, suffered one moment's equivocation. "The first time I knew my dad was somebody was when I was four years old and we went to a restaurant and everyone gave him a standing ovation and began chanting 'Ali! Ali!' I got goosebumps. I didn't know what it was all about, but I thought, 'Wow, my daddy's great.' "

She is the older of two girls from Muhammad Ali's second marriage, the only one of his nine progeny to have been brought up predominantly by him. Her sister Laila, two years younger and recently embarked on a boxing career, says that Hana is "obsessed" with their father. Hana has just published a book entitled More Than a Hero: Muhammad Ali's Life Lessons Presented Through His Daughter's Eyes. "I'll quit a job if I can't get time off to go visit him," she says. "If my dad's here, that's where I am. My sisters are more logical. They're not going to quit their jobs. But I figure, one day he's not going to be here, so I want every moment that I can."

The book is a slim volume containing those of Hana's childhood memories that highlight her father's moral character: the time she wanted to wear a white dress and expensive jewellery to school and her father told her it would make the poor kids feel bad; how he interrupted family outings to help beggars, buying them food and sometimes setting them up in hotel rooms and finding them jobs; all the times when people stole from him and he forgave them.

Among the recollections, and by far the most affecting part of the book, are the pre-fight poems Ali taunted his opponents with: "I injured a stone / Hospitalised a brick. / I'm so mean I make medicine sick." They remind you of those great 1960s photos of him gloating into the camera with beautiful mock menace. There is his buoyant retelling of the Sonny Liston fight: "Liston disappears from view/ The crowd is getting frantic / But our radar stations have picked him up / He's somewhere over the Atlantic." And the most famous of Ali's poems: "Float like a butterfly /Sting like a bee / Your hands can't hit / What your eyes can't see."

Hana was too young to remember most of her father's fights. The abiding image she has of Ali the athlete is of the end of his career. "I remember my dad training for his last two fights, which he did not win. I remember him sitting at the ringside with a robe on, with his head down. He was finally feeling that it was the end. It wasn't so much the fighting he loved, but the travelling, the attention, the proving to himself and the world that he could be the best. He loved to do things when everything was against him and it seemed impossible. It was hard to let go of."

Growing up as Muhammad Ali's daughter should have been fraught with the miseries famous people commonly inflict on their children: inferiority complex, identity crisis, cycles of over-indulgence and neglect. But Hana says that he was as generous to his children as to his fans and that of all of her siblings, she was the main beneficiary of his wisdom. It would sound gushy if Ali's vast goodness was not a matter of incontrovertible fact.

Laila was closer to their mother, Veronica, and it was Hana who followed Ali around like a puppy. When he and Veronica divorced, she was nine. "If anything, I saw him more after that," she says. "He was there almost every day and he tried to take us with him when he went away. He would send postcards which read, 'You're beautiful like your mother, I love you,' in his messy writing.

"He was nervous that I would forget him. When my mother got remarried he asked, 'Do you have a new daddy?' And I was like, 'Daddy, are you out of your mind? I love you more than life. No one will ever come close to replacing you.' "

"We had a lot of governesses and housekeepers and stuff. But my dad always said we could interrupt him no matter who he was talking to, even the president. The door was always open. There was never a moment when we couldn't disturb him."

He spoilt her, but whenever she showed signs of becoming bigheaded, his Muslim piety kicked in and he gently told her to cool it. "I remember bragging a lot about him. I'd say, 'I can do whatever I want; my dad is Muhammad Ali.' That sort of thing. But at the same time, I was humble too, because it was instilled in me from a young age that I shouldn't flaunt things that other kids might not have. So I was always giving stuff away, as he always gave, gave, gave."

Although Hana was exposed to celebrity from a young age, she knew her father's fame to be in some way different from that of his movie star friends. "I was used to seeing people from the TV in real life. John Travolta was always over at our house. But Daddy was different. People wouldn't just ask for his autograph when they saw him in the street. They would hug him and cry. People really loved him."

During the course of his boxing career, Hana only knew Ali to be angry twice. "My dad was never a very vicious boxer. He just did what he had to do to win the fight. The only time I saw him lose control was in a fight against Floyd Patterson. Patterson would not call him Muhammad Ali; he insisted on calling him Cassius Clay. You could see my dad in the ring, yelling, 'What's my name?' boom, 'What's my name?' boom. It was about something bigger. He was in there fighting for respect. That's the only time he threw some vicious punches."

"The other time involved his fight with Joe Frazier. My father was kept from his boxing career for three years for the stand he took [against the Vietnam draft], and here was a guy who went to war and now he was the champ and my dad felt robbed. The play turned more serious and he started calling Frazier an Uncle Tom. He believed that stuff. But when he saw on a documentary about how Joe Frazier's kids were teased and came home crying from school, he cried."

Of the two girls, Laila was the one who rebelled, dressing "immodestly", ditching Islam and taking up boxing, which Ali disapproves of as a women's sport. Hana went to a small private college in Boston and dropped out after two years because she was homesick for her father. Her intention now is to write children's books with "a strong moral message". She regrets not finishing college, but consoles herself with the lessons learned from her father. "I'm not going to follow the rules of society, I'm going to follow my instincts," she says, although it sounds a bit pat, a generation removed.

About her father's Parkinson's disease, she says it has slowed down his speech, but since he spoke so fast to begin with, it is not very noticeable. "When he's relaxed and at home, he will not shut up. He's cracking jokes, playing around. He's just the same."

Despite his disapproval, Ali attends his daughter Laila's fights. "He doesn't agree with women boxing, period, but he's supportive of her. When he's watching her at ringside, you'll see all the manifestations of emotion in his face: fear, excitement, reminiscence. My dad called me on the phone recently and said, 'Hana writes books, Laila throws hooks.' Ain't that something?"

More Than a Hero by Hana Ali is published by Hodder & Stoughton, price £10.

fields.headline: Marketing round-up
fields.trailText: Latest news from trade title Marketing.
fields.body:
United Distillers & Vintners has lost one of its most senior marketers to rival Allied Domecq. Kim Manley, president and global brand director for Smirnoff, has become chief marketing officer at Domeqc. He fills the post vacated in March by Todd Martin, who became president, North America.

Direct Line has signed a year-long £2m deal to sponsor ITV's movie premier slot in a bid to broaden its appeal beyond insurance to other financial services.

The National Magazine Company is launching a sister magazine to Cosmopolitan, called Cosmo Girl. It will be a monthly title aimed at 12- to 17-year-old girls . A related website will be launched in the first quarter of next year.

BMW is considering hiring a dedicated agency to handle advertising for its motorcycle range in a move that could see WCRS, its lead agency, losing a chunk of the car maker's business.

Three of Diageo's top drinks marketers have quit to join eSkye.com - a new online procurement site for alcohol retailers. The most senior, UDV global brand services director Andrew Allan, becomes managing director of the UK operation. He will be joined at eSkye's European management team by John Davison and Keith McLeod.

Hennes & Mauritz (H&M), the Swedish fashion retailer, is seeking a creative and media agency to handle a UK campaign. The work will form part of a £66m marketing drive to strengthen the chain's position in the US and UK.

ONdigital has signed up 47 brands to its TV internet service ONet, which launches this week. Simply Money, WH Smith Online and Scottish Power are among the "portal partners".

Teen portal MyKindaplace.com is to sponsor Sky One's US teenage drama Popular in a deal worth £100,000.

fields.headline: Revolution round-up
fields.trailText: Latest news from trade title Revolution.
fields.body:
Revolution's big story of the week is the news that Weetabix is making its online debut through a link-up with Babyworld.com - the parenting portal owned by Freeserve.

French-based e-commerce comparison site Kelkoo.com has merged with Norwegian clone Zoomit.com, as part of its continued European expansion.

Streets Online, the entertainment retailer in which BSkyB has a minority stake, has postponed its initial public offering due to difficult market conditions.

Revolution is launching an Asian edition in October. To be based in Hong Kong, the title is a joint venture between English language newspaper the South China Morning Post and Haymarket. It will be edited by former features editor Rachel Oliver.

The London Premier Screenings Festival - where film rights are sold - is to get its own trading platform in October. If successful, the portal will be expanded to other film festivals.

Online recruitment service StepStone is to move into interactive TV, with plans to appear on NTL's service before the end of the year.

John Charcol, the mortgage broking service from Bradford & Bingley, is to rebrand as just Charcol and increase its marketing spend to communicate the new brand-name.

EBay is introducing SMS and Wap bidding services within the next few weeks through Vodafone.

fields.headline: Marketing Week round-up
fields.trailText: Latest news from trade title Marketing Week.
fields.body:
Allied Domecq Spirits & Wines has hired Smirnoff president Kim Manley to be its top global marketer. He joins as chief marketing officer, replacing global marketing director Todd Martin, who became president of Allied Domecq North America in March. Manley will oversee international marketing, including the UK.

McDonald's is refusing to make any further payments to the Millennium Dome as part of its £12m sponsorship package, despite a report from accountancy firm PriceWaterhouseCoopers that claims it still owes £2.4m. The report, commissioned by Dome chairman David James, says that a number of sponsors still owe £5m between them.

The New Millennium Experience Company is considering slashing the Millennium Dome's marketing budget by up to two thirds, or £2.3m, over the next three months in a quest to achieve cost savings. The business is handled by M&C Saatchi.

Millennium Dome head of advertising Eliza Burrows has become an associate partner at communications company Circus.

Halifax Card Services is planning to double the size of its operation, including its marketing department, as part of plans to increase its customer base to 3m by 2003. The company is seeking seven senior marketing executives, including a sales and marketing director and a head of direct marketing.

Courts, the furnishing retailer, has undergone a top-level restructure and is about to launch a £20m advertising campaign to reposition the group's ailing UK chain to target younger consumers. Marketing director Richard Coe has been promoted to deputy managing director, while managing director Bruce Cohen becomes chairman and will be replaced by his son, Steve Cohen.

The charity Voluntary Services Overseas is reviewing its £1m ad account - currently held by Burkitt DDB.

Plans to appoint Richard Eyre, RTL director of strategy and content, as chairman of Channel 5 have collapsed following objections by United News & Media, which owns 35 per cent of the channel.

BT is to sponsor three of ITV's early evening shows in a £3m three-month deal. It is the first time the channel's early evening schedule has been sponsored in one block.

fields.headline: Sporting failures
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about being bad at sport and why we love it so much
fields.trailText: All you need to know about being bad at sport and why we love it so much.
fields.body:
1. Eric Moussambani is not a household name. But Eric the Eel, as he is now better known, is an instant Olympic hero: he's the slowest swimmer in the history of the Games.

2. Eric's main achievement in completing his 100-metre freestyle heat was, in the caustic comment of the Mirror, that he didn't drown. To be fair however, he only took up swimming this year.

3. But the crowd loved him. He's a star. Just like Eddie "the Eagle" Edwards, who floundered to fame in the 1988 winter Olympics, coming 55th out of 56 in the ski-jumping. (The 56th was disqualified.)

4. Eddie, who is now a legal eagle, has done nicely for himself since he wowed the crowds in Calgary with his fearless fecklessness. He's in high demand as an after-dinner speaker.

5. It still understandably narks Eddie that in his annus mirabilis, he was pipped by Steve "Interesting" Davis as BBC Sports Personality of the Year. Otherwise, he seems happy enough with the rewards of failure.

6. So too is Frenchman Jean Van de Velde, who had a three-shot lead on the last tee and still managed to make a complete horlicks of it at the 1999 Open golf championship in Carnoustie.

7. Britain, of course, specialises in sporting failures, not all of them heroic.

fields.headline: At this price?  Carillion
fields.trailText: At least one company has faith in Labour's ability to deliver a strong economy. Carillion, the construction and services group, is pinning hopes on the government's £180bn transport investment programme and private finance initiative, Sir Neville Simms, the chairman, said yesterday.
fields.body:
At least one company has faith in Labour's ability to deliver a strong economy. Carillion, the construction and services group, is pinning hopes on the government's £180bn transport investment programme and private finance initiative, Sir Neville Simms, the chairman, said yesterday.

A "lengthening and strengthening" order book stood at £4.15bn, including £1.7bn from stakes in PFI concession companies. Profits growth over the next two to three years would come from activities such as services, infrastructure and facilities management and the PFI rather than traditional and unfashionable construction.

Carillion, demerged from building materials group Tarmac in July last year, is restructuring and the cost, notably at its Crown House mechanical and electrical engineering business (CHE), meant a first-half, pre-tax loss of £9.3m, against a £10.4m profit last time.

With turnover up 6% to £926m, Sir Neville was able to declare a 13% rise in operating profits to £15.8m before exceptionals, an increase in underlying margins to 2.2% and a 3% increase in the interim dividend to 1.34p.

But the group, which said last month it had taken a £25m charge to cover losses on CHE contracts, is to take a further £9m charge in the second half to cover redundancies and closures. Analysts said annual earnings should be £43m before exceptionals, better than last year yet below expectations.

Restructuring also took its toll at GTRM, Carillion's joint venture rail maintenance business, but Sir Neville was confident spending on track renewal would rise. A tripling of turnover in its PFI business to £126m has made Carillion market leader with more than 30% of all contracts.

With its shares down a mere 0.5p to 100.5p yesterday, a bad day overall, the City seemed prepared to give Sir Neville the benefit of the doubt. But investors should be wary until the uncertainties are out of the way.

David Gow

fields.headline: Energis share issue to raise £400m
fields.trailText: Energis is to raise £400m through a share issue in an aggressive bid to beat rivals in the race to roll out broadband services.
fields.body:
Business telecoms company Energis is to raise £400m through a share issue in an aggressive bid to beat rivals in the race to roll out broadband services.

The company is bidding for UK broadband radio licences, which become available in mid-October, and is poised to take advantage of BT's move to open up its lines to broadband telecoms companies.

Energis was spun off from the National Grid two years ago in a perfectly timed move that coincided with a surge in demand for high-speed communications.

The £9bn company has clients including Boots, the BBC and Freeserve, which use its state-of-the-art data networks. These networks will become even more attractive if Energis wins a number of broadband radio licences, which will make them accessible through radio signals rather than cable.

Mike Grabiner, chief executive of Energis, said: "The placing announced today will provide us with greater financial strength, which will enable us to develop further our business in the UK and continental Europe to leverage our extensive network and improve local access by exploiting new technologies, and to extend our internet capabilities."

Energis is also moving into the mobile phone market this autumn with the launch of Energis Mobile, having clinched a three-year virtual network operator agreement with Orange in the UK.

"It has done the sensible thing, given the need to fund its roll-out strategy. The timing is good, because at least it is ahead of its competitors," said one analyst.

The FTSE100-listed shares tumbled 6% in morning trading, from 639p to 556.5p, largely due to the discounted price of the offering. The company added that profits and revenues for its November interims were in line with expectations.

webTitle: NY look is Bardot meets Blondie

fields.headline: NY look is Bardot meets Blondie
fields.trailText: "If you don't call me, I'm totally gonna slit my wrists. Mwah!" When the assembled throng greet each other thus, it can only be New York fashion week.
fields.byline: Jess Cartner-Morley, fashion editor in New York
fields.body:
"If you don't call me, I'm totally gonna slit my wrists. Mwah!" When the assembled throng greet each other thus, it can only be New York fashion week.

The advance rumours were of a lacklustre showing for New York this season. European designers are apparently feeling homesick: Alexander McQueen, Nicole Farhi and Donatella Versace are all showing in their native countries.

What is more, the American big-hitter Tommy Hilfiger (nicknamed "Tommy Low-Figures" following disappointing results earlier in the year) is taking time out from the show schedule to throw a party.

And the fashion world has been stung by a New York Times article by Fred Kent, a city planning consultant, which cited fashion shows and drug dealing as "private commercial interests" monopolising Bryant Park, "one of Manhattan's most remarkable, best-loved places".

Fern Mallis, organiser of the fashion week, called the comparison between designers and drug dealers "rather unfair".

But the American designer Marc Jacobs, 37, hit back at the critics with a sexy, fresh collection - Brigitte Bardot meets Blondie - staged on a basketball court. In a star-studded front row were the rap artist Puff Daddy, entrepreneur Donald Trump, actresses Winona Ryder and Milla Jovovich, and Blondie's lead singer herself, Debbie Harry.

St Tropez candy stripes and shell motifs, ra-ra skirts and satin bomber jackets were offset by leather flat caps, punky ruched shoulders, outsize diamante brooches and belts of shiny black rubber. There was still a flavour of last season's 1950s typing pool chic in the cinched waists and contrast piping trim, but the frumpiness was gone.

Jacobs is one of the most influential designers. In 1992, while designing for Perry Ellis, he launched "grunge chic", getting himself fired in the process but sparking a worldwide trend. Seven years later, as designer for the French luxury label Louis Vuitton, he championed "logomania" and turned a staid luggage firm into one of the hippest labels to be seen in.

webTitle: India need the best coach - of any nationality

fields.headline: India need the best coach - of any nationality
fields.trailText: Geoff Marsh scored 101 in Bombay; John Wright's three centuries were all on home turf. Otherwise these two openers have had little impact on India, but that might change. After the predictable departure of Kapil Dev (a year of failure, and one blub too many on television) his predecessor Anshuman Gaekwad has stepped in until the Indian board appoints a long-term successor. But the message is loud and clear: the coach will be a non-Indian and Marsh and Wright are the men most likely.
fields.body:
Geoff Marsh scored 101 in Bombay; John Wright's three centuries were all on home turf. Otherwise these two openers have had little impact on India, but that might change. After the predictable departure of Kapil Dev (a year of failure, and one blub too many on television) his predecessor Anshuman Gaekwad has stepped in until the Indian board appoints a long-term successor. But the message is loud and clear: the coach will be a non-Indian and Marsh and Wright are the men most likely.

It is not an easy job to sell. The ad reads something like this: "Cricket-mad nation seeks squeaky-clean modern thinker to lead its tarnished, demoralised, but talented team to the promised land of a top three spot in the Wisden World Championship (victory in the World Cup would also do nicely). The Indian Cricket Board is a no-confidence employer (we have none in you, you have none in us). Government interference is expected and to be tolerated. Locals have been dumped (and dumped on) many times. Hence, only Johnny Foreigners with any loose association with international cricket need apply. Coaching qualifications not essential."

This clamour for a foreign coach might not stand up to scrutiny by an equal-opportunities panel, but India is not alone in believing that the panacea for its cricketing ills lies in foreign magic bullets. Most Test nations have been seduced by the idea at some time - the logic being that if your team is performing hopelessly then the answer is to recruit a coach from a successful nation, at the cutting edge of cricket thinking. This usually boils down to attempting to sign any unemployed Australian or South African. Zimbabweans and Kiwis sometimes get a look in too - never Asians, unless your name is Dav Whatmore. Could you imagine England, for example, hiring a Pakistani to add a dash of adventure, recklessness, and scandal to its cricket? No, the steady hand of Zimbabwean Duncan Fletcher is as risky a foreign flirtation as England is prepared to make.

Indeed, swapping allegiances between England, Australia, South Africa, New Zealand, and Zimbabwe is purely a matter of business and professionalism. For the Asians, however, it is more complex. A Pakistani coach of India (and vice versa) is unthinkable. When the Asian boards call for a foreign coach, they mean a Westerner. But there are simply not enough top class coaches to go around - a surprise given the number of ex-players stalking the media world gushing wisdom. As with most types of management, however, it is one thing spotting a deficiency and an entirely different proposition putting it right. And the view that only a foreign coach can fix it when it's broke is as indicative of the incompetence of a nation's cricket structure and ruling body as it is of the players and coaching staff.

Appointing the best candidate is simpler than ruling in, or ruling out, any particular nationality. Indeed there are considerable doubts about India appointing a foreigner. If building team spirit and developing a rapport with the players is the coach's first task, then two barriers have to be overcome: language and culture. It is difficult enough for an Indian to master the myriad dialects and customs that make up Hindustan, let alone an outsider. Nevertheless, let us assume our fictitious super coach does have it in him. He is now faced by a third problem: authority. Asian cricketers are the biggest, most glitzy stars in their countries. With hero status come egos as big, and immovable, as elephants, and a coach of real stature is needed to shepherd this disaffected herd. Such desperation for a foreigner is also an insult to Indians - now deemed corrupt or incompetent or both.

Just over a year ago, Pakistan went down the same route and appointed South African Richard Pybus. Pybus got on well with "the boys" but he never had authority; not even the quiet sort that Duncan Fletcher possesses. Wasim Akram was in charge and everyone knew it. Now Pakistan is much stronger because Javed Miandad's credentials and cricket brain are highly respected.

India must learn from England's and Pakistan's experience: the answer is not to choose a coach for his foreignness, but to appoint the most accomplished technician, man-manager, and motivator available, Indian or otherwise. Gaekwad did a half-decent job last time around (the half that was played on home territory) but he is not a serious long-term candidate. In that case step up Sunil, Ravi, or Geoffrey. Are there match-winning actions behind those, oh so wise, words?

Kamran Abbasi, born in Lahore, brought up in Rotherham, is editor of the Bulletin of the World Health Organisation. His Anglo-Asian View appears every other Wednesday on Cricket Unlimited and wisden.com. To read his previous columnn, on England's best Under-15 cricketer, click here. Next Wednesday Orin Gordon returns with his Anglo-Caribbean View.

webTitle: Swimmer Eric Moussambani sets Olympic record - the slowest

fields.headline: Swimmer Eric Moussambani sets Olympic record - the slowest
fields.standfirst: Swimmer from the Equatorial Guinea clocks one minute 52.72 in 100m freestyle
fields.trailText: Swimmer from the Equatorial Guinea clocks one minute 52.72 in 100m freestyle
fields.body:
He might not have won gold, or any other medal for that matter, but Eric Moussambani from the Equatorial Guinea in west Africa yesterday covered himself in glory by becoming the slowest ever swimmer to win an Olympic race.

Moussambani, 22, who only took up swimming this year and was swimming for the first time in a 50 metre Olympic size pool, just about managed to stay afloat in the men's 100 metre freestyle race, which he won in a record slow time of one minute 52.72 seconds.

His two fellow competitors, Karim Bare of Nigeria and Farkhod Oripov of Tajikstan were disqualified for false starts.

Moussambani's time was 30 seconds slower than Arnold Gutmann of Hungary's winning time in the first ever 100 metres freestyle final at the Athens Olympics in 1896. It was also slower than Dutchman Pieter van den Hoogen band's 200 metres freestyle win in the same Sydney Olympic pool several hours earlier in a world record time of one minute 45.35 seconds.

With only the clock to race against Moussambani was roared towards the finishing line by a passionate Australian crowd.

Moussambani, who usually trains in a 20 metre pool in Malabo, capital of Equatorial Guinea - the only pool of its kind in the country - was yesterday in philosophical mood about his heroics.

"Gold medal is not everything in the Olympics," he said in true Olympian spirit. "I am really happy with what happened, it was all worth it. I want to come back next time for the 2004 games in Athens. This has been a very special moment for me. I will never forget it."

Despite winning his heat, Moussambani was eliminated from the competition because of his slow time and is preparing to return home.

His training includes swimming in a river near his home, which, according to reports, is sometimes visited by crocodiles.

He vowed yesterday to practice harder and said he was already preparing for the 2004 games in Athens.

"I want to send hugs and kisses to the crowd because it was their cheering that kept me going," he said.

webTitle: Bell steps down from role as chief executive of Excite

fields.headline: Bell resigns from chief executive role at Excite
fields.standfirst: Excite Chello gears up for merger approval
fields.trailText: 9.45am: George Bell has taken a step back from Excite by resigning from his role as chief executive officer. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
George Bell, who became Excite's first chief executive in 1996, has taken a step back from the business by resigning from his role as chief executive officer.

The news, which sent a ripple through the internet industry, is not entirely unexpected. The Excite @ Home merger deal with Chello is expected to be given regulatory approval next month and it has always been said that Bell would take a more supervisory board role over the merged company, and share the chairmanship with UPC chairman/ceo Mark Schneider. Chello president and ceo Roger Lynch is to become chief executive officer of the merged company.

Bell, who is currently chairman and chief executive officer of Excite @ Home, is to remain full-time chairman of the broadband company's board of directors at least until the end of 2001. "This move is a proactive move, initiated by George, to manage the future executive growth of the company," said a spokeswoman for Excite. webTitle: Leagas Delaney resigns Benedick's account after 10 years

fields.headline: Leagas Delaney parts company with Benedick's
fields.trailText: 9am: Leagas Delaney has resigned its Benedick's of Mayfair account after 10 years, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Leagas Delaney has resigned its Benedick's of Mayfair account, ending a 10-year relationship with the upmarket confectionery brand.

The two companies have been unable to agree a creative strategy for the £2m business.

Nick Hough, Leagas Delaney's managing director, said: "It has become clear to us over the last year or so that our idea of what constitutes creative and effective advertising differs markedly from that of the Benedick's team."

Paul Seftel, managing director of Benedick's, said: "Leagas Delaney is a fine agency that produces outstanding creative work for many clients. However, we are unable to agree on the best way forward for the Benedick's brand. Therefore it is best we part company."

fields.headline: Putin's men blackmailed media mogul
fields.trailText: Vladimir Putin's government secretly agreed to drop criminal charges against its chief rival, tycoon Vladimir Gusinsky, in return for his agreement to sell off his media empire, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Vladimir Putin's government secretly agreed to drop criminal charges against its chief rival, tycoon Vladimir Gusinsky, in return for his agreement to sell off his media empire, it emerged yesterday.

The government also agreed to lift a travel ban on Mr Gusinsky and guarantee the security and liberties of several prominent Russian journalists as part of the deal.

The former Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev denounced the government's tactics as "crude blackmail" after documents were leaked indicating interference in the constitutional rights of citizens.

The power struggle for control of NTV, Russia's biggest private television channel and the jewel in the crown of Mr Gusinsky's extensive media empire, turned more vicious after lengthy negotiations on a takeover of the Gusinsky assets collapsed in mudslinging.

Media Most, Mr Gusinsky's holding company, and Gazprom, Russia's gas monopoly, have been negotiating Gazprom's takeover of the media empire for several months. Mr Gusinsky signed a deal in July pledging to surrender his assets for $300m (£210m) while Gazprom promised to take on $473m in Media Most debt.

On Monday Mr Gusinsky reneged on the deal, declaring he was coerced "at gunpoint" and disclosing that he had signed an affidavit in the presence of two foreign lawyers two days before the deal was struck stating that it was invalid because it was reached under duress.

Paramilitary police raided Mr Gusinsky's offices in Moscow earlier this year and the mogul was briefly jailed in June in an incident that triggered international concern about Mr Putin's attitude to media freedoms. Since then the president has repeatedly attacked the Gusinsky media and other outlets he considers disloyal.

A secret appendix to the July 20 agreement to sell out to Gazprom, released yesterday by the Gusinsky team and signed by Mikhail Lesin, the media minister, detailed the terms for the proposed Gazprom takeover and the tradeoff of Mr Gusinsky's and others' rights in return for the media surrender.

The confidential appendix stipulated that the criminal investigation of Mr Gusinsky was being dropped and a travel ban lifted.

It added that Mr Gusinsky and "leaders of the organisation" - meaning the chief editors of his newspaper, magazine, radio station, and TV channel - were being granted "security guarantees, the protection of their rights and liberties, including the guaranteed right to move freely, to choose their place of residence, and to travel freely beyond the borders of the Russian federation and to return to the Russian federation without hindrance".

Yevgeny Kiselyev, the director of NTV and a star Russian television journalist, said: "This is documentary evidence that the state is engaged in racketeering."

Mr Gorbachev, who is broadly supportive of Mr Putin but warned last week that media freedoms in Russia could be in jeopardy, said he was seeking a meeting with Mr Putin to try to clear up the row.

"I'm not sure whether the president knew about this [secret agreement]," said Mr Gorbachev. "Perhaps he didn't know... But if this is going on behind the president's back, it's even worse - you have an elected president and then you have these clans operating."

The document was signed by Mr Lesin and Alfred Kokh, the head of Gazprom's modest media holdings who has been leading the negotiations.

Media Most is heavily indebted to Gazprom and the gas monopoly maintains that it is seeking the takeover in order to resell a controlling share in the empire to unnamed foreign investors in order to recoup its money.

Media Most and many analysts contend that Gazprom is acting as a proxy for the Kremlin in order to tame the influential Gusinsky media which are critical of Mr Putin.

Mr Gusinsky moved to Spain after being freed from jail and has not yet returned to Russia.

Gazprom yesterday declared Media Most in default on its $211m owed to the gas giant and said it would sue.

The general prosecutor's office said it may open a criminal investigation into Mr Gusinsky for alleged asset-stripping and allegedly transferring company assets to Gibraltar.

fields.headline: Vauxhall rethinks £8m Cogent account
fields.trailText: Network Q, Vauxhall Motors' used car dealer network, is reviewing its £8m advertising account out of Cogent.
fields.body:
Network Q, Vauxhall Motors' used car dealer network, is reviewing its £8m advertising account out of Cogent.

Cogent has handled advertising for the brand since it was created by Vauxhall in 1990 and currently handles all above-the-line activity including radio, press, poster and TV.

Sources close to the review say that Lowe Lintas & Partners, Vauxhall's lead UK agency, is likely to pick up the business following its recent acquisition of the car manufacturer's £7m vans business.

Lowe's acquired more Vauxhall business earlier in the year when it bought the Broadway agency, now Lowe Broadway, which handled the Masterfit and Network Q servicing accounts.

In the 12 months to May Vauxhall was the second largest advertising spender in the car sector after Renault at £59.4 million.

fields.headline: BSkyB/A&E launch Biography Channel
fields.trailText: BSkyB and Hearst-owned A&E Networks are launching a channel devoted to biographies of the famous. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
BSkyB and Hearst-owned A&E Networks are launching a channel devoted to biographies of the famous.

Launching on Sky Digital next month, the Biography Channel will rely largely on reformatted content from the US, although it is in talks with the BBC and Granada about acquiring content.

Biographies lined up include Paul McCartney, Mick Jagger, Ella Fitzgerald, Pele and Bill Gates.

webTitle: Radio Times in talks with TiVO

fields.headline: Radio Times eyes TiVO partnership
fields.trailText: The Radio Times is understood to be in talks with personal video technology manufacturers TiVO and Replay about setting up strategic partnerships. Any tie-ups would give the Radio Times brand prominence when the technology launches in the UK.
fields.body:
The Radio Times is understood to be in talks with personal video technology manufacturers TiVO and Replay about setting up strategic partnerships. Any tie-ups would give the Radio Times brand prominence when the technology launches in the UK.

Personal video recorders, which allow users to programme their machines to record and store up to 30 hours of programming, are being touted as the end of schedule-based television and, ultimately, the listings magazine.

Both BSkyB and the BBC have announced partnerships with TiVO, designed to maximise their brand impact in time for the launch.

The Radio Times, in a similar pattern to other established listings magazines such as TV Times and What's On TV, has seen its sales decline 10% year on year. Paid-for listings magazines have come under threat from the free magazines given away with pay-TV, including Skyview, Sky Digital Customer and Cable Guide.

Broadcasters are also desperate to increase their visibility on platforms like TiVO and Replay, and the BBC is understood to be looking at ways to use the Radio Times brand and content to draw viewers into using BBC programming.

It is understood that an editorial repositioning of the Radio Times - with more emphasis on features and less on listings - is being considered.

The Radio Times was unavailable for comment.

webTitle: Guardian draws up shortlist for advertising account

fields.headline: Six to pitch for Guardian account
fields.trailText: The Guardian has drawn up a shortlist of six agencies to pitch for its prestigious advertising account, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The Guardian has drawn up a shortlist of six agencies to pitch for its prestigious advertising account after the incumbent Partners BDDH declined to repitch for the business.

BMP DDB, Fallon, HHCL & Partners, Mother, Publicis and M&C Saatchi will all pitch for the account, which includes the Guardian Unlimited websites. Guardian Newspapers spent £3.5m on advertising last year, according to ACNielsen/MMS.

Marc Sands, marketing director at Guardian Newspapers, said: "The strength of the Guardian's brand means that it offers huge potential for a creative agency and we anticipate some exciting pitches. The role of newspapers is rapidly evolving which, coupled with the success of Guardian Unlimited, makes this a great time to take a new look at what the Guardian brand represents and how it is executed across many platforms."

Sands joined Guardian in May from ONdigital.

webTitle: Saturday night TV a turn-off as viewers desert top shows

fields.headline: Saturday night TV a turn-off as viewers desert top shows
fields.trailText: Once Bruce Forsyth could unite the nation by wheeling out a few tired comedians and a rock star or two at the London Palladium. But the days when 20m viewers would tune in for a prime time entertainment fix are gone for good, and broadcasters are struggling to find new Saturday night hits.
fields.body:
Once Bruce Forsyth could unite the nation by wheeling out a few tired comedians and a rock star or two at the London Palladium. But the days when 20m viewers would tune in for a prime time entertainment fix are gone for good, and broadcasters are struggling to find new Saturday night hits.

According to an analysis of viewing figures, programmes such as Blind Date and Big Break have lost up to half of their audiences in seven years. Viewers are deserting traditional broadcasters for the specialised offerings of pay TV channels.

Shows like Noel's House Party and Surprise Surprise have been axed due to falling ratings, while niche broadcasters such as UK Gold and Paramount Comedy are becoming increasingly popular in homes with access to multi-channel TV. According to the media research firm Human Capital, audiences for the top 10 mainstream entertainment shows fell from an average of 16.8m in 1992 to 11.5m last year. Children are leading the flight to multi-channel TV: more than half their entertainment viewing comes from pay TV broadcasters.

In 1992, the top entertainment show was ITV's It'll be Alright on the Night, with almost 20m viewers. More Auntie's Bloomers was the BBC's highest rated entertainment show, gaining 18.5m. Barrymore, at number 10, scored almost 15m viewers for ITV.

Seven years later the picture has changed considerably. The top rated shows are still from ITV, but the headline figures are much lower. Who Wants to be a Millionaire? rated almost 16m, but six out of the top 10 programmes netted between 10m and 11m viewers, far lower than the 15m to 18m of seven years previously.

The researchers identify Millionaire as an "awe inspiring breakthrough", but warn that its future success is by no means guaranteed. "One Millionaire does not revive a mainstream," they say.

Danielle Lux, controller of entertainment commissioning at the BBC, said yesterday that programmes such as Millionaire and Big Brother showed there was still a big audience for entertainment, but that viewers' tastes had changed. "What people are interested in are emotions and stories. What people follow in Big Brother and Millionaire are the participants' emotional twists and turns."

ITV said yesterday that while overall audiences were in decline, its top shows were maintaining their share of viewers. In 1992, Blind Date achieved a 51% share of the audience, which had slipped only to 46% last year. Stars in Their Eyes gained 52% of the available audience this year, the same as in 1992.

fields.headline: Gender stereotypes still hamper young
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Adolescents are still unable to shake off gender stereotypes that appear as entrenched as ever, a report by the government's Women's Unit reveals.
fields.body:
Adolescents are still unable to shake off gender stereotypes that appear as entrenched as ever, a report by the government's Women's Unit reveals.

After a wave of anxiety about the underperformance of boys at school, the analysis, commissioned by the Cabinet Office and the Home Office, says that across adolescence both genders require different but equal attention from policy-makers.

Inside, outside and beyond school, young men and women are under continuing pressure to conform to traditional behaviour.

At school, women avoid physics and information technology and choose English, biology, history and modern languages. "Young women find it easier to ask for help than young men, who find it harder to admit a lack of knowledge," the report, Young People and Gender, published yesterday, says.

Boys are more likely to break the law - a gap which extends after the age of 14 - or be involved in crime, alcohol abuse and illegal drugs.

Girls, who are more likely to be concerned about their body image and weight, are much more likely to start smoking. Suicide rates are higher for men and double the number of boys die at 17. Boys are less likely to visit their GP or to use other health services.

Girls are more at risk of depression, eating disorders and self-harm. Boys "use active methods of coping, but also use much more denial than girls".

Boys "take greater risks and feel greater pressure" to be sexually active and find it harder to admit inexperience. But "in spite of the notion of 'girl power', young women still find it problematic to say no to sex and negotiate the use of contraception", the report says.

At work, young men are more likely to want managerial or professional jobs - 75% compared with 25% for women, who are concentrated in personal service industries with part-time jobs and lower wages. "The need to conform to masculine stereo types prevents young men from joining traditionally female careers."

Although more young men are officially unemployed, a large group of young women remains outside employment, education and training opportunities because of caring responsibilities.

Tessa Jowell, minister for women and employment, said: "All young people face different pressures as they meet the challenges of the 21st century. This research underlines how important gender is to young people's behaviour, their relationships and their level of achievement."

The research emerges from a review, the Trust for the Study of Adolescence, commissioned by the women's unit in the Cabinet Office and the Home Office's family policy unit. The government has appointed a minister for young people, Paul Boateng.

This year, after years of outperforming boys at GCSE and most A-levels in England, Wales and Northern Ireland, girls won more A grades at A-level for the first time, provoking a spate of hand-wringing. David Blunkett, the education secretary, has promised to look at whether single-sex lessons help boys' achievement, though he is far from certain that they do.

But the report warns of the dangers of ignoring under-achieving girls. "At different times in the past decades public anxiety has focused on one or more of the genders, but it needs to be recognised that both young women and men may be vulnerable in different ways," it says.

"The central conclusion of this review is that it would be wrong to identify either males or females as being more in need of attention from policy-makers. Both genders have areas of their lives in which they may be at risk."

Although more young men are officially unemployed, a large group of young women remains outside employment, education and training opportunities because of caring responsibilities. This research underlines how important gender is to young people's behaviour, their relationships and their level of achievement." The research emerges from a review, the Trust for the Study of Adolescence, commissioned by the women's unit in the Cabinet Office and the Home Office's family policy unit. The government has appointed a minister for young people, Paul Boateng. This year, after years of outperforming boys at GCSE and most A-levels in England, Wales and Northern Ireland, girls won more A grades at A-level for the first time, provoking a spate of hand-wringing. But the report warns of the dangers of ignoring under-achieving girls. "At different times in the past decades public anxiety has focused on one or more of the genders, but it needs to be recognised that both young women and men may be vulnerable in different ways," it says. "The central conclusion of this review is that it would be wrong to identify either males or females as being more in need of attention from policy-makers. webTitle: Words fail Italians, so they import English ones

fields.headline: Words fail Italians, so they import English ones
fields.trailText: Italy's lawmakers will meet today to try to halt the wave of English words which are infiltrating Italian dictionaries in record numbers.
fields.body:
Italy's lawmakers will meet today to try to halt the wave of English words which are infiltrating Italian dictionaries in record numbers.

More than 4,000 foreign words and phrases are included in the latest Devoto-Oli dictionary of the Italian language, renewing fears of cultural attack.

Entries such as "outing", "question time", "mobbing", "transgender", "carbon tax", "new economy", "friendly" and "blockbuster" are infuriating politicians and intellectuals.

A cross-party group of deputies will meet in parliament to discuss why Italian translations could not have been found.

The new entries bring the number of foreign words and expressions to an unprecedented 4% of the total.

Critics complain that existing Italian words were being displaced and that not enough effort was being made to coin new ones.

Conversations, advertisements and manuals are routinely peppered with "last minute", "call centre", "chat-line", "newsgroup", "grunge", "megastore", "new age", "piercing", "squatter" and "vintage".

The popularity of transatlantic sport and entertainment is blamed for "fusion", "infotainment" and "unplugged".

Vittorio Sermonti, an authority on the medieval writer Dante, told La Repubblica that he objected to "contamination" when Italian words were dumped in the name of modernity.

High street barbers that replaced parrucchiere in favour of "hair dresser" made him want to scream. "I think the moment has arrived to put an end to this excess. It is really too much," Mr Sermonti said.

Foreign words in new editions of two other dictionaries, Lo Zingarelli and De Mauro, respectively amount to 2% and 3% of the total. Around two thirds of the foreign expressions are English.

Campaigners have also expressed concern about the impact of excessively literal translations of English phrases, which distort Italian syntax and deprive the language of its nuances.

The Italian parliament has unsuccessfully tried to limit the spread of English twice since 1997 but politicians have been accused of exacerbating the problem in their efforts to sound hip. At its last convention the ruling Democratic Left party adopted the slogan "We care".

webTitle: Botticelli's drawings of Dante poem gathered in Rome

fields.headline: Botticelli's drawings of Dante poem gathered in Rome
fields.trailText: A spectacular collection of 92 Botticelli drawings illustrating Dante's The Divine Comedy, assembled as a cycle for the first time in five centuries, has returned to Italy.
fields.body:
A spectacular collection of 92 Botticelli drawings illustrating Dante's The Divine Comedy, assembled as a cycle for the first time in five centuries, has returned to Italy.

Hailed as one of the great unknown monuments of the Italian Renaissance, the drawings went on display in Rome yesterday after being tracked down to different corners of Europe.

War, greed and national rivalry dispersed the drawings, which yesterday drew gasps at their depictions of grotesque torture and torment. The Royal Academy predicted that the exhibition, which originated in Berlin earlier this year, would cause a sensation when it transfers to London next March.

The Medici family commissioned Sandro Botticelli (1445-1510) in 1480 to illustrate the entire Divine Comedy, written 200 years earlier by Dante Alighieri.

Drawing with a lead stylus on large sheets of parchment made from sheepskin, each representing one canto, or section, Botticelli worked night and day to produce a total of 100 drawings.

He completed the designs in ink - some in red, green and blue - but many are unfinished or badly faded.

Dante's poem described his epic journey from the underworld of the inferno to purgatory and paradise, guided by the poet Virgil, Lucifer or his idealised love, Beatrice.

Seducers, sodomites, forgers, adulterers, corrupt politicians and the prophet Mohammed are shown writhing in agony. Horrors include being boiled in pitch, imprisoned in a flaming tomb, having one's head twisted backwards and being buried up to the neck in ice or excrement.

The Florentine artist's chief patron, Lorenzo di Pierfrancesco de' Medici, who also commissioned The Birth of Venus and Primavera, is thought to have kept the drawings in his library, possibly to show guests during private readings of Dante.

Mystery shrouds Botticelli's failure to complete the work, and why it was broken up shortly afterwards.

A faction of the Medici family is suspected of having passed the sketches to Paris after the French invaded Italy in 1494. Some surfaced in 1658 when they were bought from a Parisian bibliophile by Queen Christina of Sweden. On her death her nephew, a cardinal, passed eight to the Vatican, where they remained.

Another eight were lost but 82 ended up in the hands of the Dukes of Hamilton, who kept them in Scotland and put them up for auction, bound in a volume, at Sotheby's in 1882.

British art critics were incandescent when Germany's Kaiser, galvanised by his advisers, acquired them for Berlin's Kupferstichkabinett gallery before the public auction.

After the second world war, the 84 drawings were split between east and west Berlin.

Italian and German scholars persuaded Berlin and the Vatican to release the drawings for the current exhibition at the newly restored Papal Stables in Rome's Quirinale palace, the residence of Italy's president. It runs until December 3.

Art experts have compared the effect of the drawings together to an animated film, with Botticelli's use of light and movement very different from The Birth of Venus.

The artist took Dante's text literally and translated the narrative into images. Each of the hundreds of small figures has an individual face expressing torment, fear, hope or elation.

Former friends of the artist are included in the damned and do not proceed beyond the fires. Those who do, encounter a river of light to paradise, where angels, the Virgin Mary and Jesus, portrayed as a sun god, await.

Norman Rosenthal, the Royal Academy's exhibitions secretary, said the work was one of the greatest monuments to the Renaissance.

webTitle: Sense of crisis as Labour's worries  grow

fields.headline: Sense of crisis as Labour's worries  grow
fields.standfirst:
In the bunker
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Fear that poll setback is more than a blip after Ecclestone affair darkens mood
fields.body:
Already shell-shocked by the petrol crisis that had brought the country close to paralysis, ministers were braced for a hit in the weekend polls. None, however, had foreseen the scale of the turnaround, or that the position would worsen on Monday night with the Guardian's ICM poll. One minister said: "The public is incredibly difficult to read at the moment. We seem to be going through one of those collective outpourings."

Tony Blair's aides yesterday tried to protect the prime minister from the sense of crisis, leaving him alone as much as possible at Chequers to focus on writing next week's conference speech, probably his most important since he became leader six years ago.

But the political atmosphere worsened with the claims in a book by the journalist Andrew Rawnsley that Mr Blair and the chancellor, Gordon Brown, had lied over their handling of the Ecclestone affair.

Margaret Beckett, the leader of the house, was wheeled out to discuss the fuel crisis and the Guardian poll on Radio 4's Today programme, only to find herself being questioned over the Rawnsley allegations.

She claimed she knew nothing of the claims and had not read the newspapers, dismissing the affair as an old story.

As the day wore on, Labour's rebuttal team worked on knocking down the Rawnsley allegations point by point, producing detailed transcripts and original letters, and challenging the veracity of his unsourced quotes.

But inside the beleaguered Treasury, the mood darkened as Mr Brown recognised he had to admit he had discussed the Ecclestone donations with the prime minister. Meanwhile, at yesterday's meeting of Labour's national executive committee, anxious members expressed concern that the sudden reversal in the opinion polls is not just a short-term blip.

The warnings did not just come from the usual leftwingers, such as Dennis Skinner and Mark Seddon, the editor of Tribune. They also came from normally loyalist union stalwarts, such as Diana Jeudah from the shopworkers' union Usdaw, Jeremy Beecham, Labour's senior figure in local government, and Derek Hodgson, general secretary of the Communication Workers' Union.

The party leadership was told bluntly that last week's crisis over fuel revealed a gathering disaffection with the government on other issues, including pensions. Mr Skinner argued passionately that an announcement restoring the pensions link with earnings would change the climate. He warned that some of the party's difficulties stemmed from the perception that "this government is still sitting on a war chest which makes contending groups in society believe there is money to be had".

Overall, the NEC members made it clear that if extra cash is to be dispensed the priority has to be pensioners rather than cuts in fuel duty.

However, inside Downing Street there is equal alarm about fuel duties. Ministers are seriously at odds over how to make concessions on duties and the speed with which they need to be made. With the Conservatives today set to announce a proposed specific cut in fuel duty and the Liberal Democrats already pledged to a five-year freeze, the government is in danger of being left behind. There is also a fear that if the government digs in its heels, only to make concessions later, William HagueÕs current fragile poll lead might harden, and even grow.

"The longer we delay the inevitable the worse it will be for us, one participant said. One proposal being floated yesterday was for the chancellor to make a clear indication, perhaps in November, that he will cut petrol duties in the Budget in March if oil prices do not fall substantially.

But some Labour MPs with a European perspective were also pointing to the dangers of concessions. They point to the salutary lesson of the French socialist prime minister, Lionel Jospin.

Mr Jospin is still being punished by his electorate, even though he bowed to the demands of the farmers and truck drivers.

In the long term, it is argued, Mr Blair will benefit from being seen to stick to his principles. These views, naturally enough, are most strongly heard inside the Treasury and some of the big spending departments. The chancellor would like to use next week's conference as the moment in which to launch the fightback and open a challenging debate on the funding of public services.

However, this is partly a matter of striking the right tone. Mr Brown feels passionately he is right and that, at the same time, he is upholding the democratic process by insisting he will not make changes outside the budget cycle.

Downing Street is now trying to reopen lines of communication with the established road haulage groups such as the Road Haulage Association and the Freight Transport Association.

David Green, the director general of the FTA, met the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, last week and will meet transport ministers again tomorrow.

Mr Blair's aides know he needs to do more to highlight the international nature of the oil crisis. He needs to be able to show that this is a crisis made in Opec, and not in Downing Street.

Paradoxically, the international rise in the price of oil will increase the anger of the truckers, but reduce Mr Blair's personal responsibility. With protests breaking out all over Europe, the European commission has called an emergency meeting of European transport ministers.

There are also fears that Iraq will use the crisis to cut back production, or even provoke another military confrontation with Kuwait. Iraq exports about 2.3m barrels a day of crude oil into a world market desperate to cut prices.

A cutback by Iraq could push the price up to $40 a barrel. If that happens, Mr Blair's current problems would be dwarfed.

webTitle: 'There is no doubt Tony has lost a lot of ground'

fields.headline: 'There is no doubt Tony has lost a lot of ground'
fields.standfirst:
The marginal
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Precarious majority in jeopardy
fields.body:
He has braved the wrath of restless middle England at public meetings, fielded scores of critical phone calls, answered umpteen protest letters and emails.

But at least one bastion appeared secure. Then the faithful started to rebel in Lancaster and Wyre. "People said to me straightfaced, I am a Labour supporter and think you personally are doing a good job but the government has blown it and I'm not going to vote for it again".

Sitting on a precarious 1,295 majority, Hilton Dawson had used his distinctly independent streak to construct a Blairite consensus between the party's traditional supporters and 1997 converts.

But in the space of a long week, the mood has changed dramatically. "People were feeling better off, and there was a genuine mood of optimism Ñ even from those who voted Tory last time Ñ about the state of the economy," says Mr Dawson. "There is no doubt Tony has lost a lot of ground. We need a common sense approach that treats people not as enemies of the state but as people with legitimate grievances ... they feel he has misread the situation."

He has just left a large public meeting, in Poulton-le-Fylde, to discuss local housing developments rather than the fuel crisis. Although there are calls to keep party politics out of the debate, it is clear that some are restless.

Outside, there is talk of the fuel row being "Blair's poll tax" and of an arrogant prime minister considered out of touch. But among Tory voters there is enough criticism of an "opportunistic" William Hague to suggest that the four point Tory lead in yesterday's Guardian ICM poll might be a temporary phenomenon. "Put someone else in charge of the Tories and they might be well ahead of Blair," says Teri, a personnel officer with BAe systems, a large local employer.

"The Tories need a statesman," chips in Linda, a civil servant with the Department of Social Security. Lynne, who works in a travel agency, thinks the country is gripped with a collective hysteria. "It will all be forgotten soon."

Another woman says: "Labour were right to say they will not cut taxes immediately, but Gordon Brown has just made things worse by taking such a strong line."

Richard Anyon, leader of a Labour group on the local council which lost control to Tories last year, goes along with some of those sentiments. "Blair had no option but to tough it out but perhaps he should have made clear they were examining taxation in the light of public anger", he says.

Mr Anyon, a union convener at BNFL in Lancashire, fears the tide might be turning against Labour. "The swingometer is moving to the Tories and there will be a lasting impact after last week ... but Labour should get back, although it could be a lot tighter."

That is small comfort to Mr Dawson, a former social work manager and one-time councillor in Lancaster. He fears that ministers, from Jack Straw to Gordon Brown, are compounding his own political crisis by alienating voters further with tough talk.

He is now blitzing the constituency with leaflets headed "Supporting Rural Britain", saying that his government has helped expand rural bus services while putting more money into agriculture and defending post offices. "At the moment, things are extremely difficult," says Mr Dawson, who has written to Tony Blair urging him to recognise the strength of the protesters. "It is all very well for the chancellor to characterise protesters as "no more than 2,000 pickets holding the country to ransom" but I have no doubt that the vast majority of my constituents support them... some of these belligerent statements [from ministers] are going down very badly indeed."

Danny Lockwood, editor of the Lancaster Guardian, thinks the government could redeem itself by simply saying "sorry, we misjudged the public mood". Whether this will be enough to save Lancaster and Wyre, and a string of other marginals which delivered Labour more rural MPs than the Tories three years ago, is another matter.
