"I was sitting in my shop when the explosion went off. There were injured people everywhere," said Shahid Hussain Abbasi, who runs a grocery close to the scene. "It was a very crowded area, it is like this every morning. Many trucks were being unloaded. And there were just pools of blood, many people had leg injuries." Police said the truck arrived overnight on a routine delivery from the lawless tribal areas near the Afghan border. The driver, who was asleep in the cabin at the time of the blast, and his assistant were unhurt and were being held for questioning. Police and soldiers briefly cordoned off the blackened patch of ground and impounded the truck. Then officers with sticks rounded up Afghan street-children and made them collect sandals and scraps of clothes from the ground and load them into a van. Two boys were made to scoop up the human remains and carry them away in one of the fruit crates. No group claimed responsibility for the blast. "It is an act of terrorism," said Nasir Khan Durrani, the head of Islamabad police. "There has been a series of bomb blasts in Punjab and elsewhere to terrorise the population and it appears to be a link in the same chain." Last month police in Lahore arrested eight men and paraded them in front of television cameras, saying they had confessed to working for Indian intelligence and planting 10 bombs over four years. No evidence was given to support the claim and most observers said the men were more likely to be simply petty smugglers.

webTitle: Amnesty attacks Labour record on asylum and arms trade curbs

fields.headline: Amnesty attacks Labour record on asylum and arms trade curbs
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Labour's ethical foreign policy
Special report: refugees in Britain
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The government is heavily criticised for its policies on the arms trade and asylum in a report published today by the human rights group Amnesty International.
fields.body:
The government is heavily criticised for its policies on the arms trade and asylum in a report published today by the human rights group Amnesty International.

The 75-page review of the government's first three years in office praised many foreign policy achievements, but was scathing about the government's failure to curb the arms trade, and described its asylum policy as shambolic.

The report identified a lack of consistency across Whitehall. "The UK rightly criticises the appalling human rights abuses in countries such as Iraq, Afghanistan, Somalia and the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, but then fails to respect the human rights of refugees from those countries that seek protection here."

It said that the UK played an important diplomatic role in seeking to prevent or resolve conflicts abroad, "but then fails to control the activities of British brokers who ship arms to those countries where they may be used to commit abuse".

The report added: "Even when a consensus has developed within the government, such as with the need to introduce legislation to control arms brokering, the political will to take it forward appears to be absent."

A bill to control the arms trade, which the Foreign Office and the Department of Trade and Industry had been pushing for inclusion in the Queen's speech in November, has been dropped. Kate Allen, director of Amnesty International UK, said the government still had outstanding commitments to introduce legislation, including control of "the terrible trade" in arms.

"What is needed now is personal commitment from the prime minister to drive through these areas of unfinished business before the general election."

The government's approach to the arms trade was a central theme of the report: "Time and again over the last three years, the export of British arms to destinations such as Indonesia and Zimbabwe has sparked serious public concern."

On the positive side, the report welcomed the government's speedy response in providing support for UN forces in Sierra Leone this year; its work in promoting abolition of the death penalty; and the day to day work to support human rights overseas by many of Britain's diplomatic missions.

But Amnesty added asylum policy to the list of negatives, particularly the extension of pre-entry controls to prevent asylum seekers entering the UK. The report said: "The government inherited a shambles from the Tories three years ago and has now created one of its own."

It was sceptical about the government's commitment to pursuing human rights with countries such as China, Russia and Saudi Arabia and was unhappy with the muted government response in the face of widespread violations in these countries. Amnesty believed that the value of British engagement in such countries should be measured by practical results.

On China, the report said: "The UK government statements have not always acknowledged or adequately reflected the deterioration in human rights in China over the last 18 months ... as far as human rights are concerned, it appears that the UK is playing a game on terms set in Beijing."

A Foreign Office spokesman described the report as a serious analysis that recognised the government's achievements: "This is a record of which we can be proud, without claiming to have achieved all that we want to achieve."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Nuclear protest pair cleared
fields.body:
Nuclear protest pair cleared

Two protesters who spray painted peace slogans on a nuclear submarine in Barrow-in-Furness, Cumbria, were yesterday cleared at Manchester crown court of criminal damage. Rachel Wenham, 28, from Leeds, and Rosie James, 25, from London, still face a second charge of criminal damage.

Big Brother boost for fund

Big Brother producers yesterday pledged to match the £70,000 donation from the show's winner, Craig Phillips, to help fund a heart and lung operation in the US for teenager Joanne Harris.

European court blow to father

Maric Glaser, 54, a divorced father from south London, who claimed that the courts had breached his right to family life in failing to force his former wife to let him see his children lost his case at the European court of human rights in Strasbourg yesterday.

Forsyth saga published on net

Best-selling author Frederick Forsyth will have his next book, Quintet, published exclusively on the internet next month.

Workmen die in fall

Two workmen died yesterday after falling from scaffolding at an office block in Sheffield. Both were from the Leeds area.

fields.headline: Bankable art
fields.standfirst: Rembrandt portrait in Rothschild sale may draw record bid
fields.trailText: A glowing Rembrandt portrait of an unknown elderly woman and other old masters from the art collection of the Rothschild banking family are expected to fetch up to £15m at Christie's in London in December.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
A glowing Rembrandt portrait of an unknown elderly woman and other old masters from the art collection of the Rothschild banking family are expected to fetch up to £15m at Christie's in London in December.

The Rothschild art, including hundreds of pieces from every royal collection in Europe, was the prime target of Nazi looters when they invaded France. Almost 4,000 pieces were recorded in the Nazi inventory. Most of the collection was recovered by the Allies, and a huge exhibition was held in Paris in 1946, including many of the pieces in the Christie's auction.

The Rembrandt is undoubtedly the star, being regarded as the best such to come on the art market in years, but the sale will include two small paintings by Watteau which are even rarer, believed to be among the last privately owned: they have not been seen in public since the 1946 exhibition. Other works include two Fragonards, jewellery and Venetian and Islamic glass.

"It's hard to predict what the Rembrandt will fetch, but it is a quite outstanding piece, and nothing like it has been sold recently," David Llewellyn, director of Christie's, said yesterday.

The estimate is £6m, which would break the world record of£5m set at a Sotheby's auction in New York 10 years ago.

The collection is from the estate of Bathsheva de Rothschild, patron of contemporary dance, art and science and a member of the French branch of the family. She died last year in Tel Aviv.

The works, a fraction of the main Rothschild collection, came from her grandfather, Alphonse, a 19th century collector.

webTitle: Bush turns to drink in ordeal by Oprah

fields.headline: Bush turns to drink in ordeal by Oprah
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Just 24 hours after he supposedly switched his campaign against Al Gore to focus on the big political issues, George W Bush found himself making strictly personal headlines again yesterday about his battle with the bottle and the things he said at a meeting with the Queen.
fields.body:
Just 24 hours after he supposedly switched his campaign against Al Gore to focus on the big political issues, George W Bush found himself making strictly personal headlines again yesterday about his battle with the bottle and the things he said at a meeting with the Queen.

In what has now become an obligatory stop on the White House campaign trail, the Republican presidential candidate went cautiously confessional about his past in a Chicago interview with the television talkshow host Oprah Winfrey.

"Alcohol was beginning to compete for my affections - for my wife and my family," Mr Bush told the studio audience. "It was beginning to crowd out my energy and I decided to quit, and it's one of the best decisions I've ever made."

Mr Bush's former drinking problem has never been a secret, but this was the first time he had talked about it in any detail during this stage of the campaign.

Though Mr Bush purports to enjoy the Oprah Winfrey "touchy-feely" style of interview, the encounter compelled him to tread a fine line between giving too much away about his closely guarded past excesses, while wooing the show's largely female audience by presenting himself as a redeemed sinner who had given up the booze for the sake of his wife and children.

The Republican candidate neither confirmed nor denied that his wife, Laura, had threatened to leave him at the height of his drinking days, which came to an end more than 14 years ago after he went on one last bender in Colorado with a bunch of friends to mark their 40th birthdays.

"There's a lot of speculation," Mr Bush admitted, while referring to rumours that his wife had told him, "It's either you or Jack Daniels".

"I think she got disappointed some evenings. I was always a fairly disciplined person. I wasn't drinking all the time, but there were some times when she said you need to think about what you're doing. She understood it requires the person involved to make up their own mind," Mr Bush said.

Earlier, Mr Bush was asked what he was referring to when he said, during his acceptance speech at the Republican convention last month, that there was a time when he had "needed forgiveness".

"When my heart turns dark, when I am jealous or when I'm spiteful," Mr Bush replied after a pause.

"I'm looking for specifics," Winfrey said in reply.

"I know you are, but I'm running for president," Mr Bush responded with a laugh.

In submitting himself to ordeal by Oprah, the Republican candidate was following in the footsteps of Mr Gore, who appeared on the same show last week.

Such prime-time interviews - along with campaign appearances by the candidates on the rival Jay Leno and David Letterman late night chatshows - have become an essential part of the US presidential campaign timetable, as the rivals seek to humanise themselves and to reach swing voters who would not dream of watching a more formal debate or political discussion programme.

If they handle such appearances well, the candidates do not just reach out to the shows' target audiences, but also receive hours of "free media", as the clips from their interviews are replayed on other channels and news bulletins.

Mr Gore was particularly successful in this respect last week when he made fun of himself on the Letterman show. Among the slogans that the Democratic candidate said he was contemplating using in the campaign were, "Vote for me - or I will come round to your house and explain my 200-page economic plan in excruciating detail" and, "I gave you the internet, America, and I can take it back".

Mr Bush has looked nervous when he has gone on such programmes in the past, but he gave a more confident, if not entirely relaxed, performance on the Oprah show. There was only one of the now legendary "Bushisms", when the candidate said that he was someone who "recognises the fallacy of humans".

During the hour-long interview - which was interrupted at one point by a protester complaining about US policy towards Iraq - Mr Bush was asked about the claim that he once told the Queen, at a dinner hosted by his father, that he was "the black sheep" of the Bush family.

"The Queen said, 'Are you the black sheep of the family?' I said, 'I don't know, do you have any in your family?' Like a good mother, she gave me a look," Mr Bush recalled.

"I respect the Queen a lot," he continued. "I don't know what she thinks about me."

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone has been rather quiet since his election triumph. But behind the scenes big issues are being dealt with - and few literally come bigger than who presides over the switching on of lights on the famous Christmas tree in Trafalgar Square.
fields.body:
 Ken Livingstone has been rather quiet since his election triumph. But behind the scenes big issues are being dealt with - and few literally come bigger than who presides over the switching on of lights on the famous Christmas tree in Trafalgar Square. The tree (donated by a grateful Norway for Britain's efforts in the second world war) has traditionally been lit by the mayor of Oslo, with the Lord Mayor of Westminster in attendance. But in October responsibility for Trafalgar Square passes from the Department of Culture, Media and Sport to the mayor of London's office, and Ken wanted a cut of the tree action. "The Lord Mayor can go to Norway and watch the thing being cut down if he wants, but Ken's going to switch it on. He is the mayor of London," one of Ken's aides was heard to say. Top-level talks last week between Westminster's lord mayor Michael Brahams and Ken led to a compromise, with the DCMS organising this year's festivities for one last time. "Ken is going to be there as well," says press officer Helen Hall-Wright.

 We can sleep easier now the government is dealing with the threat of the earth being destroyed by asteroids. But what is being done about killer robots and giant mutant lizards? We rang the Number 10 press office to demand action on the robot-lizard threat, only to be fobbed off to the Cabinet Office. "Oh, this came up yesterday," said a press officer, who suggested we try the DTI. "Good God, I've got no idea," said Mark Haliford, the DTI's press officer for potentially hazardous near earth export commodities, "I'm trying to think, is this really a matter for the department?" Of course it is, Mark. "Is there any evidence of these lizards, I mean asteroids, have actually hit the earth?" Mark asks. That petty empirical view won't help, Mark.

 At least one transport company bucked the trend and froze its prices this year, in spite of "above average increases in fuel tax". It's the Government Car and Despatch Agency, which provides "a high quality, secure environment in which ministers and others in public life can travel safely and in comfort, allowing them to concentrate on their work."

 Michela Wrong's new book In the Footsteps of Mr Kurtz (Fourth Estate, £14) recounts some extraordinary tales of excess by Zaire's President Mobutu, funded in the main by the IMF and the World Bank. In his later years Mobutu retreated to a Xanadu-style folie de grandeur, complete with orange groves, musical fountains and imported Swiss cattle. But for visiting dignitaries, forced to travel 700 miles from Kinshasa, the worst part was being taken for a drive in the presidential Chevrolet. One US official found himself clinging on for his life as Mobutu careered along. "It was like a cartoon, people and things were leaping out of the way," said the official. When his guests made mild remonstrations, the dictator replied: "It's OK, these are all my roads."

 I'm grateful to my so-called rivals at The Register website for the charming tale of David Watkins, who wrote to BT complaining about poor service. BT replied: "Dear Mr Watkins, I sincerely apologise for any incontinence caused over the last few weeks."

 This is, I am told, a true story, and since it was told to me by a man in a pub who read it on an email, who could doubt it? It involves a businessman waiting to meet a client in an airport VIP lounge. He spots Bill Gates sitting alone, and introduces himself. "Could I ask a small favour?" he says to Gates. "I'm waiting for someone and when he arrives I'd be grateful if you could walk by, tap me on the shoulder and say hello." Bill graciously agrees, and when the client arrives, Bill taps the first man on the shoulder and says "Hi!" The man turns around and snarls: "F*** off Gates, can't you see I'm busy!"

webTitle: Poll reform leaves French voters cold

fields.headline: Poll reform leaves French voters cold
fields.trailText: France holds its first referendum in nearly a decade on Sunday, amid massive popular indifference to an issue most French voters see as irrelevant: the length of time their president spends in office.
fields.body:
France holds its first referendum in nearly a decade on Sunday, amid massive popular indifference to an issue most French voters see as irrelevant: the length of time their president spends in office.

At a pro-reform Socialist party meeting in Paris last night, the embattled prime minister, Lionel Jospin, made a brave attempt to interest the record 64% of the electorate who have said that they will not bother to cast their ballot.

He said that the constitutional reform that will reduce the presidential term to five years from seven "may not be the first preoccupation of the French people", but is nonetheless important for the country's future.

Both Mr Jospin and the conservative president, Jacques Chirac, back the change because in theory it will reduce the chance of uncomfortable "cohabitations" between governments and presidents from opposing parties that effectively block all major reform.

But with a yes vote virtually guaranteed and both main parties agreed on the advantages of the shorter term, which would come into force after parliamentary and presidential elections scheduled for 2002, the campaigning is lacklustre, with electoral enthusiasm all but non-existent.

Only the rebel Gaullist Charles Pasqua, a former interior minister, and small far-right and far-left parties have been campaigning against the reform.

But matters have not been helped by 250 mayors who are threatening not to organise the vote in their districts in protest at the government's failure to solve such local problems as the extension of a rubbish dump, the closure of a maternity wing and the route of a projected motorway.

Although nearly 80% of those who plan to vote say they will cast their ballot in favour of the reform, only 36% of eligible voters in a recent poll said they expected to turn out. The figure is down even on the record low of 37% which launched New Caledonia on the road to independence in a 1988 referendum, and nowhere near the turnout for France's last referendum, on the Maastricht treaty, in 1992.

Several politicians have said such a turnout would be a blow to French democracy. "If the turnout is indeed as low as forecast, it will be our democracy as a whole that will suffer," said a leading Socialist, Henri Weber. "What head of state will dare call a referendum in the future?"

Pollsters say the low turn-out reflects the feelings of most French people that there are more important issues facing the country: soaring fuel prices, which led to this month's crippling blockade of depots, and controversial plans to give limited autonomy to Corsica, which have prompted the resignation of the interior minister.

Mr Jospin, whose approval rating has plummeted by 20% since the fuel crisis, is expected within the next few days to announce some form of voter-friendly tax scheme intended to help offset sky-high petrol prices.

fields.headline: Married to the job
fields.standfirst:
They are no Hillary Clintons. Cast as homey housewives and mothers with no interest in politics, they are ready to stand by their men (and be kissed by them in public when necessary). But Americans can't get enough of Laura Bush and Tipper Gore - who could decide the outcome of the race to the White House. Katie Roiphe on the rival first ladies in waiting

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Americans can't get enough of Laura Bush and Tipper Gore - who could decide the outcome of the race to the White House.  Katie Roiphe on the rival first ladies in waiting.
fields.body:
Political wives have never been so fascinating, or so it would seem from the amount of attention they have been getting in the US. The Democratic and Republican conventions have been packed with an unprecedented number of testimonials and introductions and cute jokes and homey anecdotes from wives and daughters, not as background, but as a central part of the campaign: elect this man, the message seemed to be, because he once brought his daughter toast and hot chocolate out in the snow.

It is interesting that after the long, boring impeachment, when the American public signalled that it couldn't care less about the private lives of its politicians, it is their private lives that are being endlessly promoted in the new political season. First there was the Gores' popular kiss that lasted several beats longer than it had to, and then there was Joe Lieberman, Gore's running mate, calling his wife Hadassah "sweetheart" during his acceptance speech. These are not public displays of affection so much as public displays of functionality. It is as if there is a pornographic picture in the back of everyone's mind of Monica Lewinsky in the oval office, and all the candidates all running as hard as they can against that picture with their own cheery vignettes of conjugal bliss.

Part of this year's obsession with first marriages may also be that our politicians are so stage-managed, every gesture, every motion so scripted and second-guessed and polled, that there is some doubt as to who they really are. The media's favourite activity now is covering not the candidates, but their coaching, their pollsters and managers, advisers who tell them to wear greens and beiges, and speech writers who craft their rhetorical swells. You would have to be illiterate and without a television set to think that you are getting anywhere near the real man. Somehow, quite irrationally, this leads to the belief that when the candidates' wives come on to the stage in powder-blue suits, you are tapping in to their real lives.

The fact that all of this is scripted, too, that the wives' collages of photographs, and daughters' affectionate reminiscences are also staged, doesn't seem to matter. These women - Tipper Gore, Laura Bush, Gore's daughters Karenna and Kristen, Hadassah Lieberman - are not professionals, or don't seem like professionals, and so there is a feeling when they come to the podium, awkward and shy, like Laura, or giddily cheery, like Tipper, that we are getting closer to the men themselves. But are these women humanising their husbands, or are we just reading a lot about how they humanise them?

The candidates' wives are being used in a way that vice-presidents have traditionally been used - to balance the candidate, to compensate for a perceived weakness. The wives are not there to support their husbands but to subtly shift perceptions of them. For instance, George W Bush's drunken past, his volatile emotional side, his tendency to curse New York Times reporters, is counteracted by Laura's down-to-earth sweetness. He is "grounded" by her, everyone around them constantly tells us. She tempers his excesses. And in much the same way, Tipper's naturalness is offered by the campaign as an antidote to Gore's stiffness. She says that she has a "commitment to have fun" on the campaign trail, which does not seem like a commitment Gore has ever made to anyone about anything.

And it is true that, at the convention, Tipper seemed at ease enough for both of them. She danced and sashayed across the stage. She seemed happy to the point of giddiness, and one wondered whether her dose of Prozac may have been a tad too high that day. One big point that the Gore campaign likes to make about Tipper, and one that Karenna Gore (their eldest daughter) made at the convention, is that she is an enfant terrible, a free spirit, albeit a harmless one, who tells reporters whatever is on her mind. Her handlers cannot control her.

The message that is put out to the press is that no message can be put out to the press. She is just too authentic, too true to herself. The idea is that you are getting pure, uncensored access to the Gore family. The character of Tipper is meant to counteract everything you have seen or read or know about her husband's lack of spontaneity. In high school she played drums with a girl band called the Wild Cats. She painted a naked self-portrait when she was pregnant. She goes barefoot on Airforce Two. She is Gore's frolicking unselfconscious other half. The plump blonde id of the Gore campaign.

Laura, an ex-elementary school librarian, is quintessentially unthreatening in an entirely different way. With her short, sensible hair, bright blue eyes and dowdy style, she is a vague maternal figure who somehow manages to stay vague no matter how many times she speaks or is profiled. When she stood on the podium at the Republican convention there was an absence of slickness, a lack of charisma, of heat and desire, that played well. Much was made of how nervous she was before her speech ("I get butterflies a little bit thinking about it") and that nervousness translated into a middle American ordinariness, a modesty that people found appealing.

The New York Times headlined its profile of her "Quiet Strength", which is exactly the image the Bush campaign was trying to project. Even the "political problems" with Laura seem to serve a shrewd function. For instance, she doesn't agree with her husband on all of the issues, such as abortion. She loyally refuses to talk about it. But, in fact, having a wife who disagrees with him in a quiet way can't hurt a candidate seeking women's votes and trying to soften his anti-choice image without alienating his core constituency.

And then there is, of course, the great unspoken shadow of the current first lady - the dislike that rises in her wake, and leaves the campaigns scrambling to define exactly how their candidates are not like Hillary Clinton without saying it too directly. Laura says things like: "I don't really want to talk about the issues that much. I am not that knowledgeable about most issues." Tipper says things like: "With four children and ageing parents I find that I only spend so much time on the issues that I care about, and I spend a lot of time on keeping the family together." In other words, we couldn't have two aspiring first ladies less interested in politics.

Both campaigns have made quite a show of how their candidates' wives were resistant to public life. Bush recounts over and over how he promised his wife that she would never have to give a political speech before she would agree to marry him, and her friends give accounts that she would trade it all in "for long afternoons of reading and mornings of gardening, and be utterly happy". Meanwhile, Gore aides send out reports of how fearful Tipper was that a presidential campaign would consume her family, and how apprehensive she was about her husband's first run for congress.

It seems important that the point is made: these are spotlight-shunning, un-power-hungry women. Not shrinking violets, either of them, but women who don't possess a single ounce of vicarious ambition. Either one of them, their campaigns seem to say, will be dragged reluctantly yet dutifully into the oval office. These are the un-Hillarys being displayed for the American public. (Though it should be pointed out that their distaste for political life seems largely theoretical: Laura is being cast by her husband's camp as an extremely reluctant campaigner, but in February alone she reluctantly campaigned in 22 different states.)

The wives of America's current candidates are studiedly old-fashioned. Even the Democrats stress that Tipper will be a first lady "in the traditional mould". These women are housewives and mothers. They gave up their temporary and unpassionate careers for their husbands in an era when it was no longer common to do so. They devote themselves to their families, and have mild artistic pursuits, such as photography and painting and reading. They present a sweetly pastoral image of American womanhood that has nothing whatsoever to do with American women. Somehow, America seems to want a first lady who represents not the values of the country, but the values of the country 50 years ago.

It is a curious pocket of sexism, a pocket of nostalgia, that represents not what women are but an old portrait of them that, some of us at least, apparently still long for: the mother who stays home; the supportive wife; the quiet strength. As if behind every powerful man is a not-so-powerful woman. So far it has worked. Laura Bush and Tipper Gore are both immensely popular. (Though the campaigns are careful not to make it seem like they are too retrograde. For instance, Laura used to refer to herself as "shy" and now denies it, as does everyone around her with a regularity so noticeable that the New York Times said it was "as if they all received the same memo".)

Gore said in his convention speech, "This is not a popularity contest," but, of course, that is exactly what it is. Today's candidates have to be liked, and known in the manner of the captain of the football team. Neither Gore nor Bush are particularly adept at giving the crucial illusion of intimacy, of making the voter feel like they know him, making the voter dream about him, the way Bill Clinton famously is. Without that gift for intimacy the voter has to be drawn into the candidate's kitchen by other means. They have to feel like they have been invited over to dinner and chatted with. To do what Clinton could do with a bite of his lip, with a throaty laugh, with a lazy smile, these candidates have to call in reserves - their pleasant, unthreatening wives.

webTitle: Wartime sex slaves take Japan to US court

fields.headline: Wartime sex slaves take Japan to US court
fields.trailText: Women raped up to 40 times a day in Japanese sex slave camps during the second world war yesterday shifted the focus of their campaign for further compensation and an official apology to the American courts.
fields.body:
Women raped up to 40 times a day in Japanese sex slave camps during the second world war yesterday shifted the focus of their campaign for further compensation and an official apology to the American courts.

A total of 15 women - surviving representatives of about 200,000 forced to act as what were known euphemistically as "comfort women" - filed a lawsuit in Washington. In response, the Japanese government expressed remorse while asserting that the matter is closed.

"We are aware of the lawsuit," said a foreign ministry official, "but the Japanese government stance is that all issues related to compensation were already settled by post-war treaties."

The women involved in the case come from South Korea, China, the Philippines and Taiwan, countries occupied or colonised by Japan. One, 78-year-old Hwang Geum-Joo, from Seoul, said that for five years she was raped by 30 or 40 Japanese soldiers a day.

"Many of the women became so sick that they had yellow pus from their pubic hair to their belly buttons and their faces turned yellow as well," said the lawsuit. "Women who got sick three times were taken away by the soldiers and never returned."

Japan says compensation was settled by the San Francisco Peace Treaty of 1951. It set up the Asian Women's Fund five years ago and has paid out 2m yen (£13,000) in "atonement money" to each of 170 former comfort women, as well as delivering a letter of apology from the prime minister.

South Korean and Taiwanese women have been given another £20,000 to cover medical and welfare bills, with Filipinos receiving about £8,000.

But Kohken Tsuchiya, a human rights lawyer, said these payments were a veil for the failure to offer a real apology. "Through the fund the government is evading its responsibility to officially apologise for its wartime conduct," he said.

webTitle: European court rules Guinness trial unfair

fields.headline: European court rules Guinness trial unfair
fields.trailText: The three businessmen convicted 10 years ago of taking part in an illegal share support operation with the former Guinness chairman Ernest Saunders were denied a fair trial, the European court of human rights in Strasbourg ruled yesterday.
fields.body:
The three businessmen convicted 10 years ago of taking part in an illegal share support operation with the former Guinness chairman Ernest Saunders were denied a fair trial, the European court of human rights in Strasbourg ruled yesterday.

Gerald Ronson, Jack Lyons and Anthony Parnes were found guilty in 1990 of colluding in an unlawful scheme set up to support the Guinness takeover of the Distillers company.

But the prosecution's reliance on transcripts of interviews with the men by Department of Trade inspectors during the inquiry into the takeover breached their right not to incriminate themselves, a key element of the right to a fair trial, the seven judges held unanimously. The men were compelled by statute to answer the inspectors' questions and could have faced two years in jail had they refused.

During their criminal trial, the prosecution spent three days reading out parts of the transcripts of the interviews to the jury "in a manner intended to incriminate them", the judges said.

Yesterday's ruling, which does not affect the men's convictions, was inevitable because the court made the same finding four years ago in a case brought by Saunders, dealing a blow to efforts to tackle city corruption.

After the Saunders ruling, the government conceded that the use of DTI interviews in criminal trials breached the European convention on human rights and prosecuting authorities stopped using them.

But the Strasbourg court dismissed other complaints by the trio about the fairness of their trial, and refused to award them damages.

The three men had argued that their right to a fair trial was also violated by improper collusion between the DTI and prosecutors, non-disclosure of material relevant to their defence, and the length of time it took for the proceedings against them to finish.

Ronson's solicitors, Mishcon de Reya, said they were "examining the judgment in detail and the options concerning future action". Parnes's solicitor, Keith Oliver of Peters & Peters, said: "The options obviously include making application for the convictions to be set aside."

The DTI investigation into Guinness's acquisition of Distillers was launched in November 1986, after allegations of an illegal share support operation to guarantee the success of the bid.

Saunders was charged in May 1987 with false accounting, theft and the destruction of documents.

Lyons, a financier, Gerald Ronson, chairman of Heron International, and Anthony Parnes, a trader, were charged with conspiracy, false accounting and theft. All three maintained that the share operations were common practice and could not be classified as a crime, and they denied all charges at their trial.

In August 1990 Saunders was convicted and jailed for five years. The others were also convicted. Ronson, whose Heron Group received a £5m success fee and an £800,000 indemnity against share losses, was jailed for 12 months and fined a record £5m. Parnes was jailed for 30 months, while Lyons was spared a prison sentence because of ill health.

Appeals were rejected in May 1991 and in 1995. Permission to appeal to the House of Lords was refused.

Lyons, 84, who was stripped of his knighthood after the original verdict, said: "The last 12 years have been very difficult for me, for my family and for my friends. I welcome this judgment so that I may yet be able to enjoy a little of my retirement, without the cloud of injustice hanging over me."

webTitle: Arms cache seized as Spain moves to crush Eta

fields.headline: Arms cache seized as Spain moves to crush Eta
fields.standfirst: Special report: violence in Spain
fields.trailText: Spanish police seized a cache of arms and explosives from what they believe to be a command centre used by the Basque separatist group Eta near Bilbao yesterday as they consolidated a full frontal assault on the organisation ordered by Spain's prime minister, José María Aznar.
fields.body:
Spanish police seized a cache of arms and explosives from what they believe to be a command centre used by the Basque separatist group Eta near Bilbao yesterday as they consolidated a full frontal assault on the organisation ordered by Spain's prime minister, José María Aznar.

Mop-up operations continued in the aftermath of one of the harshest blows ever dealt the group. Thirty six people have been arrested, over the past week, including the man believed to be Eta's top military commander, Ignacio Gracia Arregui.

Eta ended a 14-month truce at the start of the year and began a campaign of violence that has caused 12 deaths.

Spain's security chiefs say they have virtually destroyed Eta's military and support structure in a series of raids on safe houses and headquarters belonging to the group's political wing which began last Wednesday but followed months of coordinated planning with French police.

The offensive came at a time when the security forces were under strong political pressure to counter an escalation in attacks aimed at politicians, journalists and businessmen critical of Eta.

But Mr Aznar and his tough-minded interior minister, Jaime Mayor Oreja, himself a Basque, have been careful not to cry victory. Past experience has shown Eta's capacity to recover and restructure. In 1992, the group's three top military leaders were seized in Bidart just over the French border. It has taken eight years for Mr Arregui, the man who rebuilt Eta's commandos, to be captured, once again in Bidart.

Mr Aznar is determined not to repeat the mistake he believes was made in 1992 by limiting his offensive to police action. For that reason he has launched simultaneous judicial and political initiatives aimed at curbing the activities of fringe organisations linked to Eta and at ousting the non-violent Basque Nationalist Party (PNV), the largest in the area, from the regional government.

Mr Arregui's arrest followed a round-up of 20 activists linked to the separatist party Euskal Herritarrok which has close ties to Eta. Spain's national court is preparing charges against 18 of them on the grounds that they collaborated with Eta.

People thought to be Eta's explosives experts and key technicians were rounded up over the weekend in a further wave of arrests, mostly in France. Harsh penalties have also been introduced for those involved in so-called low level violence mainly youth groups linked to Eta who are thought to number 3,000 people.

But the initiative floundered after voting patterns in the Basque country remained unaltered giving those who wish to remain Spanish an edge over those who see themselves as totally or predominantly Basque.

Mr Aznar now wants to force early regional elections in the Basque country which he hopes will be won by non-nationalist forces led by his own People's party.

The hardline he assumed throughout Eta's 14-month ceasefire continues. "We cannot negotiate in return for peace," he insists, arguing that Basques are free to pursue political change through existing institutions set up when Spain adopted a democratic constitution 22 years ago.

fields.headline: Time for a change
fields.trailText: Following its transformation from a dull, if dependable, electronics manufacturer to a sexy telecoms kit maker, Marconi shares have enjoyed a strong run. Since November Marconi shareholders have looked on as the value of their investment has risen from 610p to last night's closing price of £10.45.
fields.body:
Following its transformation from a dull, if dependable, electronics manufacturer to a sexy telecoms kit maker, Marconi shares have enjoyed a strong run. Since November Marconi shareholders have looked on as the value of their investment has risen from 610p to last night's closing price of £10.45.

But analysts are now starting to question the valuation of the company. Earlier this week Deutsche Bank initiated coverage of the stock with a "market perform" recommendation and said the stock was fairly valued at current levels.

In Deutsche's view the strengths of the company and its future growth prospects are already in the share price.

With Marconi the most expensive stock in the European telecom equipment universe, investors may want to take Deutsche's advice and seek better value elsewhere in the sector.

fields.headline: Water goes against the tide
fields.trailText: With global equity markets continuing to fret about the impact of the high oil price it was no surprise to see defensive favourites such as water utilities and food retailers perform well yesterday.
fields.body:
With global equity markets continuing to fret about the impact of the high oil price it was no surprise to see defensive favourites such as water utilities and food retailers perform well yesterday.

But that only told half the story. In the main Tesco, up 18.25p, or 8.43%, to 234.75p, was responding to another set of flawless figures, while talk that German utilities group RWE is on the prowl sent the share prices in the water sector sharply higher.

Thames Water rose 48.5p to 915p, the best performer in the FTSE 250, Severn Trent Water put on 23.5p to 677p, Anglian Water advanced 18p to 528p and Kelda Group rose 11.5p to 350p.

According to traders the speculative money was on a bid by RWE for Thames Water, by common consent the sector's blue chip play. "It's a credible story. If someone wanted to take on Vivendi and Suez they would snap up Thames because of the international spread of its operations," one sector specialist said.

That plus comments attributed at the weekend to the new industry regulator, Philip Fletcher, indicating he was open to ideas about restructuring in the sector, got punters very excited.

"The sector is very cheap at the moment on fundamentals. Restructuring is inevitable and we expect management to look at creative ways to unlock value," UBS utilities analyst Simon Hawkins said.

Dealers also noted that the sector was belatedly reacting to comments made by the competition commission at the end of last week, which appeared to support the argument that price cuts imposed by industry regulator Ofwat on the industry had been too harsh.

The commission argued that the price cuts imposed on Mid Kent Water and East Surrey Water by Ofwat were over the top. In particular, it took issue with Ofwat's treatment of depreciation and the cost of capital, both of which are crucial because they determine the level of returns utilities can make for their shareholders.

It concluded that both companies should be allowed a high rate of return, a precedent that could have important ramifications for the sector. Some analysts expect other water companies to follow the lead of Mid Kent and East Surrey and demand the regulator takes a fresh look at the price cuts.

Meanwhile, leading shares made it 10 down days in the last 11 trading sessions, as the oil price continued to stoke fears that the global economy is heading for a hard landing.

At the close the blue chip index was down 6.7 points at 6,403.5, with "old economy" stocks undermined by a string of profit warnings from US peers and concerns about the effect the oil price is having on raw material costs.

Just when Invensys share holders thought things could not get worse, they did.

Shares in the automation and controls firm slipped 7p to 144p, unsettled by a nasty profit warning from US rival Rockwell.

Shares in chemicals outfit ICI, which slipped to a 10-year low on Monday, sank further into the mire, by 26p to 384p, as investors continued to fret about the impact of the strong oil price and the weak euro. However, dealers dismissed talk that ICI is close to issuing a profit warning.

Shares in the mining group Billiton dropped 12.5p to 264p as a profit warning from the US group Alcoa soured sentiment toward the entire sector.

Lower down the corporate scale, things were not much better. The FTSE 250 ended down 95.8 points at 6,806, with the conglomerate Tomkins falling 18.5p to 172p. Analysts are concerned about the performance of industrial components which are predominantly focused on North America.

Sugar company Tate & Lyle fell 21.75p to 225.5p as punters finally reacted to a profit warning from US sweetener group Corn Products International.

fields.headline: The Rev Gordon Wakefield
fields.standfirst:
Methodist preacher with a passion for bringing people together
Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: The crowning achievement of the Rev Gordon Wakefield, who has died aged 79, was his appointment in 1979 as principal of Queen's College, Birmingham, the only ecumenical theological college in mainland Britain. There, he held together Anglican, Liberal Catholic, Methodist and Reformed in a way no other Methodist was capable of; only he could have been the first Methodist principal. He was a master of spontaneous prayer, a superb liturgist, and a writer whose unrivalled knowledge of spirituality culminated, in 1983, in A Dictionary Of Christian Spirituality, which he edited.
fields.body:
The crowning achievement of the Rev Gordon Wakefield, who has died aged 79, was his appointment in 1979 as principal of Queen's College, Birmingham, the only ecumenical theological college in mainland Britain. There, he held together Anglican, Liberal Catholic, Methodist and Reformed in a way no other Methodist was capable of; only he could have been the first Methodist principal. He was a master of spontaneous prayer, a superb liturgist, and a writer whose unrivalled knowledge of spirituality culminated, in 1983, in A Dictionary Of Christian Spirituality, which he edited.

Born to industrious working-class parents in Crewe, Wakefield was steeped in Methodism. His childhood was marred by health problems, including a bout of rheumatic fever, the legacy of which he carried all his life. He began preaching at the age of 16 and, a year after being turned down for military service in 1939, was accepted as a candidate for the ministry.

In 1944, he worked as a pre-collegiate probationer in the Finchley and Hendon Methodist circuit and, in 1946, was sent to Wesley House, Cambridge. He served his first station as a probationer in Woodstock, on the Oxford circuit, followed by periods in Stockport, Newcastle-upon-Tyne and Bristol.

Gordon's immense knowledge of English literature, and command of the language, found expression not only in the enormous range of literary references in his sermons, but also in his wonderful extempore prayers, which were filled with images from scripture and hymnary, in an age when many are thrown back on written anthologies.

In 1963, he became connexional editor of the Methodist church, a post he held for eight years and which brought him into close contact with John Bowden, of the SCM Press, and Noel Davey, of the Society For Promoting Christian Knowledge (SPCK). In this role, he scrutinised mountains of manuscripts and enabled the publication of many important texts.

His own literary production began with the published version of his Fernley- Hartley lecture on Puritan devotion. He wrote for many journals on a wide range of subjects, including a series in the Expository Times on modern English poets. His life of Bunyan, Bunyan The Christian, was published in 1993, and his Groundwork Of Worship is due to appear shortly.

In 1971, Gordon became chairman of the Manchester and Stockport Methodist district, a post in which he did more good work than he knew, although he seemed surprisingly uneasy in the role. He did not like to exercise discipline, but his unwillingness to be judgmental endeared him to many, for they knew that he would always listen attentively both to the troubled and the troublers.

This was true also of his relationship with ordinands and student ministers in his post at Queen's, where, as a passionate ecumenist, he found his real home. His immense contribution was recognised in 1986 by the then Archbishop of Canterbury in the award of a Lambeth DD. He was proud of his connections with the church of England; he knew more bishops than most bishops and delighted in his relationships with them. He was a great raconteur.Hundreds of students knew him simply as Gordon, and affectionately imitated his melodious voice in the college concerts.

Above all, Gordon Wakefield was a connexional person, in the Methodist sense of being very proud to be a preacher in connexion with the Methodist conference. He was also connexional in knowing how to hold together the Puritan and Methodist traditions. He was both a sacramentalist and skilled in leading free worship. He will be sorely missed, especially by those who depended on his sermons in the Methodist Recorder.

He leaves his wife Beryl - to whom he acknowledged his deep indebtedness for providing the stable, loving relationship which allowed him to achieve so much - and his children, Adrian, Helen, Pamela and Penny.

 Gordon Stevens Wakefield, clergyman and writer, born January 15 1921; died September 11 2000

fields.headline: Redbus seeks £82m for e-hotel chain
fields.trailText: Redbus Interhouse, the company that provides support and connections for internet servers, yesterday announced a £82m share issue to fund a chain of "internet hotels".
fields.body:
Redbus Interhouse, the company that provides support and connections for internet servers, yesterday announced a £82m share issue to fund a chain of "internet hotels".

The company, whose co-founder Cliff Stanford made millions of pounds from the sale of internet service provider Demon, plans to use the money to increase the number of data storage centres it has in Europe.

The internet hotels provide temperature-controlled environments with extensive electronic security in which internet servers for telecoms companies, e-commerce businesses and application service providers are housed for a monthly fee.

Redbus aims to have 13 sites operating by the end of 2001 and 21 by the end of 2002. The company has enough funding to set up 27 sites. It has one site in London and one in Paris, which are expected to be fully leased by the end of this year. Redbus plans two more internet hotels in London.

The company is in a market that is growing rapidly. According to Phillips Group research the sector will be worth $5.4bn by 2001. Redbus hopes to be one of the first to build centres in different countries, but rivals such as CityReach International and Telecity also plan to expand their networks.

Redbus' new sites will be larger than existing ones, the company said, because of the strength of demand.

Company executives believe it will take about five months to build each hotel, at a cost of £6m, and 18 months to lease fully. At that stage the sites will generate £10m in sales and reach break-even within their first year of operation.

Yesterday Redbus shares closed up 20.5p at 312p. The fundraising involves the issue of about 30m shares at 280p.

Existing shareholders have the right to buy one new share for every four they own.

Mr Porter said: "We are pleased that the market has responded positively. The success of this fundraising allows us to deploy a high specification network across the full footprint in Europe requested by our customers."

fields.headline: Home truths
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV:  Gareth McLean
fields.trailText: Telly Sales/My Family/Love Is Not Enough: The Journey To Adoption/A Very British Murder: Killing Christine
fields.body:
Paul Wright and Val Kaye's attempt to set up a home-shopping channel was the subject of Telly Sales (Channel 4), a rather jolly documentary which showed that the public gets what it deserves. The public - or at least, the public who watch home-shopping channels - don't like the hustle and bustle of ordinary shopping. They visit the Ideal Homes Exhibition to see the "stars" of QVC, ogling them with an adoration normally reserved for pop stars and David Jason, and showering them with compliments like "she is the personification of elegance" despite it being blatantly untrue. Thus, this public gets imitation diamonds, home hair-removal kits and toilet-seat warmers, paid for in two easy payments and all without the hassle of leaving the house. While it's probably for the best that these people stay indoors and off the streets, rather worryingly they flex substantial financial muscle. In the UK alone, the home-shopping industry has a turnover of £250 million.

Understandably then, Paul and Val wanted Ideal to take on the home-shopping giant QVC. But as Paul himself admitted, if the granddaddy of home shopping knew how disorganised his channel was, "they would be laughing into their socks". Or, more likely, into their sheepskin-effect cosyboots with a choice of three tartan covers.

With little time to build a studio, even less to train gormless presenters - or find ones with gorm pre-removed - and the media showing little interest in their exciting new venture (emphatically their words), tempers were fraying. The trophies of the presenting team - Debbie Flint, formerly a presenter on British Forces television, Paul Lavers, runner-up in last year's cable TV personality of the year, and Steve Whatley, the gadget man from This Morning - were, in their own individual ways, quite repellent. One can only assume Lavers, who looked as if he was sculpted by Gerry Anderson and operated by Lily Savage, lost out in the personality of the year contest to some effervescent individual. Perhaps that man from the Claims Direct advert who received £13,000 after suffering an accident at work. In between queeny fits, hilarious incompetence all round and praying for death threats (though, oddly, not on each other), Ideal went on air on time ("Live from Peterborough!") And people phoned in. And ordered things. It almost beggars belief.

When Strindberg described the family as "home of all social evils, a charitable institution for indolent women, a prison workshop for the slaving breadwinner and a hell for children", he hadn't even seen My Family (BBC1). If he had, he would have added "and not an institution easily made amusing, even if you have a team of writers in an American style". Robert Lindsay and Zoë Wanamaker lead the cast, all of whom were sleepwalking through their parts, thanks to the absolute dearth of interesting plot and pedestrian characters.

Love Is Not Enough: The Journey To Adoption (BBC1) was a sensitive and honest look at "the ultimate job interview that natural parents never need endure". Three quite different couples, with a more positive view of families than Strindberg, were being assessed as potential adoptive parents, with each set of circumstances illuminating the process of adoption as a whole. It made for moving television.

Linda and Tony from Leeds were worried that the bedroom they had set aside for a prospective child might be considered too small; Paula and Al left the decisions in God's hands; while Mark and Sarah were adopting a "special needs" child from China. While the couples are to be applauded for their openness - and like it or not, Mark and Sarah's discussion of what level of disability they would accept is one most of us would have - Sarah's reason for adopting again sounded a bit odd, if not selfish. "If we lost him [Joshua], the cost would be so high emotionally, you kind of feel you want a second child as an insurance policy", she explained. Second child as insurance policy. How heart-warming.

A Very British Murder: Killing Christine (Channel 4) told of another family, albeit one torn apart by murder. Speaking of their mother's murder, her prostitution and her murderers, Denise and Damon Alford were dignified and honest, children of whom their mother would be rightly proud. A testament to the indomitability of the human spirit and a tribute to their mother's love.

Perhaps that man from the Claims Direct advert who received £13,000 after suffering an accident at work. In between queeny fits, hilarious incompetence all round and praying for death threats (though, oddly, not on each other), Ideal went on air on time ("Live from Peterborough!") And people phoned in. And ordered things. It almost beggars belief. When Strindberg described the family as "home of all social evils, a charitable institution for indolent women, a prison workshop for the slaving breadwinner and a hell for children", he hadn't even seen My Family (BBC1). If he had, he would have added "and not an institution easily made amusing, even if you have a team of writers in an American style". Robert Lindsay and Zoë Wanamaker lead the cast, all of whom were sleepwalking through their parts, thanks to the absolute dearth of interesting plot and pedestrian characters. Love Is Not Enough: The Journey To Adoption (BBC1) was a sensitive and honest look at "the ultimate job interview that natural parents never need endure". Three quite different couples, with a more positive view of families than Strindberg, were being assessed as potential adoptive parents, with each set of circumstances illuminating the process of adoption as a whole. It made for moving television. Linda and Tony from Leeds were worried that the bedroom they had set aside for a prospective child might be considered too small; Paula and Al left the decisions in God's hands; while Mark and Sarah were adopting a "special needs" child from China. While the couples are to be applauded for their openness - and like it or not, Mark and Sarah's discussion of what level of disability they would accept is one most of us would have - Sarah's reason for adopting again sounded a bit odd, if not selfish. "If we lost him [Joshua], the cost would be so high emotionally, you kind of feel you want a second child as an insurance policy", she explained. Second child as insurance policy. How heart-warming. A Very British Murder: Killing Christine (Channel 4) told of another family, albeit one torn apart by murder. Speaking of their mother's murder, her prostitution and her murderers, Denise and Damon Alford were dignified and honest, children of whom their mother would be rightly proud. A testament to the indomitability of the human spirit and a tribute to their mother's love.

webTitle: What sci-fi fans are watching on TV

fields.headline: Random views
fields.standfirst: What sci-fi fans are watching on TV
fields.trailText: What sci-fi fans are watching on TV...
fields.byline: Sin Pattenden spoke to sci-fi fans through the internet
fields.body:
Kevin Jones:

"Obviously I do like watching Star Trek and Deep Space Nine. I'm a big X-Files fan too, but I'm also a sucker for Coronation Street. Do I like Mike Baldwin? I don't feel sorry for him, because he was a bastard to Alma really, and the baddies get their comeuppance, don't they? I like a bit of crime stuff - the Women Who Kill thing was quite good, I thought. The suicidal car driver woman, that was fascinating. She jumped out of the car, didn't she? Killed her family? It's not very sci-fi though, is it?"

Hal Greenham:

"I'm Canadian and I think British TV is very good, but it does seem to have gone down a little in tone. There's someone who I think is majorly responsible and that's Denise van Outen. I thought her weekend show was the absolute pits, but I must say she does exert a strange fascination over me."

Jonathan Renfrew:

"I like all the sci-fi programmes, but do you know the one I really miss? Twin Peaks (pictured). You can watch it on cable but I think a new series with the original cast would be fantastic. I loved that programme, I've got all the videos and I even managed to get a letter off David Lynch after I wrote a few to him. I hope it was him, anyway, I'm sure it's real. I do like watching other programmes on TV. I enjoy Countdown and Fifteen To One and I like Top Of The Pops 2 because it features so many interesting groups from years ago. I didn't like the Robbie Williams one, because I don't like him at all - he's a show off."

Serena Pye:

"I watch the Big Breakfast to help me get up in the morning, and I hate it, but the other programmes are so boring. I do watch Star Trek but I'm more of a Doctor Who fan myself so I watch old videos and spend time on the internet or reading. If I could be on any programme I'd be Jeremy Paxman on Newsnight, or Jeremy Clarkson. Hahahahahaha! I do have a car, it's a Cavalier. I go up to the moon in it."

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: A Class Act/Morning Performance
fields.body:
In a 12-month plan, the failed Dulwich High School for Boys is being replaced by a comprehensive school. A new head teacher, Pam Bowmaker, is responsible for this total rehabilitation. A Class Act (11.0am, Radio 4) finds the transformation highly popular with local people, 840 of whom want their children enrolled. So far only 150 have been accepted, and one of the rejects is the deputy head's daughter. Like 170 other aggrieved parents, he now wants the decision overturned.

For the next three days Petroc Trelawney devotes the whole of Morning Performance (11.30am, Radio 3) to the semi-finals of the Leeds International Piano Competition. So far the 90 entrants have had to play works chosen by the judges. Now, the semi-finalists have the luxury of choosing their own well-practised programmes. Saturday's winner will emerge with £12,000 - and the comforting thought that victory at Leeds launched the careers of Radu Lupu and Andras Schiff.

fields.headline: The separation game
fields.standfirst: Unreasonable behaviour. Alimony payments. Bitter custody battles. Who in their right mind wants a camera crew filming their divorce?  Camilla Redmond reports on the couples who said they did...
fields.trailText: Unreasonable behaviour. Alimony payments. Bitter custody battles. Who in their right mind wants a camera crew filming their divorce? Camilla Redmond reports on the couples who said they did...
fields.body:
Your marriage is on the rocks and your misery is absolute. What do you do next? Call the cameras in, if you follow the lead of the four couples featured in Channel 4's Break Up, which starts tonight.

On the surface, a fly-on-the-wall documentary series about divorce negotiations would seem to be just another in the series of cheap-to-make real-life programmes that have flooded our screens in recent years, their Reithian values seemingly in inverse proportion to their ratings figures. And Channel 4, after all, brought us Big Brother, the colossus of the genre.

Such an assumption would be hasty, however. Despite the voyeuristic appeal of their subject matter, the Break Up films adopt a thoughtful, compassionate tone, and have a clear intent: to put across the worth of expert mediation in divorce proceedings. With almost one in two marriages in Britain now failing, the need for such a service is rapidly increasing.

Mark Harrison, the producer and director of the series, has a personal interest in the subject. "When I got divorced, I went down the old-fashioned route of two years of solicitors and spending many thousands of pounds," he explains. "Mediation encourages people to separate in as civilised a way as possible."

Jane and Graham, the subjects of the first film, start on a course of mediation on the advice of their solicitors. "We all love happy endings, but usually it's too late for reconciliation when people come for mediation," says Ruth Smallacombe, a mediator and a governor of the UK College of Family Mediators, who served as a consultant on the series. "This is not relationship counselling. The best we can do as mediators is to help people to think about the implications - financial and practical - of the decision they have already made, and get the appropriate support, particularly if there are children involved."

In the mediation sessions Jane and Graham are seen working out their financial arrangements, how things will be divided up, and discussing custody of their three small children. The mediators encourage both husband and wife to articulate their feelings and, when the atmosphere becomes heated, intervene to suggest how certain points of issue might be resolved.

Cutting from the formal surroundings of the mediation rooms, separate, less structured interviews with Jane and Graham in their own homes flesh out the background to their marriage. Inevitably their tales are poignant, with both partners recalling how they met and fell in love, and then how things started to go wrong. These sections make for powerfully sad viewing, as their wedding-day photographs are counterpoised against their weary expressions of the here and now.

Significantly, no other family members or friends are interviewed. "Being impartial was a key element in the editorial approach," says Mark Harrison. "We made a decision not to widen the net - we realised that as soon as you go outside of those two people, you start getting sucked into the whole side-taking business. It's extremely rare to find a situation where one person is overwhelmingly to blame for the break-up of a long-term relationship. You leave it to the viewer to form a view."

Despite this scrupulous fairness in approach, the fluctuating anger and bitterness of the participants are not omitted. Filmed over a period of months, midway through the programme Jane describes finding some letters written to Graham which suggest that he was already having an affair before they separated. "I hate him, I really hate him", she whispers.

Worse is to follow. Having received a letter from the Child Support Agency telling him how much he will be expected to pay Jane every month, Graham announces that this means he will have to rethink all the arrangements that were agreed in the mediation sessions. The film ends with Graham flying off on holiday with a new girlfriend, and the news that Jane will be taking him to court to seek financial support.

"Arrangements made in mediation aren't finally legally binding," Smallacombe warns. "But if one person is less keen to give financial information or is spending family assets, we wouldn't just ignore it, we're very interventionist - not in judging what they're doing, but we will say that the other person needs to get legal advice."

Although Jane and Graham do not manage to avoid calling in solicitors to settle their dispute, they can agree upon the usefulness of their mediation sessions. Smallacombe is hopeful that the series will spread the word further. She also sees a wider relevance for the programmes.

"My hope is also that they might encourage people watching them to make a climate-check on their own relationships," she says. "But the best result of all would be for us to start putting lots more energy and education into the preparation for marriage - getting people to really think about what relationships entail before they make these huge commitments."

Break Up, Channel 4, tonight, 9pm.

fields.headline: Court circular
fields.standfirst: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.trailText: Who's up in front of the judge...
fields.body:
Muscle-bound, bleach-blond, mullet-headed wrestler Hulk Hogan is suing his former bosses at World Championship Wrestling for defamation. Hogan - real name Terry Bolea - grappled in a pay-per-view event this summer, Bash At The Beach, but took umbrage with events that happened on the night.

The wrestler claims he agreed to the match on condition that he was the "featured fighter" and that he would beat his opponent, Jeff Jarrett, which he duly did. And who said wrestling was fixed? But what the Hulkster claims he didn't expect was the rant that the WCW's Vince Russo came out with following the bout. Russo's post-rumble speech, in which he called Hogan a "goddamn politician" who "doesn't give a shit about this company", climaxed with the diktat: "Hogan you big, bald son of a bitch... KISS MY ASS!"

While this all sounds like pretty straightforward wrestling talk to me, Hogan's lawyer asserts that it violated his contract for "creative control" of his character. So this is one grudge match that won't be settled in the ring.

"Gorgeous" George Clooney may be getting critical acclaim for his role in the Coen brothers' O Brother, Where Art Thou?, but his recent water-logged effort, The Perfect Storm, is receiving some unwanted attention in the US. Jodi Tyne, ex-wife of the late Captain Billy Tyne (played by Clooney), has brought a case against the filmmakers and Warner Bros, claiming that Tyne was unfairly represented and that the family hadn't given permission for his life story to be represented on screen. The suit alleges that Tyne's daughters Erica and Billie-Jo, as his legal heirs, are entitled to a cut of the film's profits - estimated at more than $170m. Warner Bros contest that permission isn't needed to portray a well-known event.

webTitle: Mother Teresa nun accused of torture

fields.headline: Mother Teresa nun accused of torture
fields.standfirst: Sister goes missing after claims she burnt seven-year-old's hand
fields.trailText: The Missionaries of Charity, the organisation founded by the late Mother Teresa to help the poor and dying, was facing grave embarrassment last night after the order and one of its nuns were accused of torturing a seven-year-old girl.
fields.byline: Luke Harding in New Delhi and Raekha Prasad
fields.body:
The Missionaries of Charity, the organisation founded by the late Mother Teresa to help the poor and dying, was facing grave embarrassment last night after the order and one of its nuns were accused of torturing a seven-year-old girl.

The nun who allegedly carried out the torture, Sister Francesco, has mysteriously vanished. The order's head, Sister Nirmala, was summoned on Friday by a court in Calcutta in connection with the allegation. She was given conditional bail in the sum of $110 (£79) and asked to return on October 2.

The scandal comes as the Vatican continues to ponder whether Mother Teresa's "fast-track" application for sainthood should be granted. Although the order was accused before her death three years ago of unwisely accepting donations from dictators and crooks, this is the first time in 50 years an allegation of abuse has been made against it.

The girl's father, Kaviran Mondal, a local rag picker, filed a criminal case against the Missionaries of Charity and Sister Francesco following the incident last week, which took place at the mission's home for destitute children in central Calcutta. The girl - Karabi Mondal - was one of 100 children living at the hostel.

According to sources close to the investigation, Karabi was blamed after neighbours in the house next door complained that some of their jewellery had been stolen. As a punishment, Sister Francesco allegedly placed the girl's hand on a hot plate used for cooking chapatis. The burns were so severe the girl requires a skin graft. "The sister had a Catholic penchant for punishment," a source said.

Speaking on local television, Mr Mondal, who has another daughter also cared for by the charity, said: "We looked upon Mother Teresa as a god. We never imagined this could happen here. It is unbelievable."

"This particular sister has beaten and hurt other children. I don't want to blame the whole organisation. She doesn't know limits," he added.

Mr Mondal said that he was too poor to look after his own children.

Karabi had been at the hostel for six months, while the nuns had cared for her sister for two years. Their father was alerted to what had happened after the older girl rushed to tell him that Karabi had been hurt. The family is now living in Bow Bazaar, a Calcutta slum.

Sister Nirmala, who was elected head of the order following Mother Teresa's death, was last night unavailable for comment. But on leaving court last week she said: "The truth will come out. We will co-operate with the judicial process. Beyond that I can't say anything."

The sister, described by one source as "shy", "retiring" and with Mother Teresa's "spirit", is believed not to dispute that the incident took place and to have said: "We should love children, not punish them."

In a withering revisionist biography, The Missionary Position, published in 1995, the journalist Christopher Hitchens rounded on Mother Teresa for accepting donations from Jean-Claude "Baby Doc" Duvalier, the former dictator of Haiti, and from fraudsters such as Robert Maxwell and Charles Keating, the California banker jailed in the Savings and Loan scandal. Other critics have complained of the order's opposition to birth control, and the primitive medical regime in its clinics.

But last night Navin Chawla, Mother Teresa's Indian biographer, said he was surprised by the allegation of abuse. "This is the first such case I have come across in 23 years. I can only put it down as a freak thing," he said. "As for the complaint that the order runs primitive medical regimes, Mother Teresa used to take people from the streets after they had been refused by every other hospital. It is very hard to get into a hospital in India if you are poor."

Following Mother Teresa's death in September 1997, the Pope took the unprecedented step of scrapping the traditional five-year waiting period for beatification.

The Missionaries of Charity, which has its world headquarters in Calcutta, has campaigned vigorously for her sainthood. Last summer the process of canonisation formally began, when 100 witnesses gave evidence before a three-man tribunal. The Vatican is expected to wait another two or three years before confirming her as Saint Teresa.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText:
Treasury sells more gold

Jiway signs up 30 brokers
US trustbuster stands down
fields.body:
Treasury sells more gold

Another 25 tonnes of gold was auctioned yesterday as part of the Treasury's plan to reduce its bullion reserves.

The Bank of England said 804,000 ounces of gold were sold for £193.30 an ounce, yielding a total of £155m. So far about 200 tonnes have been sold from a planned total of 415 tonnes. The last sale was in July, when 25 tonnes were sold for £197 an ounce.

One analyst commented: "The gold market has been a bit weak of late. Under normal circumstances a seller probably wouldn't sell gold at present."

Jiway signs up 30 brokers

Jiway, the planned pan-European, internet-based trading platform, said 30 brokers from Britain, Sweden and Germany had signed letters of intent to use the new marketplace due in November. Jiway, a joint venture between Stockholm stock exchange operator OM and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, will provide online trading, clearing and settlement for small investors via brokers.

It will handle 6,000 shares listed in on the New York Stock Exchange, Nasdaq and six European exchanges - London, Frankfurt, Paris, Milan, Amsterdam and Stockholm.

US trustbuster stands down

The US justice department's top anti-trust official, Joel Klein, who took Microsoft to court for curbing competition, will leave office at the end of the month.

His deputy, A Douglas Melamed, will replace Mr Klein, a political appointee, who probably would have been replaced in the change of administration that will follow the presidential election.

Second suitor eyes Go-Ahead

A French railway firm said yesterday it was considering making a counterbid for bus and rail group Go-Ahead, operator of Thames Trains, one of the services involved in last year's Paddington rail crash.

Via-Cariane, a subsidiary of SNCF, said it was considering options which included "the possibility of a counter-proposal being made to Go-Ahead's shareholders".

French consortium C3DA has already made a hostile £326m takeover bid Go-Ahead. Shareholders had until last Saturday to consider that deal but yesterday the deadline was extended to September 30.
