fields.headline: The smell of success
fields.standfirst: A regional theatre that's actually breaking even?  David Ward investigates
fields.trailText: A regional theatre that's actually breaking even? David Ward investigates...
fields.body:
Much to their amazement, the staff of the Theatre by the Lake, on the shores of Derwentwater in Keswick, have just discovered that they have reinvented old-fashioned rep. They didn't set out to do it: producers, directors, critics and arts administrators have all written rep's obituary and proclaimed the need for new policies to suit a time of declining, ageing theatre audiences and soaring deficits. But the £6.25m theatre, built in the style of a barn and housing a 400-seat auditorium and an 80-seat studio, has shown that it is still possible to mount a season of plays using a company of actors hired on extended contracts.

Since August 1999, TbtL has presented 10 plays (nine home-produced, one joint production) and a series of films and imported shows and concerts. It has staged 419 performances, sold 82,000 tickets and broken even on public funding of just £130,000 (about a quarter of what other theatres of comparable size receive). It served the summer-season tourists who flock to the Lake District but also won a completely new Cumbrian audience: A Christmas Carol played to 95% capacity in December and January.

"Our original business plan included three plays for the summer and then perhaps another the following Easter," says Patric Gilchrist, the executive director. "But we have turned out to be much more of a producing theatre than was ever thought possible."

All this runs contrary to the kind of mixed economy (a financially astute blend of home-grown, touring and bought-in shows) that the Arts Council proclaimed was the new reality when it reported in May on what it called "an art form in crisis". On the day when the council's chairman, Gerry Robinson, said English theatre needed an extra £25m a year to survive, a company of nine actors in Keswick was rehearsing the first play of TbtL's 2000 summer season. Four more have been added, and if you nip up to the Lakes for an autumn break you could see all five in a week.

"If this policy works again next year, things could get scary," says Gilchrist. "The danger is that people will say that if we have done it once, we can do it again."

It worked because he and his artistic director Ian Forrest made unreasonable demands on themselves and their staff: Forrest directed nine plays in a year and Gilchrist has had five days off in two years. "Part of my reason for coming here was my belief that it was possible for a small regional theatre to redefine how it operates within existing levels of funding," adds Gilchrist, who had been at Clywd Theatr Cymru for 11 years. "But we go forward knowing that we will need a bit more money if we are to deliver the range of work we set out to deliver, including youth and community programmes. In the year to March 31, we incurred no deficit. This year we are working on a budget that doesn't yet balance, although we are not so far away as to make the whole operation unrealistic or unreasonable."

The theatre has been helped by a £75,000 reserve fund accumulated by the former Century Theatre, which operated in the Blue Box, a mobile auditorium that was built for postwar touring and came to rest in the car park where TbtL now stands.

"If we are to continue with our present level of work, we could sustain it for two years. But after that, there would have to be a rapid retrenchment and we would operate for only eight months a year. To go on as an all-singing, all-dancing operation, we need to double our money. We need £300,000."

Which is hardly big bucks. The Northern Arts Board knows that and is listening sympathetically.

Meanwhile, Forrest is surrounded by piles of play texts as he tries to repeat the trick in 2001. This year's plays were a safe bunch: Priestley's Dangerous Corner, a Daphne du Maurier adaptation, Noel and Gertie, Romeo and Juliet and (the year's only gamble) Dennis Lumborg's One Fine Day.

Once a loyal audience has been built up, the theatre can begin to stretch the repertory, Forrest says. "The trick is knowing when."

webTitle: Theatre: Julius Caesar and naked torsos

fields.headline: Pecs and violence
fields.standfirst: Julius Caesar is usually seen as a play for elderly actors - but not by David Lan, new artistic director at the Young Vic. He tells  Lyn Gardner  why he has gone for naked torsos and rippling muscles
fields.trailText: Julius Caesar is usually seen as a play for elderly actors - but not by David Lan, new artistic director at the Young Vic. He tells Lyn Gardner why he has gone for naked torsos and rippling muscles.
fields.body:
The act of murder in Shakespeare's plays, suggests the Young Vic's new artistic director, David Lan, often has parallels with the sexual act. Think of the procrastination of Hamlet, the planning of regicide by the Macbeths, the build-up to the killing of Julius Caesar. In both Macbeth and Julius Caesar there is a gulf between what the murderers think they are going to achieve by homicide, and what they actually do achieve. Reality doesn't live up to expectation. When desire is spent there is only emptiness.

"It's like sex," says Lan. A lot of the time you are anxious that you should do it and obsessed by the need to do it. Then you do it and it's great. But afterwards you think, 'What was that all about?' There is a kind of melancholy."

The brochure for the Young Vic's new season, advertising Lan's production of Julius Caesar, shows three male torsos. The models' heads are either cut off or turned away so as not to detract from the rippling muscles.

It is a startling sight. You tend to think of Julius Caesar as an old man's play, a gift for a trio of elderly actors physically past their prime. But Shakespeare was still a relatively young man in his early 30s when he wrote it. It is, suggests Lan, the last young play of a young playwright.

There is more to the Young Vic's marketing strategy than just an advertising campaign in the style of those English National Opera posters a few years back that tried to persuade a doubtful public that opera has nothing to do with fat people singing and everything to do with sex. Lan's proposition is that Julius Caesar as a play about active soldiers, young men bound by friendship and love and destroyed by it. What interests him is the evident absorption of Shakespeare in the relationships between the main characters.

By casting Dorian Healy as Julius Caesar, Marcus D'Amico as Cassius and Lloyd Owen as Brutus - all good-looking actors in their 30s - he seems likely to come up with a production that will challenge our preconception that Julius Caesar is primarily a political play. But while Lan is keen to explore the sensuality of the play and the psychological detail of what he calls "this grown-up male drama", this is certainly not an attempt to stage the first gay Julius Caesar. Lan is far too perceptive for such a crudity.

The South African-born Lan, who trained as an actor and then came to Britain aged 20, has always had the capacity to surprise. Even his appointment earlier this year as the successor to Tim Supple at the Young Vic came out of the blue. This, after all, is a man with only two directorial credits to his name in this country - a widely ignored production of The Glass Menagerie at Watford in 1998, and a superb 'Tis Pity She's a Whore with Jude Law at the Young Vic last autumn.

Until Lan took that Jacobean thriller and turned it inside out, he was mainly known in the theatre world as a playwright. In another incarnation he was an anthropologist, spending two years in the 1980s living in a small village in the Zambezi studying the effects of the guerrilla war on religious beliefs of the local community.

Out of that came a classic anthropological text, Guns and Rain: Guerillas and Spirit Mediums in Zimbabwe, and Desire, a beautiful, wonderfully unfashionable play about possession and the exorcism of guilt. It premiered at the Almeida in 1990 and completed a trilogy begun 10 years previously, which encompassed shamanism and Melanesian cargo cults. As Stephen Daldry of the Royal Court has noted, even when he began his writing career back in the 1970s, Lan "was never part of the dominant ethos which suggested that a playwright's responsibility was to depict and analyse contemporary life in, say, Brixton or Moss Side".

Some years ago a critic, reviewing one of Lan's plays, observed that Lan's was a theatrical career that had never quite coalesced. But everything seems to be coming together nicely now, as the various strands of Lan's long apprenticeship in the theatre and life begin to tie up. Anthropology and theatre have much in common, not least in the way that they explore the nature of ritual. But Lan's own plays are only the tip of an iceberg in a career that includes documentary film-making, translation (his new version of The Cherry Orchard premieres at the National Theatre the night after Julius Caesar opens), extensive work with playwrights and screenwriters and two years spent as writer in residence at the Royal Court in the mid-1990s. Here he became the unsung hero of the new-writing boom, nurturing scripts through the process from development to final production. "Your brief," Daldry told Lan, "is to do what ever you like until you meet resistance."

"I worked with people on the basis that there was no deal," Lan recalls. "I'd be around as long as people wanted me to be there and then I wouldn't. It worked. On many plays I became an unofficial producer."

Without that experience at the Court, Lan would never have considered applying for the Young Vic job. But working closely with Daldry may stand Lan in good stead in other ways, if his ambitious plans for the Young Vic are to be realised. The redevelopment of the Court is testament to the fact that Daldry has no equal in British theatre when it comes to fundraising. "I learned such a lot from Stephen. How could one not? If we're going to rebuild, I need to learn more."

At 48, Lan considers himself too old to be running the Young Vic. He would like it to return to its original ethos of being a theatre where the young inspire the young. "I want 27-year-olds directing King Lear," he says, while pointing out that the current funding situation means that the theatre can only produce three or four in-house shows every year. That, and the need to generate 60% of the theatre's income from the box office, means that Lan has already discovered that "the pressure to be conservative is great".

Then there is the small problem that the building is falling down even faster now than it was 30 years ago, when the first schemes to rebuild it were hatched. None have ever come to fruition, in part because nobody has ever come up with a way to improve upon the current auditorium, one of the most attractive spaces in the country. But if anyone can get the job done, Lan has to be the man, not least because for him the Young Vic is a passion, whereas for his much younger predecessors Tim Supple and David Thacker it was also a career move. Lan didn't need to run a theatre, he just wanted to, and it wasn't any theatre he wanted to run, but the Young Vic in particular.

In the publicity for Julius Caesar, Lan poses questions about the way "some men lead and others follow" and "the enchantment of power", an anthropologist's concept if ever there was one. I wonder whether his nine months at the Young Vic have given him an insight into that enchantment.

He smiles, looking pale as a ghost and completely exhausted. "I knew in the abstract that this was a big job, but the abstract became concrete very quickly. The thing I've really learned is that as quickly as you put things together they fall apart."

Julius Caesar opens at the Young Vic, London SE1, tonight. Box office: 020-7926 6363.

fields.headline: Protein pioneer heads west
fields.standfirst: Oxford Glycosciences seeks Nasdaq listing
fields.trailText: Oxford Glycosciences, the protein-based medicines specialist, is to seek a listing on the hi-tech stock market Nasdaq to raise its profile in the American biotechnology industry.
fields.body:
Oxford Glycosciences, the protein-based medicines specialist, is to seek a listing on the hi-tech stock market Nasdaq to raise its profile in the American biotechnology industry.

The news emerged as the company forged two new alliances, with the genomics equipment firm Perkin Elmer and the medical instruments group Packard BioScience.

Speaking as the group increased its half-year losses by 60% to £7.27m, chief scientific officer Raj Parekh said: "America is pretty much the home of biotech, despite the advances that Europe's been making."

Oxford Glycosciences already has a significant base of US shareholders. Mr Parekh said: "A Nasdaq listing will provide them with easier access to trading, greater liquidity and will give us access to a wider market for our products."

The timing of the secondary listing will depend on market conditions.

Oxford Glycosciences' losses increased due to the cost of large-scale trials for its most advanced drug, Vevesca, a treatment for Gaucher's disease. Sufferers develop a build-up of fatty materials, which damage the liver and spleen.

Mr Parek said: "The rise in losses is for positive reasons. The drug is showing efficacy and tolerability and we're pressing ahead with it."

The company's most promising technology is for analysing proteins to identify therapeutically useful substances.

Its link with Perkin Elmer will give it access to screening machines which are not yet generally available. Perkin is one of the leaders in tools for examining tiny medical compounds. Its machines and those from rival Nycomed Amersham were central to completion of the Human Genome Project.

In a separate deal, the group is collaborating with US-based Packard BioScience to explore ways of developing protein biochips, tiny wafers used to detect the presence of proteins in blood samples.

Oxford Glycosciences' shares rose 15p to £20.75.

webTitle: Dixons call centre gives Sheffield a 1,000-job fillip

fields.headline: Dixons call centre gives Sheffield a 1,000-job fillip
fields.trailText: Dixons, Britain's largest electrical retailer, is creating 1,000 jobs at its expanded call centre in Sheffield.
fields.body:
Dixons, Britain's largest electrical retailer, is creating 1,000 jobs at its expanded call centre in Sheffield.

The recruitment drive follows the firm's decision to centralise all customer services in Yorkshire.

Its announcement yesterday is the second phase of a £45m project which has already seen 650 staff taken on. The investment will be a tonic for Sheffield, which has reinvented itself since the days when most of its population was employed in the steelworks.

Tony Ackroyd, Dixons Group contact centres director, said the centre was on the 11-acre Nunnery Square site. "The first phase created 650 new jobs and invested almost £30m in the local economy. When phase two is fully operational we expect to have created up to 2,000 jobs with a total investment of around £45m."

A spokesman for Dixons said the centre would eventually receive all inquiries - including advice on setting up machinery and ordering spare parts - which were previously dealt with at the head office in Hemel Hempstead.

"Customers of electrical retailers tend to want a lot of after-sales service," he said. "We wanted to centralise all our customer contact activities."

The call centre industry has been one of the success stories of the past five years, despite some debate about the career prospects and security of tenure they offer.

Most retailers, manufacturers and financial service companies have either established their own centres or contracted out the operation to independent operators.

South Yorkshire, whose economy has suffered dramatically from the decline of steel and coal, is a favoured location because costs are relatively low and labour is plentiful.

Earlier this month Dixons announced sales for the 18 weeks to September 2 were 29% ahead of the same period last year and 5% up on a like-for-like basis.

fields.headline: Russia gets the Hello! treatment
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: A newly-discovered cult of celebrity is thriving in Moscow, crowned this month by the long awaited publication of a Russian imitation of Hello! magazine.
fields.body:
A newly-discovered cult of celebrity is thriving in Moscow, crowned this month by the long awaited publication of a Russian imitation of Hello! magazine.

Designed to follow the style of the hugely popular European gossip weeklies, the publisher selected the title Kto! (Who!) rather than the less-than-catchy Russian word for hello - zdravstvuite.

But for those magazine readers not immersed in the blossoming world of Russian showbusiness, the title is wholly appropriate. Some of those featured in the first edition would not score highly on an international celebrity recognition register.

Complete with hallmark red masthead and a liberal sprinkling of enthusiastic exclamation marks, Kto! contains the standard innocuous interviews with the stars alongside lavish pictures.

Readers this week get a glimpse into the extravagant lifestyle of Pavel Bure, Olympic ice hockey heart-throb and one-time fiance of tennis star Anna Kournikova - relaxing in his vast Miami apartment.

"It cost me $1,700,000," Bure tells readers with evident satisfaction. "At first I wanted to buy the whole floor, with palm trees on the balconies, but it didn't work out."

Tatyana Bogolyubova, editor of Kto!, which has no formal links with Hello!, is confident of success.

"In Soviet times, the only information we had about our film stars and musicians came from serious articles about their achievements published in Pravda," she says. "There was no scandal, and nothing about their private lives."

Until the mid-1980s the only comparable publications were Rabotnitsa (Woman Worker) and Krestyanka (Peasant Woman) which created celebrities out of ordinary workers.

The demise of the Russian imperial family is inconvenient, Ms Bogolyubova admits, depriving the magazine of a reliable circulation boost. "It would be nice if the Romanovs were still around, but we can make do instead with the British royal family. Russian women find Prince William very attractive."
fields.bodyText: A newly-discovered cult of celebrity is thriving in Moscow, crowned this month by the long awaited publication of a Russian imitation of Hello! magazine. Designed to follow the style of the hugely popular European gossip weeklies, the publisher selected the title Kto! (Who!) rather than the less-than-catchy Russian word for hello - zdravstvuite. But for those magazine readers not immersed in the blossoming world of Russian showbusiness, the title is wholly appropriate. Some of those featured in the first edition would not score highly on an international celebrity recognition register. Complete with hallmark red masthead and a liberal sprinkling of enthusiastic exclamation marks, Kto! contains the standard innocuous interviews with the stars alongside lavish pictures. Readers this week get a glimpse into the extravagant lifestyle of Pavel Bure, Olympic ice hockey heart-throb and one-time fiance of tennis star Anna Kournikova - relaxing in his vast Miami apartment. "It cost me $1,700,000," Bure tells readers with evident satisfaction. "At first I wanted to buy the whole floor, with palm trees on the balconies, but it didn't work out." Tatyana Bogolyubova, editor of Kto!, which has no formal links with Hello!, is confident of success. "In Soviet times, the only information we had about our film stars and musicians came from serious articles about their achievements published in Pravda," she says. "There was no scandal, and nothing about their private lives." Until the mid-1980s the only comparable publications were Rabotnitsa (Woman Worker) and Krestyanka (Peasant Woman) which created celebrities out of ordinary workers. The demise of the Russian imperial family is inconvenient, Ms Bogolyubova admits, depriving the magazine of a reliable circulation boost. "It would be nice if the Romanovs were still around, but we can make do instead with the British royal family. Russian women find Prince William very attractive."

webTitle: Brief encounters: an employment tribunal lawyer writes

fields.headline: Brief encounters: an employment tribunal lawyer writes
fields.trailText: "I was a paratrooper. I am trained not to surrender."
fields.body:
"I was a paratrooper. I am trained not to surrender." I am trying not to look at Jim, my client, in a manner that could be construed as sceptical. True, he is shorter and slighter than me, but I suppose he could be wiry under his suit. He also has the slightly translucent, almost luminescent flesh of a person who has worked for a long time in a large open-plan office with fluorescent lighting and no windows, like the white tuberous parts of neglected pot plants. I am trying to visualise him a sort of barbecue brown with combat stripes, wearing a helmet with greenery on it. It's not working.

Jim has just been offered £1,500 by his ex-employers to settle his case. This is what we call a nuisance offer. It has occurred to Jim's ex-employers that it would be cheaper to give him £1,500 than to carry on fighting his case. This probably struck them when everyone arrived at the tribunal to discover the case was "floating". This means that although our case is listed to be heard today, no tribunal has actually been allocated to hear it. So we have to "float" around, waiting for a tribunal to come free.

But it is now 11:30 and Jim and I are still sat in the waiting room with the clammy dregs of our coffee and not much left to say to each other. It has probably just struck Jim's ex-employers that even if we get a tribunal now, we are unlikely to finish the case in the remains of the day, which will mean coming back and more legal costs. Jim doesn't have to worry about that because I am doing his case pro bono. So he can afford to be a paratrooper.

I think the £1,500 is attractive and not just because I want to get away from Jim. Jim was dismissed for excessive use of the internet when he was supposed to be working. Our best point is that Jim, unlike most bored surfers, was not looking at xxxchicks.com or pussytown.com. Jim was looking at some very dull stuff. I've seen the logs. Jim spent over an hour looking at avocado recipes. He conducted searches on his mother's maiden name, various cricket players, verrucas.

There are hundreds of pages of these logs. Taken together they are somehow intimate and awful, an appalling record of days and weeks of dullness. I feel like I've looked into Jim's brain.

I think his employers have got a point when they say Jim couldn't have been doing very much work. But Jim, as he says, was a paratrooper. So when they send us away tribunal-less at 12:30, Jim has not accepted the £1,500 and we live to fight another day. Never surrender.

fields.headline: No: 1724
fields.standfirst: Elizabeth Jagger
fields.trailText: Elizabeth Jagger
fields.body:
Age: A comely 16.

Heritage: Legs and hair courtesy of mother Jerry Hall; attitude and cash courtesy of father Mick Jagger; penchant for the modelling scene courtesy of both.

Appearance: On a catwalk / billboard / glossy mag ad campaign near you.

Shouldn't she be at school? Careful, her dad might hear you. He's not ever so keen to see her swapping A-levels for A-line skirts.

Killjoy. Maybe he simply wants to protect her from the predatory world of fashion.

But you said he had a thing for modelling. Which might be why he wants to keep his daughter away. His long relationship with Texan catwalk prowler Jerry Hall produced four children, one legally dubious wedding ceremony and a hefty financial settlement, and finally fell to pieces when Mick fathered a child by Luciana Morad.

A model? You guessed it.

So will dad be stopping Elizabeth's pocket money and confining her to her room until she sees sense? If so, he'll have a shock when he flicks through Vogue at the hairdresser's. It seems the enterprising Ms Jagger has shinned down a drainpipe and legged it to New York to make her Stateside catwalk debut for Indian designer Anand Jon.

And on a schoolnight! She's decided against returning to lessons this year, after term time inconveniently coincided with the spring-summer 2001 shows. But I'm sure mum will write her a note.

So Jerry doesn't fear being overshadowed by her younger gene-bearer? Hardly. While Elizabeth posts a respectable 5ft 11in, mum still has the edge, at 6ft.

Still, maybe Mick's right. Modelling is a fickle game, and you can't count on becoming pregnant by an ageing millionaire rock star to make your fortune. You could always take your kit off for the world's press (and a few paying punters) in a theatre.

Do say: "You can't always get what you want."

Don't say: "Have you done your homework?"

fields.headline: Ramesh Kumar
fields.trailText: Professor Ramesh Kumar, who has died aged 62, was the first professor of perinatal psychiatry in Britain. He won an international reputation for his research, clinical services and training, and was assiduous in his efforts to bring to public attention the needs of women suffering from postnatal depression.
fields.body:
Professor Ramesh Kumar, who has died aged 62, was the first professor of perinatal psychiatry in Britain. He won an international reputation for his research, clinical services and training, and was assiduous in his efforts to bring to public attention the needs of women suffering from postnatal depression.

In 1987, he set up a new section of perinatal psychiatry at the Institute of Psychiatry, London. Its wide-ranging research has included studies into hormonal influences on postnatal depression, mothers who have difficulty bonding with their babies, the causes of postnatal mental illness, the effects of postnatal depression on babies, and postnatal depression across cultures.

Kumar's two volumes (co-edited with Ian Brockington), Motherhood and Mental Illness, are already classics. His work for the Marcé Society, an international organisation involved in the treatment of postnatal psychiatric disorders, brought together statutory and voluntary services in a unique and purposeful way. He was a founding member, and president from 1984-86.

Channi, as he was affectionately known, was born in India, and came to Britain for his secondary education. He studied medicine at Cambridge University and Guy's hospital medical school, before completing his PhD at University College, London. He started his psychiatric training at the Maudsley hospital in 1969 and, in 1981, became consultant in charge of the newly-formed mother and baby unit at the Bethlem Royal hospital, a post he held until his untimely death.

When he was diagnosed with leukaemia, he did not allow the illness to get him down or affect his work. In the last six months, his family, with Channi's blessing, set out to increase public awareness of all aspects of leukaemia, especially among the Asian community.

Channi also had a passion for Indian writing, and was a great follower of RK Narayan. His sense of humour, dedication and understanding of his patients are what I shall remember most about him.

He is survived by his wife and two daughters.

 Ramesh 'Channi' Kumar, psychiatrist, born January 12 1938; died September 19 2000

fields.headline: Shelagh Fraser
fields.standfirst: Versatile actress who wrote and played fine drama
fields.trailText: Shelagh Fraser, who has died aged 79, was a versatile and distinctive actress, whose work was informed by a glint of insightful humour. She enjoyed a 60-year career in the London theatre, a leading role in the 1969 television saga, A Family At War, and a character part in the 1977 film blockbuster, Star Wars.
fields.body:
Shelagh Fraser, who has died aged 79, was a versatile and distinctive actress, whose work was informed by a glint of insightful humour. She enjoyed a 60-year career in the London theatre, a leading role in the 1969 television saga, A Family At War, and a character part in the 1977 film blockbuster, Star Wars.

She had established herself on the West End stage by the mid-1940s, after making her debut at the Comedy Theatre in 1944, as Effie in This Was A Woman. After Rattigan's While The Sun Shines (1945), playing the irrepressible good-time girl, Mabel Crumm, there followed a succession of leading roles, including Hetty, in Call Home The Heart (1947), and the formidably strait-laced Lady Orreyd, in HM Tennent's lavish 1950 revival of Pinero's society drama, The Second Mrs Tanqueray, about the dire consequences which could follow from a Victorian misalliance. It was a performance widely noticed for its aristocratic poise and sharp cutting edge.

National fame came in 1969, when Fraser was cast as Jean Ashton, the embattled matriarch of Granada Television's A Family At War, in which an ordinary northern family faced the perils and sacrifices of life in wartime Liverpool. She appeared in 45 of the serial's 52 episodes.

Eight years later, she was cast by George Lucas as Luke Skywalker's Aunt Beru in Star Wars. Although this was only a small character role, the fact that she had played a part in the most successful cinema attraction of its time resulted in an avalanche of global fan-mail - and her own internet website.

Fraser made a careful choice of her stage roles. In 1953, at the Arts Theatre, she played Cristine in a revival of Lennox Robinson's Drama At Inish, a delicate tragi-comedy of theatrical life in Northern Ireland, and, in the 1960s and 70s, she continued to appear in a range of plays by such notable dramatists as Harold Pinter (Flora, in A Slight Ache), Alan Ayckbourn (Delia, in A Bedroom Farce), Tennessee Williams and Edward Albee. In 1967, she gave a virulent and anguished account of Martha, in Who's Afraid Of Virginia Woolf, and, in 1973, a poignant study of Amanda Wingfield, the fluttery, clinging mother-figure in The Glass Menagerie.

Her last major stage appearance was in 1974, in David Hare's Knuckle, at the Royal Court, where her Mrs Dinning made a marked contribution to the play's edgy and disturbing effect.

Her television and film work was lively and varied, with two vivid flourishes marking her last appearances - as the demented old bag-lady who haunted the bar in the BBC version of Rodney Ackland's Absolute Hell, and as the paralysed, but wickedly communicative, stroke victim in Edith's Finger, which won the Welsh Bafta award for best short film in 1999.

Fraser's family was part of the City dynasty of jewellers Mappin and Webb. Her father was sent to Australia to found an outpost of the business, and, on his return to England, it was discovered that his daughter had contracted spinal tuberculosis, which, as a child, condemned her to lying flat in a specially elongated invalid carriage. She faced this adversity with courage, did well at St Christopher's school, Kingswood, and won a scholarship to a nearby drama school, attached to Croydon repertory theatre. Here, she made her first stage appearance, in 1938.

With her naturally inquiring mind, it was never likely that Fraser would be content to work simply as an actress. In the 1970s, by then in her 50s, she wrote two successful children's books, Captain Johnny and Princess Tai Lue, the tale of an exotic cat. But, as early as 1950, she had tried her hand as a playwright, collaborating on Always Afternoon, a languorous evocation of lotus-eating expatriates on the French riviera, which ran briefly at the Garrick Theatre.

In the 1980s, she became fascinated by the challenges of radio drama. As an actress, she had appeared in more than 500 radio plays, and, for a time, been a member of the BBC Repertory Company. Now, as a dramatist, she adapted Rose Macauley's The World My Wilderness and Rebecca West's The Salt Of The Earth for Radio 4. Her other play for radio was an original, The Maid's Room, a fascinating study of a servant-mistress relationship.

Fraser remained a strikingly pretty woman, whose appearance was marked with a characteristic expression in which humour and tenderness were equally mixed, and which reflected her warm and constant gift for friendship.

 Shelagh Fraser, actress and writer, born November 25 1920; died August 29 2000

fields.headline: Gilbert de Botton
fields.standfirst: Self-made financier who revelled in money, markets and modern art
fields.trailText: "When you are really rich, people come to you," Gilbert de Botton once said to Lucian Freud. De Botton, who has died aged 65, was a powerful, immensely respected financier, with many friends among the great, the good and the super-rich. Yet he began his career as a penniless Sephardic Jew in the conservative banking environment of Zurich, with no family or connections, isolated and lonely.
fields.body:
"When you are really rich, people come to you," Gilbert de Botton once said to Lucian Freud. De Botton, who has died aged 65, was a powerful, immensely respected financier, with many friends among the great, the good and the super-rich. Yet he began his career as a penniless Sephardic Jew in the conservative banking environment of Zurich, with no family or connections, isolated and lonely.

Born in Alexandria, he attended the Hebrew University of Jerusalem before taking an MA at Columbia University, New York. In 1960, he joined the Zilkha family's investment vehicle, Ufltec, in Zurich. In 1968, he was introduced to Jacob (now Lord) Rothschild, at a time when the family was opening a new bank in Switzerland, Rothschild Bank AG. They started with a tiny office and the "genius" - as Gilbert had been described - and business grew exponentially. He moved briefly to New York to take care of the Rothschild interests there until 1983, when he decided to go it alone.

Gilbert moved to London, founded Global Asset Management (GAM), of which he owned 60% and Jacob Rothschild 40%, and set about changing the way the money of the really wealthy was invested: no longer a safe split between equities and bonds handled in-house by the relevant departments of the firm, but a global and imaginative delegation to the truly knowledgeable.

Gilbert searched the world for expert in each investment area, be it Japanese bonds, American stocks or European currencies. He spread his increasingly large portfolio of assets under management among them, according to his assessment of the risk involved in each area; he started with £lm and ended with more than £10bn. It was a brilliant strategy, and it resulted in GAM being sold in 1999 to UBS for more than £420m, an extraordinary price for a company whose assets were mostly know-how, contacts and credibility.

In those characteristics, the firm reflected its boss. Gilbert was a brilliant man, with the intellectual power to absorb, analyse and understand a mind-boggling amount of information. He was also cultured, suave, witty, modest and authoritative - an impossible combination to resist when first meeting him.

A new client would be invited for lunch in GAM's elegant St James's office, served with delicious, but very light, food and, as the butler took the coffee cups, Gilbert would nonchalantly say: "Let's see how the markets are doing today", while opening a concealed drawer in the table.

A Bond film scene would ensue: shutters would close, blinds come down, the 18th century mirror would come to light with a back-projected screen showing, in vivid colours, the day's activities or, better still, GAM's impressive track record. The client was hooked. Credibility came from Gilbert's total reliability, and his obsessive attention to confidentiality.

Gilbert was also a world expert on the 16th-century French thinker Michel de Montaigne, and had amassed an immense library devoted to his work. Though sometimes aloof - Francis Bacon said to Lucian Freud that Gilbert reminded him of an ancient Egyptian - and often short-tempered with those closest to him, he managed, on the whole, to appear always smiling and courteous and, particularly in recent years, seemed to start relaxing in the happiness that his second wife, Janet Wolfson, brought him.

Both loved art, if not perhaps the same art. Gilbert recognised early the greatness of Picasso's late paintings, and collected the best of them. He bought Freud before it was fashionable, and the painter introduced him to Francis Bacon: both made portraits of Gilbert. Freud worked for a long time on a large canvas, and, realising months later that the picture did not work, started again on a smaller canvas - without the slightest protest from his busy sitter.

Gilbert was also a great benefactor of the Tate Gallery, a trustee (1985-92), the first chairman of both the Tate Gallery Foundation and of the museum's international council. A major gallery of the fifth floor of Tate Modern is named after him.

Ultimately, he was a great intellectual, a scholar who enjoyed applying purity of thought to everything he did, as if to follow in the tradition of a family steeped in learning since the 16th century. His articles on Montaigne, or the world economy, were as subtle as they were learned and sophisticated in construction, and he was immensely proud that his son Alain had become a famous writer. A short and wiry man, he will be remembered by his many friends for his good heart and captivating smile.

He is survived by his wife, and two children from his earlier marriage to Jacqueline Burgauer.

Ultimately, he was a great intellectual, a scholar who enjoyed applying purity of thought to everything he did, as if to follow in the tradition of a family steeped in learning since the 16th century. His articles on Montaigne, or the world economy, were as subtle as they were learned and sophisticated in construction, and he was immensely proud that his son Alain had become a famous writer. A short and wiry man, he will be remembered by his many friends for his good heart and captivating smile. He is survived by his wife, and two children from his earlier marriage to Jacqueline Burgauer.  Gilbert de Botton, banker and art benefactor, born February 16 1935; died August 27 2000

webTitle: Goldman plans to double in size with 20,000 recruits

fields.headline: Goldman plans to double in size with 20,000 recruits
fields.trailText: American investment bank Goldman Sachs plans to double its size within four years by hiring 20,000 staff to take advantage of the continuing boom in technology and telecoms.
fields.body:
American investment bank Goldman Sachs plans to double its size within four years by hiring 20,000 staff to take advantage of the continuing boom in technology and telecoms.

Chief financial officer David Viniar said recruitment was the only constraint to Goldman's growth. He was speaking as the bank reported a 33% surge in third-quarter revenue to $4.53bn.

Goldman has 18,700 workers, with recruitment proceeding fastest outside the US. Mr Viniar expects the payroll to increase by 20% annually for at least five years.

"We're people constrained, we're not market or capital constrained. We see lots of opportunities - the only constraint we see is in actually getting people."

The results confirmed Goldman's position as the world's number one adviser in flotations and stock offerings. The group made profits of $824m and its earnings per share increased 24%, despite a traditional summer slowdown in mergers and acquisitions.

Revenue from trading rose by 46%, and Mr Viniar said most of the gains were from hi-tech investments.

"These results are a testimony to the diversity of our revenue stream, despite the usual seasonal slowdown in some investment banking activities," he said.

Goldman's shares edged up 1.5% in early trading yesterday following publication of the figures, which beat most forecasts.

However, there was scepticism from some analysts. Amy Butte of stockbroker Bear Stearns said much of Goldman's growth had come from growth in private equity revenue.

This type of activity, in private companies, is seen as volatile compared to stockmarket business: "I think Wall Street is going to be a little critical of that."

She also pointed out that Goldman's costs had grown at 35%, while income had risen only 33%.

Among the big deals involving Goldman recently have been Deutsche Telekom's $40bn purchase of Voicestream Wireless, French entertainment group Vivendi's merger with Seagram and Swiss bank UBS's purchase of American stockbroker Paine Webber.

Goldman recently joined the rush to buy middle-ranking finance houses by agreeing a $6.5bn takeover of Spear, Leeds & Kellogg.

webTitle: TUC general secretary speaks out in support of euro

fields.headline: Monks wins ovation over single currency
fields.standfirst: Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: John Monks, TUC general secretary, won an unexpected standing ovation from the Liberal Democrat conference yesterday after calling for immediate moves to beef up the campaign to take Britain into the euro zone.
fields.body:
John Monks, TUC general secretary, won an unexpected standing ovation from the Liberal Democrat conference yesterday after calling for immediate moves to beef up the campaign to take Britain into the euro zone.

"Some of us might wish that we were in the euro already," he said. "But the realpolitik is that we will have to win a referendum some time after the next election," after the pound "has become far more competitive" against the euro.

His call for "a people's Europe, not just a Europe for bankers, boardrooms and bureaucrats" was matched with a warning that the campaign would not be won by conceding key Eurosceptic allegations such as excess regulation which were simply untrue.

In the first appearance by a TUC leader on the main conference platform, Mr Monks, who was invited by Charles Kennedy, stressed how many shared aims and interests the unions and the Lib Dems had.

He took several sideswipes at the government for not going as far as the unions or Lib Dems wanted, though aides said his olive branch to the Lib Dems did not mean he was distancing himself from Labour.

"The TUC both wants and has good relations with this government," said Mr Monks. "We, like you, will make our criticisms, but the contrast with the previous government is all too stark."

In a pointer to the coming election campaign he warned that William Hague's Toryism would remove workers' rights and push Britain towards the American social model - instead of the inclusive European one that Al Gore, the Democrats' presidential candidate, would like to move towards.

His moderate speech, a week after the TUC conference, repeated criticism of the fuel blockades. "You cannot expect governments to cut taxes without spelling out how you would cut spending. These were not just blockades on petrol but blockades on democracy."

fields.headline: Pressure grows on EU ministers
fields.standfirst:
Blockades and go-slow road demos spread
Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: An emergency meeting of European Union transport ministers has been switched from Brussels to Luxembourg today in an attempt to head off anticipated protests by truckers protesting against the high price of petrol.
fields.body:
An emergency meeting of European Union transport ministers has been switched from Brussels to Luxembourg today in an attempt to head off anticipated protests by truckers protesting against the high price of petrol.

Demonstrations continued across Europe yesterday as farmers, truckers and fishermen did their utmost to extract tax cuts from bewildered governments.

For the first time, demon strations spread to Israel, where angry truckers staged a go-slow along the main road linking Haifa with Ashdod.

The European Union believes the protests are set to worsen and today's emergency meeting of transport ministers will discuss harmonising national Vat regimes for fuel and will assess what action can be taken to aid Europe's ailing transport sector.

It is not expected to reach any firm conclusions, diplomats revealed yesterday, and is more likely to be used by the UK as an opportunity to question whether other governments' concessions are in line with EU law.

There were few signs yesterday, however, that protesters will be pacified by mealy-mouthed political pledges.

In Spain, 100,000 farmers drove their tractors through the centre of Madrid and other cities around the country, while the two biggest farming unions warned they would bring the country to a halt unless the government acted.

"We are the first ants of the swarm ... in October we'll cut off roads wherever we have to in order to reach our objective," one union official told a noisy rally in Madrid.

German truckers and taxi drivers also flexed their muscles in an attempt to shake concessions from the chancellor Gerhard Schröder.

Around 300 trucks, buses and taxis blew their horns in unison as they circled Hamburg's inner ring road and traffic was disrupted elsewhere too.

"We will not allow ourselves to be taxed into the abyss," read a slogan in one of the many protests to take place across Germany.

Meanwhile, in Israel truckers warned that yesterday's massive go-slow could only be the tip of the iceberg and should be seen as "a warning shot."

In Scandinavia, Sweden's second largest port, Gothenburg, was snarled for the second day in a row as truckers hampered the movement of freight.

Blockades of the ports at Malmo and Stockholm also showed no signs of abating.

In Ireland fishermen tied up their boats at midday and stopped work for a 24-hour period.

A spokesman complained that fishermen had been hit with a 180% rise in fuel costs in the last 18 months.

fields.headline: Conservatives pledge 3p fuel tax cut
fields.standfirst: Hague pillories Labour for profligacy, lies and arrogance
fields.trailText: Renewing their attack on the government, senior Tories today pledged that the next Conservative administration will cut fuel tax by 3p per litre, or 13.6p per gallon.
fields.body:
Renewing their attack on the government, senior Tories today pledged that the next Conservative administration will cut fuel tax by 3p per litre, or 13.6p per gallon.

This would save a family with a Ford Mondeo £1.85 every time they filled the tank, shadow chancellor Michael Portillo told a press conference at Conservative central office.

He insisted that these reductions were sustainable, accusing the chancellor of hoarding £5bn in surplus revenues. "Everybody knows that Gordon Brown has a war chest," he said. Implementing the changes immediately would cost £525m this year.

The proposed cuts, costing £1.1bn annually, could easily be met, he said. "We have identified reductions in public spending well in excess of that number."

He concluded: "The reduction we propose is prudent, achievable and modest."

Mr Portillo was speaking after an introductory address by Conservative leader William Hague in which he pilloried government profligacy, lies and arrogance.

"It's now beyond dispute that this Labour government wastes vast sums of money and we have the scandal of the Millennium Dome as a monument to that.," he said.

"It is now beyond dispute that this Labour government does not tell the truth - and we now have the chancellor's lies over Formula One as proof of that. And it is now beyond dispute that this Labour government does not listen.

"Tens of millions of people want the government to listen over fuel taxes. It is because they won't listen that those people have come to view this prime minister as arrogant and out of touch."

He criticised both the real-term rise in fuel taxation suggested by the Liberal Democrats and the strategy of "stealth taxation" adopted by the Labour party.

"Tony Blair is still more interested in blaming everyone else for what happened last week. Instead, he should say sorry for his stealth taxes Incredibly, Tony Blair still thinks spin is the only answer," Mr Hague said.

Referring again to the controversy over Bernie Ecclestone's £1m donation to Labour, he described current fiscal policy as "the devious tax-raising methods of a devious chancellor."

While insisting that the petrol and diesel tax cuts were "modest and achievable", he stressed it was not the limit of what a future Conservative government might cut off fuel duty.

Social Security secretary Alistair Darling described Mr Portillo's announcement as "opportunistic" and a "return to the worst of Tory boom and bust". "Michael Portillo was Treasury Chief Secretary when the Tories broke their promises on tax 22 times. This is the man who personally argued for many of these tax rises."

He added: "Rather than William Hague attempting to jump on any passing bandwagon it is time the Tories came clean with the British people and admitted which schools and which hospitals they will cut. The Tories may be serious opportunists but they are not a serious Opposition."

Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy also dismissed the promises. "I don't think that the country will take seriously what William Hague's Conservative party has got to say about tax on this or anything else."

Speaking at the annual party conference in Bournemouth, he said: "They seem to be promising reductions in tax on every available issue and increases in spending on all the right things. Real life isn't like that."

Liberal Democrat environment spokesman Don Foster said: "With the billions they are promising to cut out of the income coming into the Exchequer, they have now got to explain how they are going to fund the quality services the British people want, not least investment in public transport."

Europe's transport minister's are due to meet in Luxembourg later today to discuss the ongoing fuel crisis. Loyola de Palacio, EC commissioner for transport and energy, has warned that EU governments will play into the hands of the oil producers if they compensated for higher basic costs by easing tax. "Member states must resist the temptation, amid demands from certain sectors of the economy, to reduce taxes," she said this morning.

fields.headline: Portillo calls for Brown's resignation
fields.standfirst: Tories also reveal fuel tax cuts plan
fields.trailText: The shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, today renewed calls for Gordon Brown to resign - or be sacked - amid claims he lied about a £1m donation to Labour party funds.
fields.body:
The shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, today renewed calls for Gordon Brown to resign - or be sacked - amid claims he lied about a £1m donation to Labour party funds.

And it came on the day the Tories planned to launch a new offensive in the petrol political war - a proposed cut in fuel duty.

In his first of a two-pronged attack on a floundering Labour Party, Mr Portillo called for the chancellor to leave office for having allegedly deliberately misled the public over the gift from motor racing chief Bernie Ecclestone.

He said Mr Brown's own spokesman had revealed in a statement yesterday, that the chancellor knew about the donation three days before he was interviewed on the BBC radio programme Today, saying he did not.

His second broadside was to announce Tory fuel tax cut plans - to be confirmed later today. He said: "The consensus is that the chancellor of the exchequer has about £4.5 billion more than he reckoned he would have at the time of the Budget. Many people know that Gordon Brown has a war chest and that is why the public have been absolutely unwilling to believe his false claims that he couldn't reduce the petrol tax without affecting vital services."

The Bernie Ecclestone donation was at the centre of a controversy in 1997, amid suggestions that it might have been linked to the Government's unexpected decision at that time to exempt Formula One from a ban on tobacco advertising.

Mr Portillo said: "Sometimes we (politicians) try to avoid issues, but if we are asked something head-on you have really got to answer it. If you are asked 'has there been a donation?', you can't say you don't know, when the truth is the opposite.

"He was asked about a major issue of public policy and asked whether a £1m donation by Bernie Ecclestone had changed party policy. This was not a trivial question.

"It is not a jolly day if people have lost confidence in the Government."

Mr Portillo also reiterated his criticism of the chancellor's handling of the fuel crisis, saying a Tory government would have dealt with the situation better.

"I would not have got myself into this position (over fuel). If the Tories were there (in government), we would not have put petrol prices like this."

Downing Street has so far consistently rejected Mr Portillo's demand for Mr Brown's resignation, and has continued to offer strong backing for the chancellor, who was today attending a meeting of Commonwealth finance meetings in Malta.

webTitle: Sense of crisis as Labour's worries grow

fields.headline: Sense of crisis as Labour's worries grow
fields.standfirst:
In the bunker Fear that poll setback is more than a blip after Ecclestone affair darkens mood

Special report: New Labour in power
Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Already shell-shocked by the petrol crisis that had brought the country close to paralysis, ministers were braced for a hit in the weekend polls.
fields.body:
Already shell-shocked by the petrol crisis that had brought the country close to paralysis, ministers were braced for a hit in the weekend polls. None, however, had foreseen the scale of the turnaround, or that the position would worsen on Monday night with the Guardian's ICM poll. One minister said: "The public is incredibly difficult to read at the moment. We seem to be going through one of those collective outpourings."

Tony Blair's aides yesterday tried to protect the prime minister from the sense of crisis, leaving him alone as much as possible at Chequers to focus on writing next week's conference speech, probably his most important since he became leader six years ago.

But the political atmosphere worsened with the claims in a book by the journalist Andrew Rawnsley that Mr Blair and the chancellor, Gordon Brown, had lied over their handling of the Ecclestone affair.

Margaret Beckett, the leader of the house, was wheeled out to discuss the fuel crisis and the Guardian poll on Radio 4's Today programme, only to find herself being questioned over the Rawnsley allegations.

She claimed she knew nothing of the claims and had not read the newspapers, dismissing the affair as an old story.

As the day wore on, Labour's rebuttal team worked on knocking down the Rawnsley allegations point by point, producing detailed transcripts and original letters, and challenging the veracity of his unsourced quotes.

But inside the beleaguered Treasury, the mood darkened as Mr Brown recognised he had to admit he had discussed the Ecclestone donations with the prime minister.

Meanwhile, at yesterday's meeting of Labour's national executive committee, anxious members expressed concern that the sudden reversal in the opinion polls is not just a short-term blip.

The warnings did not just come from the usual leftwingers, such as Dennis Skinner and Mark Seddon, the editor of Tribune. They also came from normally loyalist union stalwarts, such as Diana Jeudah from the shopworker's union Usdaw, Jeremy Beecham, Labour's senior figure in local government, and Derek Hodgson, general secretary of the Communication Workers' Union.

The party leadership was told bluntly that last week's crisis over fuel revealed a gathering disaffection with the government on other issues, including pensions. Mr Skinner argued passionately that an announcement restoring the pensions link with earnings would change the climate. He warned that some of the party's difficulties stemmed from the perception that "this government is still sitting on a war chest which makes contending groups in society believe there is money to be had".

Overall, the NEC members made it clear that if extra cash is to be dispensed the priority has to be pensioners rather than cuts in fuel duty.

However, inside Downing Street there is equal alarm about fuel duties. Ministers are seriously at odds over how to make concessions on duties and the speed with which they need to be made. With the Conservatives today set to announce a proposed specific cut in fuel duty and the Liberal Democrats already pledged to a five-year freeze, the government is in danger of being left behind. There is also a fear that if the government digs in its heels, only to make concessions later, William Hague's current fragile poll lead might harden, and even grow.

"The longer we delay the inevitable the worse it will be for us," one participant said.

One proposal being floated yesterday was for the chancellor to make a clear indication, perhaps in November, that he will cut petrol duties in the Budget in March if oil prices do not fall substantially.

But some Labour MPs with a European perspective were also pointing to the dangers of concessions. They point to the salutary lesson of the French socialist prime minister, Lionel Jospin.

Mr Jospin is still being punished by his electorate, even though he bowed to the demands of the farmers and truck drivers.

In the long term, it is argued, Mr Blair will benefit from being seen to stick to his principles. These views, naturally enough, are most strongly heard inside the Treasury and some of the big spending departments. The chancellor would like to use next week's conference as the moment in which to launch the fightback and open a challenging debate on the funding of public services.

However, this is partly a matter of striking the right tone. Mr Brown feels passionately he is right and that, at the same time, he is upholding the democratic process by insisting he will not make changes outside the budget cycle.

Downing Street is now trying to reopen lines of communication with the established road haulage groups such as the Road Haulage Association and the Freight Transport Association.

David Green, the director general of the FTA, met the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, last week and will meet transport ministers again tomorrow.

Mr Blair's aides know he needs to do more to highlight the international nature of the oil crisis. He needs to be able to show that this is a crisis made in Opec, and not in Downing Street. Paradoxically, the international rise in the price of oil will increase the anger of the truckers, but reduce Mr Blair's personal responsibility. With protests breaking out all over Europe, the European commission has called an emergency meeting of European transport ministers.

There are also fears that Iraq will use the crisis to cut back production, or even provoke another military confrontation with Kuwait. Iraq exports about 2.3m barrels a day of crude oil into a world market desperate to cut prices.

A cutback by Iraq could push the price up to $40 a barrel. If that happens, Mr Blair's current problems would be dwarfed.

Mr Skinner argued passionately that an announcement restoring the pensions link with earnings would change the climate. He warned that some of the party's difficulties stemmed from the perception that "this government is still sitting on a war chest which makes contending groups in society believe there is money to be had". Overall, the NEC members made it clear that if extra cash is to be dispensed the priority has to be pensioners rather than cuts in fuel duty. However, inside Downing Street there is equal alarm about fuel duties. Ministers are seriously at odds over how to make concessions on duties and the speed with which they need to be made. With the Conservatives today set to announce a proposed specific cut in fuel duty and the Liberal Democrats already pledged to a five-year freeze, the government is in danger of being left behind. There is also a fear that if the government digs in its heels, only to make concessions later, William Hague's current fragile poll lead might harden, and even grow. "The longer we delay the inevitable the worse it will be for us," one participant said. One proposal being floated yesterday was for the chancellor to make a clear indication, perhaps in November, that he will cut petrol duties in the Budget in March if oil prices do not fall substantially. But some Labour MPs with a European perspective were also pointing to the dangers of concessions. They point to the salutary lesson of the French socialist prime minister, Lionel Jospin. Mr Jospin is still being punished by his electorate, even though he bowed to the demands of the farmers and truck drivers. In the long term, it is argued, Mr Blair will benefit from being seen to stick to his principles. These views, naturally enough, are most strongly heard inside the Treasury and some of the big spending departments. The chancellor would like to use next week's conference as the moment in which to launch the fightback and open a challenging debate on the funding of public services. However, this is partly a matter of striking the right tone. Mr Brown feels passionately he is right and that, at the same time, he is upholding the democratic process by insisting he will not make changes outside the budget cycle. Downing Street is now trying to reopen lines of communication with the established road haulage groups such as the Road Haulage Association and the Freight Transport Association. David Green, the director general of the FTA, met the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, last week and will meet transport ministers again tomorrow. Mr Blair's aides know he needs to do more to highlight the international nature of the oil crisis. He needs to be able to show that this is a crisis made in Opec, and not in Downing Street. Paradoxically, the international rise in the price of oil will increase the anger of the truckers, but reduce Mr Blair's personal responsibility. With protests breaking out all over Europe, the European commission has called an emergency meeting of European transport ministers. There are also fears that Iraq will use the crisis to cut back production, or even provoke another military confrontation with Kuwait. Iraq exports about 2.3m barrels a day of crude oil into a world market desperate to cut prices. A cutback by Iraq could push the price up to $40 a barrel. If that happens, Mr Blair's current problems would be dwarfed.

webTitle: Rumours fuel new panic at the pumps

fields.headline: Rumours fuel new panic at the pumps
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Fuel panic and petrol pump queues returned to Britain yesterday as rumours of new refinery blockades and strikes by tanker drivers raced through the country by phone, fax and email.
fields.body:
Fuel panic and petrol pump queues returned to Britain yesterday as rumours of new refinery blockades and strikes by tanker drivers raced through the country by phone, fax and email.

Filling stations from Truro to Glasgow reported swelling lines of cars waiting to top up tanks as drivers relived the stresses of last week's crisis.

The rumours are thought to have originated at a Cardiff radio station. They may have been helped on their way by reports of rising world petrol prices and a defiant response to farmers and truckers by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, who said he would not surrender to their 60-day ultimatum.

Fuel companies and police forces, faced with the growing hysteria, assured motorists that refineries were open, tanker deliveries had not been interrupted and fuel was getting to the pumps. Margaret Beckett, leader of the Commons, called the panic buying "appalling", and strongly denied that it had been sparked by Mr Brown's remarks.

"This is purely a hoax," said a spokesman for the Association of Chief Police Officers. "We have spoken to the petroleum companies and there are no problems. Everything is flowing normally but there seems to be a lot of scaremongering."

But reassurances came too late to prevent many office workers joining the queues at lunchtime. Some found that rationing had already been introduced to conserve stocks.

Police closed many filling stations as queues caused traffic snarl-ups. Newbury in Berkshire ground to a standstill, Milton Keynes was described as "gridlocked" and Burtonwood services on the M62 at Warrington were closed when the queue stretched down the slip road on to the carriageway.

Police in Cheshire, where last week's blockades began at the Stanlow oil refinery, described the rumours as "malicious". At an Esso station in North Shields, Tyne and Wear, Bob Cockburn said trade "had gone ballistic" and added: "It has kicked off again after what Brown and Blair said about not recognising the 60-day deadline.

"At the height of the crisis last week, we were selling 3,000 litres an hour. Today I think we are getting close to that figure again."

In Yorkshire, internet claims that taxi drivers were about to renew the fuel blockade were blamed for the petrol buying panic. There were reports of a driver buying £1.20 worth of fuel in Huddersfield, and a woman trying to fill a washing-up bowl in Leeds.

The Transport and General Workers' union said that none of its tanker driver members was involved in any official or unofficial action.

BP warned that if the panic buying continued, 46 sites previously designated for emergency services might have to be closed to the public. "The panic buying is putting extra pressure on an already difficult task," a spokesman said.

webTitle: Radio rumour, gossip and then chaos

fields.headline: Radio rumour, gossip and then chaos
fields.standfirst:
Careless talk How a local radio chat unwittingly caused 'mad' day of new queues
Special report: the petrol war
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The tone of the conversation was light-hearted, almost banal.
fields.body:
The tone of the conversation was light-hearted, almost banal.

As Warren Moore, popular drivetime presenter on the commercial radio station Red Dragon FM, jokingly put his newsreader Stuart McTeer on the spot about rumours of new fuel blockades, he could not have dreamt of the storm which was about to be unleashed.

By next morning queues were forming on forecourts of petrol stations in Dragon FM's south Wales constituency. By noon the panic was spreading across the country. Petrol station managers from Cornwall to Scotland were being besieged by frantic motorists. Some were rationing fuel, others were having to turn off their pumps because they were overheating.

A nationwide police operation co-ordinated from Scotland Yard swung into action. The leader of the House of Commons was rushed in front of the cameras to lend a hand in the firefighting exercise. And the government's enemies were once again making political capital of the panic.

Rumour

The day - described by one senior police officer as "simply mad" - was a vivid illustration of how easily another real fuel crisis could bring the country to its knees. It also gave the psychologists an insight into the power of rumour and the rather British proclivity to panic buy.

Last night Red Dragon FM, which boasts a listenership of 301,000, was doing its own firefighting exercise in trying to play down its role in the chaos. It claimed that the rumour had not started at the Cardiff-based station, though station bosses conceded they had repeated it.

According to Texaco, Red Dragon rang it after the conversation was broadcast. Spokeswoman Nicole Hutchings said: "The radio station rang us to seek clarification. There was absolutely no truth in the rumour but once it has been broadcast it is obviously very hard to quash it."

Throughout the evening Red Dragon put out bulletins stressing that there was to be no new blockade. But it was too late: the genie was out of the bottle.

Down the road at Cardiff General Service Station, manager Brian Smith had been enjoying seeing business getting back to normal after last week's trauma. He said: "It was business as usual all day - and then all of a sudden queues started forming. It was just like last week. People were really panicking. I was serving until 1.30am when I closed and the garage up the road was still very busy then."

Rumours reached the pubs of south Wales. Motorist Holly Thomas, 21, said: "I was out for the evening in the pub and word went around very quickly that the blockades were back on. People were leaving to go and fill their cars up."

By the morning South Wales police had been forced to reopen its fuel command room, staffed by 20 people with the job of taking calls from the public and liaising with other forces, the government and the petrol companies. Superintendent Bob Evans, head of the traffic and operations department, did the rounds of the radio and television stations trying to calm the fever.

But it was no good. Driver John Morris, 52, who queued 40 minutes to fill up, said: "People at work told me about the fuel crisis this morning and I'm not taking any chances. It's better to be safe than sorry."

And then the rumours began to spread. First petrol stations in the south west were hit. Then the hysteria moved to the rest of the south. Then it enveloped the country. Quite how the rumours spread so far remains unclear. Some police forces believe they found their way on to internet sites. Others believe it was simply word of mouth. By the time the police and government began their drive to reassure the public it was too late, and many motorists simply did not believe the words of comfort.

By lunchtime assistant chief constable Bernard Hogan-Howe at Scotland Yard's police national information centre was seriously concerned. Police around the country were put on alert.

The Association of Chief Police Officers, which normally does not get involved with operational affairs, put out a statement calling for calm, and its president, Sir John Evans, appealed to the public in radio and television interviews. But still the panic continued.

The Elf garage on busy Leeds Street in Liverpool ran out of fuel by 2pm as a mile-long queue formed. Breakdown and repair firm worker Lee Bryant, 19, was one of the last people to get fuel before it ran out. He said: "We got a tip off from another garage that someone had blockaded Stanlow again. Then it came on the radio that it was just a rumour but we did not dare take the chance."

Across the country the pattern was repeated. Some service stations in the East Midlands closed early to conserve supplies. At the Sainsbury filling station on Civic Way, Derby, police described the situation as "mayhem", while the Texaco garage at the city's Pentagon Island was described as "gridlocked". Queues began to build up in Glasgow.

Nobody was sure quite how the rumours spread so far so quickly.

Buying

Paul Edwards, chairman of consumer consultancy the Henley Centre, said that panic buying tended to be fuelled both by the media and the great power of word of mouth.

He said: "It's a funny thing. You see a picture of an empty shelf and think 'My shelves are going to be like that soon'. People also rationalise what they are doing. They think: 'I'm not going to panic buy but I'll have to get extra supplies because everyone else will panic buy'.

Mr Edwards said British panic buying may go back went back to wartime rationing. "That may be long ago but I think the temptation still remains to buy supplies while they are there or they will vanish."

In January Buckingham Palace was moved to issue a statement that the Queen Mother was well after a rumour that she had died gripped the country. Newspapers and radio and television stations were bombarded by worried callers even though the rumour had not been broadcast or reported. It was thought that the rumour had spread purely by word of mouth.

Another element which may have come into play in yesterday's crisis was the internet. Some police forces believed that the rumour had been spread via internet sites.

Of course, political capital was to be made. The shadow transport minister, Bernard Jenkin, said: "This kind of public reaction shows that people have no faith that the government has solved this crisis."

The Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, called on ministers to restore calm by providing reliable information on any threats to supply.

The leader of the Commons, Margaret Beckett, said the way the situation had developed was "quite appalling", and put the blame firmly on the radio station in south Wales. Back at Red Dragon FM, a chastened presenter and newsreader were no doubt ruefully reflecting on their flippant Monday afternoon conversation.

fields.headline: Protests on continent
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: In France, where the original protests began, the prime minister, Lionel Jospin, has agreed to cut fuel taxes for truckers and fishermen, but his personal ratings have still suffered the biggest month-on-month fall ever recorded for a French prime minister and there are demands for further tax cuts.
fields.body:
In France , where the original protests began, the prime minister, Lionel Jospin, has agreed to cut fuel taxes for truckers and fishermen, but his personal ratings have still suffered the biggest month-on-month fall ever recorded for a French prime minister and there are demands for further tax cuts.

In Germany the chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, is under intense public pressure to scrap a plan to raise petrol taxes in January, but refuses to yield. He has signalled that he may bring in more tax cuts for car commuters and help pensioners with their heating-oil bills. But truckers and farmers are restless and look likely to step up their protests.

In the Netherlands there is no such pressure. The government has given in to protesters' demands and agreed a £200m package of subsidies to the transport sector. Taxes for diesel and less polluting fuels are also set to be cut.

Paralysis in Belgium led the prime minister, Guy Verhofstadt, to adopt a similar approach and he has reluctantly approved a £40m aid package. Truckers are to be allowed to postpone road tax and social security payments, and tax on vehicle insurance is to be cut.

In Ireland the government finds itself in a similar position to Tony Blair and ministers have indicated that they will only consider tax cuts in the context of the 2001 budget, due in early December.

In Spain the government has ruled out a cut in a special petrol tax, but talks continue and there are rumours that Madrid is willing to offer a £150m aid package to offset petrol prices.

The government of Sweden is mulling its options. The social democrat prime minister,Goeran Persson, said protesters should focus their anger on the oil companies and oil-producing countries.

In Norway the government has also resisted calls to cut fuel tax, despite sitting on an enormous nest egg accrued as a result of its massive oil revenues. It is the second biggest oil exporter in the world.

In Israel the government has given some ground, although the prime minister, Ehud Barak, believes petrol prices are low compared to Europe. But truckers claimed yesterday that the government had agreed to adjust the price of diesel fuel each month, based on an international average.

fields.headline: Tories promise fuel duty reduction
fields.standfirst:
Pledge means spending cuts says Labour
Special report: the petrol war
Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Michael Portillo's pledge today of a "significant cut" in petrol and diesel taxes - probably at least 5p a litre - will spark a huge party political row about spending cuts and the state of North Sea oil revenues.
fields.body:
Michael Portillo's pledge today of a "significant cut" in petrol and diesel taxes - probably at least 5p a litre - will spark a huge party political row about spending cuts and the state of North Sea oil revenues.

The Tories are certain to use figures from last year's national audit office pre-budget analysis to claim that petrol prices can be cut significantly because Gordon Brown is already getting a "windfall tax" following the jump in oil prices from $22 a barrel last year to $34 today.

Labour will claim that to rely on oil to raise revenue will not work, because of the rapid change in prices.

This, it will claim, would lead the Tories to introduce spending cuts in the NHS and other public services when the price dives.

The audit office's analysis is likely to feature highly in the argument.

It shows the chancellor's budget finances were based on a North Sea price of $22. By the time of the budget, the price had reached $22.8.

The audit office estimates that for each one dollar rise in the oil price, the chancellor gets an extra £330m a year. With the North Sea price now $12 higher, the chancellor should be getting about £4bn extra a year.

That figure is disputed by the Treasury, where a spokesmen said that it would depend on the oil price staying at over $34 for the whole year. So far the price has only been that high for a month, and could easily fall back. As a result revenues have been much lower.

The loss to the revenue of a 1p cut in petrol and diesel tax is estimated at £500m.

Thus, in theory, the windfall gives the chancellor an opportunity to cut taxes by up to 8p a litre.

John Redwood, the former shadow trade secretary, used these figures in a back of an envelope calculation, when he gave an interview to his local radio station last week, saying that petrol taxes could be cut by 5p immediately.

Mr Redwood said yesterday: "There is a windfall tax and some of it should be given back.

"The chancellor has not made any announcement of any further increased spending on schools and hospitals since the summer so this extra money was not intended for that and could be given back."

The windfall figures have also been highlighted by Maurice Fitzpatrick, a partner in the accountancy firm Chantery Vellacott.

He wrote to Tony Blair, suggesting that petrol duties should fluctuate like the oil price, stabilising the cost of petrol.

The Treasury dismisses this as impracticable, saying the oil companies might not pass on all the cuts when the price went down.
